I finally understood that the jarring transitions and lack of obvious exposition are deliberate narrative devices to place the audience in the same unsettling place as Evelyn as she tries to make sense of what is happening to and around her. Editor Paul Rogers deserves either an Oscar or a long prison sentence, because his work here is either inspired or demented, or possibly both.Did I mention the performances? Did I mention how good they are? Considering how off the wall the film is, they are uniformly excellent. Committed, emotional, moving, and often very funny. Michelle Yeoh holds the film together as Evelyn manages to be put-upon, stoic, saddened by frustration, and sometimes very very silly. It is a pleasure to see Ke Huy Quan as Waymond so many years after Goonies and Indy 2 - I recognised his voice before I recognised him. Stephanie Hsu is phenomenal as daughter Joy and multiverse destroying villain Jobu Tupaki. I can't believe how long it took me to recognise the tax lady - ominously villainous and hysterically funny at the same time.Because that's another feature of this movie - it's really funny, with some great lines (You're capable of anything because you're so bad at everything.") I laughed out loud quite often in a small auditorium. I was not alone.And, as the end approached (I still had no idea what to expect), and two rocks, one with google eyes, had a conversation in a universe where life had never begun, I wept.It's that sort of film.You may read this and think "That sounds awful," in which case don't see it. You'll hate it. But if you think "That sounds a bit different, interesting," then I urge you to give it a chance. I assure you that you will never have seen a film remotely like it.

I have a high expectations of this movie not only the high rating but also with positive reviews about its creativity and implication. I end up getting a sound sleep at the last half hour. It starts off not that bad with developing some funny characters but then it get lost with having just a single plot about a woman's head splitting. This scene pops up over hundred times which becomes a kind of nuisance and chaos.

reviews.review_title: This is not your father's meta verse story.
reviews.content: First and foremost, you won't see a more original movie this year, or many years following. The story is not straightforward and requires several viewings to pick up on all the nuances of what is being told here. It literally is Everything Everywhere All at Once. In no way is this film meant to be serious though it does touch upon existentialism. Ok, more than touch it. It's the theme of the whole movie. In a nutshell (from what I understood) the movie shows us that every choice we make in our life creates a new alternative universe we can choose to live. Therefore we have hundreds of "lives" we live with regrets. How we live those lives is up to us.This is definitely a comedy more than science fiction. If you go into it with that in mind you can allow your mind to wrap around that concept. I give a ton of credit to the actors as this had to be a very hard script to put together. On top of the layers, movies are shot out of order so having to jump into the characters at random times would be a mind meld. The actors did an outstanding job with their portrayals of the layers of their life without being too much "in" on the joke. EEA doesn't assume we follow the plot anymore than the characters do. It doesn't insult our intelligence at the same time. Follow? Of course not. It's not meant to make complete sense. There are many stories within a story. So much of it is so outlandish that we cannot assume to take everything so seriously.There are a lot of serious tones in the film as well. Divorce, parenting mistakes, tax problems, success or the lack of it, love, and death are all there. But so are bagels, butt plugs, dogs being swung around as a weapon, hot dog fingers (I hope Dwight Shrute takes credit for that gag), and googly eyes to name a few.In the (real) end, (there is a false ending in the middle of the film) we are left wondering, " what the hell did I just watch?", feeling but we also can't stop thinking about "what the hell? Did I just just watch that?"I recommend EEA based on the themes, the acting, and originality. When someone complains there are no original ideas in Hollywood any longer, turn them on to this movie.If you like The Matrix, Kill Bill, Being John Malkovich, and Into the Spider-verse you will probably enjoy EEAAO. If you like romantic comedies and straight forward movies that walk you through every plot line then you will not get through this film.Side note: Kudos to Jamie Lee Curtis for her outlandish comedic acting. She is hardly recognizable and very funny here. Michelle Yeoh channels her Crouching Tiger...role and that's fun to watch. I also didn't realize that Short Round played her husband. He's all grown up (like we do as we age). All of them did an excellent job and we should see their names on the Oscar nomination lists soon.

reviews.review_title: What rubbish did I just watch??? 🤔
reviews.content: I watched this movie because if the high ratings it got. Well.... What a load of rubbish!From starting off fairly normaly it quickly decends into a mess of rubbish and confusion that I can only described as Jackie Chan meets Mr and Mrs Smith in Marvel Multiverse which simply DOES NOT WORK.Nuff zed.

I used to make sure I watched the January Man each year on New Years' day. I took pride in liking the film so much when more than one film guide described it using words to the effect 'in the weird movie museum, this film has its own wing'. Everything Everywhere...has its own museum.Ever been in a group on a project trying to come up with ideas and writing them all down to select the better ones? The writers did that without the selection part. They just used all of the ideas constantly throughout. To say the film lacks focus is to say Mozart wrote some music.There is a false ending not far from the film's climax that could as easily have been the real thing. I remember watching 8 1/2 and falling asleep for 45 minutes. Never felt like the film made less sense. Everything Everywhere... is like that.

reviews.review_title: Really not a hater at all
reviews.content: I made an account just to make a review for this film. From trailers and online hype I was very excited to see this. I adore Michelle yeoh and James Hong. I also thought it was cool that Key Hu Quan had a lead role after such a long absence from Hollywood. That being said the movie was just terrible. Spoilers ahead. Yeoh is a Chinese immigrant who owns a laundromat. And her father comes to visit. She is afraid to introduce her daughter's girlfriend to him because homosexuals is bad in Chinese culture. She later goes to do her taxes and is visited by a version of her husband from another universe and gives her instructions. She is told she needs battle a great enemy to save her universe which we come to find out is her daughter from another universe. So essentially the message is she needs to forget her old Chinese ways and accept her gay daughter. A storyline thats been done a million times. Hollywood as a whole might be in trouble if they keep catering to one category of people. This movie had so much potential. With the ensemble cast. But it just sucked so bad. The different universes they use and sequence are just flat out dumb. I'm convinced people behind making this film paid critics and others to come on here and make reviews. It currently has 8.5 on here as I write this. What in the world ? There are classics that don't even have an 8.5 this movie should be at 6/10 at best. Don't know what is going on with the industry. If the movie was THAT great then why did a make so little money. Doesn't matter that's and indy film. If this movie was as good as it's hype it would have at least made 200-300 mil.. it made 50mil on a 25 mil budget.

Don't ask. Go and see it, because you've never seen a movie quite like this one. It is a fantasy/comedy, but at times that is reversed. I will now make an attempt at a review.The middle-aged owner of a failing Chinese laundry is being audited by the IRS, her lesbian daughter brings her 'friend' home for a visit, her infantile husband is of marginal help and her father is senile. On a visit to the IRS her husband reveals himself as an alien who can show her how marvelous her life would have been in other galaxies, to which he gives her access.Sound confusing? Just go and see it. It is extremely entertaining, and I'm going to see it again to fill in the considerable number of incoherent spots I still have. Oscar noms for Best Actress (are they still called that?) Michelle Yeoh and for Editing and Special Effects.P. S. The hole in the bagel represents the way to inner peace. (Don't ask).7******* Website no longer prints my star rating.

The first recommendation when watching EVERYTHING EVERYWHERE ALL AT ONCE is to not try to figure out what is going on in this movie during the first 1/2 hour to 45 minutes. This will drive you mad. Just sit back and enjoy the mind-bending experience you are having.After that point, either it will click in your brain...or it won't. If it does - great! If not...continue to sit back and enjoy the mind-bending experience you are having.For...EVERYTHING EVERYWHERE ALL AT ONCE is a trippy head-trip of a film that is certainly unique - but it also has something going for it that all good films do - characters that you will care about in a story that will touch your heart.Written and Directed by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert (SWISS ARMY MAN), EVERYTHING...tells the tale of unhappily married couple Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh) and Waymond Wang (Ke Huy Quan), her father Gong Gong (the great James Hong) and their daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu). When interdimensional travel interrupts their mundane life, things get much, much more than mundane.Yes, folks, you read that right INTERDIMENSIONAL TRAVEL - and this is not a Marvel movie! Evelyn and family start jumping to parallel dimensions, experiencing everything, everywhere...all at once (hence, the name of the film).This is a smart, unique and visually interesting film and credit for this must go to Wang and Scheinert. They have come up with something unusual. However, they don't just do "unusual for unusual sake" they wrap this film up - and connect the dots - in a satisfying way in the end. Oh...and they also build in some incredibly impressive fight scenes along the way. To not hype them too much, but these are the best fight scenes that have been on film in quite some time - certainly the most interesting and unique since the JOHN WICK films.The duo, smartly, enlisted the aid of the underappreciated - but very talented - Michelle Yeoh (CRAZY RICH ASIANS) as the protagonist of this piece. It is a wise choice for she must go from mousey housewife to kick-butt SuperHero (and everywhere in between) throughout the course of this film and her Martial Arts background comes in very, very handy. It is a bravura performance by Yeoh and it would be TERRIFIC if her name is called come awards season next year (yes, it is that good of a performance).She is ably assisted by Hong (a veteran character actor with more than 450 credits to his name), Hsu (known for her role as Mei in THE MARVELOUS MRS. MAISEL) and, especially Quan (the kid "Short Round" who assists the hero in INDIANA JONES AND THE TEMPLE OF DOOM) - it was good to see Quan back on the big screen.The filmmakers also sprinkle some very strong character actors/actresses in the mix here. Both Jenny Slate (Mona-Lisa Saperstein in PARKS & REC) and Harry Shum, Jr. (GLEE, CRAZY RICH ASIANS) are fun in small roles as is the aforementioned James Hong as Gong Gong (the Grandfather).But...the person who ALMOST steals this film from Ms. Yeoh is the incomparable Jamie Lee Curtis as the somewhat overweight and out of shape IRS Agent who plays a pivotal role in Evelyn's life across the Dimensions. It is a fun role for Curtis who is not afraid to look physically bad. Again, I would LOVE IT if she got some love come awards time next year (she won't, but maybe in some other parallel Universe she would).Not for everyone - the multi-dimensional travel is going to give some folks a headache as they try to figure things out - but if you surrender yourself to the wildness that is going on, and embrace the spirit and the heart of this film, you will be rewarded with a very rich film going experience.Letter Grade: A-8 Stars out of 10 (might move up to 9 on a rewatch) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

I have never felt this way after a movie that I feel now. I left the theater delirious, feeling drunk almost. I laughed. I cried. I felt despair, and hope, and everything all at the same time. I made it home just in time for me to bawl again and then laugh. This movie is a masterpiece of cinema, and a masterpiece of life. Run, don't walk, to see this movie.

reviews.review_title: Michelle Yeoh in the Multiverse of Madness
reviews.content: Why take drugs when you can experience whatever fever dream this film was?Truly one of the most bonkers and most creative movies I've ever seen! Phenomenal performances, great characters, an engaging story, an amazing soundtrack, stunning visuals, cool action sequences, and genuinely funny moments while exploring deep themes and having a touching message that will no doubt resonate with audiences.If you don't watch this movie then you are committing a crime! One of the best experiences of 2022.

reviews.review_title: I love this movie, but I hate it.
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All at Once is the strangest I've ever seen and I've never been so split in half by a movie. It's: a comedy, but not that funny. An action film, but too much drama. A love movie, but not seriously. The Matrix, but not really. A kung-fu flick, but not nearly enough fighting scenes to be considered one. A dark toned thriller, but too many chuckles for it. Smart, but stupid. A profound revelation, but its everyday things I'm aware of already.I'm torn.

reviews.review_title: Contemporary cinema at its most cosmic yet most intimate, this is a triumph for the ages
reviews.content: Charlie Kaufman once wrote "Everything is more complicated than you think. You only see a tenth of what is true. There are a million little strings attached to every choice you make; you can destroy your life every time you choose. But maybe you won't know for twenty years. And you'll never ever trace it to its source. And you only get one chance to play it out". I can start with nothing better to talk about an immense new movie, the Daniels' "Everything everywhere all at once".This hyperreal piece of art comes to us quietly sampling something that crosses our path only every decade or so to remind us that there is still more to explore in our collective cultural consciousness and that we are yet to discover a fraction of what a truly good script can do; How images can transform a script to something better, deeper, and more effective; How a harmonious marriage of script and picture can explore emotional depths that are commonly visited yet rarely understood. "Everything everywhere all at once" is only the second movie project of its writers/directors. Their first was a subject of small talks at drunk parties and "the weirdest I have seen" conversations, the story of a desperate loner who was saved by a dead body that mainly flatulates then comes alive to ask existential questions about the meaning of life, "Swiss Army Man". That project might have been too eccentric and much ahead of its time for the common taste, but it was a true eye-opener. Now, after 6 years since that ambitious project and the experience it distilled, comes this utterly more marvelous achievement."Everything everywhere all at once" is impossible to describe and synopsizing it is unjust as it is a true and rare symbiosis of script and picture, each highlighting the other, making each and the whole something more than words can explain. But perhaps to describe it best -and you must see it yourself to try and state your own- it's a surreal psychedelic journey through the eyes of a financially struggling immigrant nuclear family with their crumbling owned business and their cyclical hopeless life and what bent it of their dying hopes, missed opportunities, decaying bounds, and their valiant efforts to maybe bring some love and tradition and purpose back to it. This essence of the story is challenged by the simple concept of "what if" through a theme of a multiverse with characters sliding through the different possible versions of themselves to try and find meaning through the overwhelming nonsense of their lives.There are many aspects that make this movie a bombastic one. The screenplay introduces a simple premise but then quickly, continuously, and relentlessly evolves into absurd levels that are unpredictable and, frankly, unprecedented throughout the whole runtime, effectively challenging your sense of what is "enough". The story is an adventure of cosmic proportions of characters and characters' versions of themselves that then is juxtaposed with its intimate origins. And so, this gargantuan design is just an external manifestation of the emotional depths of a dialogue between a mother, a father, a daughter, a grandfather, and a tax auditor in the span of 6 hours of one day of their tiny lives. It's childish and hilarious and creepy. It is a meticulous machine that keeps discovering unimaginable dimensions to portray an intense emotional and philosophical battle between purpose and nihilism, and then purpose through nihilism. The script actively prevents itself from committing to a moral conclusion. It juggles continuously -as life is and any grasp on it- between the hopeful and the hopeless and is only bound by accepting the inevitability of chaos while rejecting the perceived destiny of loneliness.This immense script wouldn't have made this piece without the visuals. Here, the actual pictures do not only serve as a representation of the script but also feel that they have their own identity. The visuals are utterly and out worldly surreal, like a Salvador Dalí or a David lynch or a stargate sequence of Kubrick's Space Odyssey. They are beautifully influenced by the exciting and fun Chinese martial arts Jackie Chan movies, the action/mystery of "The Matrix", the eerie imagery of Charlie Kaufman's "Eternal sunshine of the spotless mind", "Synecdoche New York", and "Adaptation", and Wong Kar-Wai's sexy romantic spectacle "In the mood for love".Script and picture being their own separate entities in this movie needed a masterful editor, and here too it excels. This cinematic piece could have been easily a disorienting mess of random events and visual madness, but what the editing actually achieves is a story that is easily followed and understood with characters that are poignant, close, and intimate, creating relatability that captivates and elates. The acting is flawless, specifically on the parts of Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan, who both complete and finesse. The cinema that comes from all these passionately crafted ingredients creates what can be described as a particle accelerator that elaborately assaults the senses, with passion, from every angle, generating a hilarious, creepy, and immensely emotional journey that will undoubtedly leave you to tears on many occasions, and then latch on to you with a fantastic and inspiring after taste.The Daniels wrote and directed "Everything everywhere all at once" to make it look like a marvel blockbuster but with the spirit and the feel of an art-house independent picture, effectively thriving through the fierce competition that is threatening creativity in cinema. They -either willingly with the audacity of an artist, or instinctively through the passion of a child explorer- ditched the three-act structure of a script and then went above and beyond with a bizarre and mind-blowing cinematic exploration of the depths of meaning and love. It is contemporary yet traditional, enormous yet intimate, focused yet living up to its title; It is truly Everything first, everywhere second, then all together all at once. This picture is an absolute triumph, a true masterpiece, one of the best movies in the last 20 years, and one of the most beautiful things I personally have ever seen. Be sure not to miss it.

Started well..ended in nonsense
Certainly not as great as everyone was making out and definitely not worth a score of 8.5. A clever idea but wasted, a shame.

This movie about meaninglessness is, ironically, equally meaningless.Except for tiny emotional touches of depth near the end about the only emotionally engaging thing in the film; the dysfunctional family relationships, dysfunctional family patterns and how to grow as a person and not be a heartless robot going through the monotony of a self-chosen way of life.They should've kept to the story and cut out completely useless and nonsensical headache and seizure-inducing visuals.I suggest watching Dirk Gently instead for way more fun (eeaao wasn't funny in the slightest Except with the rocks) and more meaningful craziness. Also Cloud Atlas.

reviews.review_title: Must See, but Gets Really Stressful
reviews.content:
-Handles multiverses really well.-LOVE THE OUTFITS.-LOVE THE ACTORS
-What a unique and cool premise, as well as diverse characters
-Love that the lesson is learning from those around you and that fighting with good is always an option
-AMAZING SETS AND CHOREOGRAPHY
-Great music
-Also love how outrageous it is. It tackles a sci-fi multiverse story with the tenacity of an overblown and ridiculous kung fu film-Only issue would be it hits to close to home for me in the beginning. I was SO STRESSED during the first half that it bring it down a star. I love that is was so dramatic but it was just... ouch hit too close.

reviews.review_title: Every bad wierd movie all at once
reviews.content: I've seen alot of wierd films. I was interested in giving this one ago whilst ignoring my better judgement. This is beyond wierd. Really daft and maybe a little bit woke. This film seems like it was written for school kids and tried waaay to hard to be funny. It was embarrissingly silly and stupid. One of the few films I would have quit after 20 minutes had I not been watching it with the missus (green lantern was the other). IMDb 8.1 rating!!!. I can only guess this is because the majority of the views don't watch much out of typical Hollywood movies and found it different (maybe I'm wrong). Imo it's possibly the worst film iv'e every seen. Next time I'll trust my judgement.

reviews.review_title: You will either get it, or you wont.
reviews.content: This movie wont be for everyone. For all of you, this might be a crazy chaotic mess of things going on. That might not mean you wont like it, just take it for what it is and enjoy. But if you end up being confused by it all... well, don't say I did not warn you! LolBut for those that do know what this movie is about, where they draw their inspiration, you know this movie is awesome!This movie has so much going on that its definitely worth watching more then once. Much like where it comes from, it takes time to unpack it. So expect to revisit this movie again if you plan to watch it the first time.

reviews.review_title: Just wasted 2 hours of my life on this garbage
reviews.content: I usually don't write reviews, but this "movie" encouraged me to do so after I feel a victim to a bunch of 10/10 reviews and decided to give it a shot.Tasteless, with "humour" deserving low-budget student-made film, this pretentious piece tries to touch philosophical matters but does it with so little quality it almost pains to watch. Just a set of arbitrary kung-fu scenes mixed with tasteless humour.If we look at IMDB Top-250 we will see "12 Angry men", "Seven samurai" and other amazing movies having similar rating to this. Does anyone even dare to compare those movies to this piece?I wish people who rate it 10/10 and mark as "masterpiece" would explain why they think it is so. Watched until the end trying to find any sense to absolute failure. Wish would have walked out.

This movie could have worked if the script did not try so hard to be "woke" and to be funny. It will appeal to like-minded individuals, no doubt, but a few changes and a more "finger on the pulse" direction would have made this movie a lot better.

Is it sci-fi? Barely. Is it comedy? Maybe a little. Is it a drama? Humm... I'm not sure. Is it a romance? ... Maybe not... So what is it? A big confusion disguised as a huge movie. Well overrated. It can be seen a mix of an old format of Chinese and American movies and a general pleased performance of the actors. The story can be resumed in a multiverse were infinite individual possibilities can originate ONE personality that wants to fix and overcome all the others, without any group context that characterises spieces or survival and a second one that antagonise the "vilan". When i saw sci -fi so well rated immediately commes into my mind: 2001 space odyssey or Stalker or even Interstellar but in the end i cant call it sci-fi. If you are looking for a nice Saturday afternoon easy film to entertain that's a good choice, for a cinema movie, better not...

The movie had potential to go into a serious direction but instead it became a parody comedy with bad special effects. It looked liked a Youtube video from 2012 that imitates a music video. The randomness destroyed all the meaning in the plot.

The title of co-directors Daniel Kwon and Scheinert's 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' will aptly clue you in to this head-scratcher you're in store for. Indeed if you may have seen this movie's old long-lost Uncle entitled 'Adventures of Buckeroo Bonzai into the 8th Dimension, you know what kind of zaniness the directors and story-tellers are going for. This is concept movie that kinda wears out for a lack of focus probably purposely. By the last 20 minutes I'd lost interest and was fast-forwarding. I liked seeing 'Short Stuff' back in a co-leading role, and Michelle Yeoh did everything asked of her, but the movie is like weird dream - the ones you don't remember after 3 min waking up.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a film like no other that effortlessly switches between painfully funny comedy, impressive action and heartfelt drama. A truly original film that covers so many genres and ideas without ever losing sight of the extremely emotional core at the centre of its truly ambitious narrative.Michelle Yeoh has never been better with an incredible lead performance that utilises all of her talents. Ke Huy Quan makes a triumphant return with a performance and character that's endlessly loveable. Stephanie Hsu is also impressive, skillfully switching between antagonist and emotional core.The direction by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert is phenomenal, always visually striking, endlessly inventive and the fight scenes are impressively shot, exciting and impactful. The visual effects are ridiculously impressive, especially considering the lower budget.The pacing is extremely strong, gaining momentum early on and never losing it. The music by Son Lux is fantastic, swapping genres along with film perfectly whilst also keeping the core style and voice when necessary.

reviews.review_title: I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish, I Wish
reviews.content: I wish I could lend my eyes and ears and my mind to the ones who didn't quite grasp this movie so they too could see how every single scene in it is a marvel.One guy in a review below misses the entire point while debating the complexities of a multiverse. How do you explain a movie ike this to someone like that? You can't.

reviews.review_title: 1st part was so good then it got too silly and repetitive
reviews.content: I wish the movie had stayed within the parameters of part 1 cause it had already jumped the shark but somehow managed to keep some seriousness intact but then they started to add a bunch of weird elements just for the sake of it showing their intention was to make a quirky comedy and slowly all the provoking thoughts it had created in my mind started to fade. I still loved some of the messages behind the movie but it got so repetitive and nonsensical. She acquires abilities from other people but they never explain how they can change physical elements and also out of the billion versions of the multiverse they only show like 10 versions max, while focusing only on 5. It gave that silly cloud atlas vibe. Definitely a very fun movie to watch but lost the opportunity to be what everyone is praising it to be.

I love weird movies. But this movie is just ... ok. The 8.x rating makes no sense.. it's just an unnecessarily long mish mash of random things added in just for the sake of being weird and then finally a heart strings pull at the end. Sounds very much like the director's own movie 'Swiss Army Man' but with more of Radcliffe's corpses. Feels like movies like this were made because the creatives are tripping and is also obligated to deliver preachy themes and forced pandering.

reviews.review_title: Highly original and exhausting at the same time
reviews.content: As "Everything Everywhere All at Once" (2022 release; 139 min.) opens, we are introduced to Evelyn Quan, who along with her husband, runs a laundromat. For reasons unknown, the laundromat is being audited by the IRS, and a meeting with the IRS auditor does not go well. Then out of the blue, Evelyn's mind is taken over by her husband's alternative from the Alphaverse, one of apparently thousands of alternative universes out there... At this point we are 10 minutes into the movie.Couple of comment: this is the latest from writers-producers-directors Daniel Kwam and Daniel Scheineret (a/k/a "the Danierls"). This is only their second feature length movie, after 2016's critically acclaimed "Swiss Army Man". Like that movie, in "Everything Everywhere All at Once" they bring a highly original premise and story line. Frankly, the plot is so off kilter that it doesn't even make any sense, nor need it be. Instead, one simply sits back and enjoys whatever is unfolding on the screen. Michelle Yeoh is outstanding as Evelyn. I didn't realize that the IRS auditor is played by Jamie Lee Curtis until the credits rolled. I don't know if others felt the same, but I felt a bit overwhelmed, if npot exhausted, by it all and I watched the entire movie over two equal parts on consecutive evenings. That does not mean that I didn't like the movie, let me be clear."Everything Everywhere All at Once" was an unexpected box office hit during its US theatrical run that started last Spring, For whatever reason I just didn't feel drawn to it. Then earlier this week, it gathered an amazing 11 Oscar nominations, more than any other film, and I told myself I really needed to find out what the buzz was all about. I watched the film earlier this week (it's streaming on Showtime). Glad I did. If you are in the mood for truly something very different and uniquely original, I'd readily suggest you check this out, and draw your own conclusion.

reviews.review_title: I liked it a lot, but even if you didn't, you must admit it's remarkably creative and ambitious
reviews.content: There's no question that EEAAO is one of the most well-regarded movies of the year, and it's leading the charge in Oscar nominations with a total of 11. It's is to be expected, since it's very much not a blockbuster and more the type of film the Academy would tend to award. At the same time, it is a bit of a surprise given that it's a very out-there kind of movie, with an almost outrageous concept and even more outlandish execution.That being said, it's almost a miracle that this movie works at all, given that it is very true to its title, it's a lot of things at the same time. Incidentally, that's what takes a lot of people out of the movie.In a very summarized way, EEAAO tells the story of Evelyn, an immigrant middle-aged woman from China living in the US, where she manages a failing laundromat with her husband Waymond and daughter Joy. Her marriage to Waymond is failing, her daughter Joy feels like her mom does not truly understand her for who she is and resents her for it and the laundromat is at risk of closure due to an imminent IRS audit.At this critical moment in her life, Evelyn finds herself day-dreaming about what her life could have been like, and incidentally, people from other dimensions pop into her life and ask her help in stopping an interdimensional threat that is on the verge of destroying the entire multiverse and dooming it all to non-existence. In combating this threat, Evelyn understands the true value to be found in her simple life and re-contextualizes her outlook on the world and on her relationships.On paper, this seems wacky enough, but what's interesting is that the character work on Evelyn and the overall themes of the movie are pretty grounded and not wacky at all. If the multiverse aspects of the plot were removed you would have a typical premise for a drama about a struggling family of Chinese immigrants struggling to integrate socially and financially in the ruthless capitalist system of the United States. And that would be pretty Oscar-bait in itself with plenty of social commentary going on, which is fine. But EEAAO, having those dramatic components, uses the premise of looking at alternative versions of your life as a twist on that premise to heighten the themes in a pretty creative way.Mind you, the multiverse stuff is not just a gimmick used to make the plot seem or artsy, indie, or wacky for the sake of it. While I understand it may seem that way, what it actually does, besides breaking genre tropes, is expand the themes of the character story underneath and turn it into a more existential exploration of what we value in life, no matter how small or meaningless, of the need to reject nihilism, and of how a different perspective can change our whole outlook of ourselves and others. The movie just wouldn't allow for that if that part of the movie was excluded.That said, this is a big reach for a movie with a small budget and contained settings, so you really have to let your imagination run wild to embrace the concept as it develops and that might be a stretch for some. The editing is fast, cuts are even faster, the movie rarely slows down to fit it all in. It works amazingly well for me and is a testament to economic film making and sharp editing, but for others it came off as disorienting.It goes without saying that the acting is pretty damn good from everyone in this small cast, they completely buy into it and run with every crazy concept, which makes them land as they should. Additionally, there are scenes that are so incredibly hilarious in concept alone that it made wish I had such ideas.In the end, if this movie isn't for you, I understand. It is kind of absurd, very silly at several points, incredibly fast-paced and definitely unfamiliar to most audiences. But even if that is the case, before you judge it a 1/10, consider the scene with Waymond talking about how he fights, or with Evelyn reconnecting with Joy in the parking lot at the end of the movie. Because those, to an extent, embody the true point, the message of the movie, and solidify the fact that there is something being said here besides people with sausages for fingers, googly eyes and Ratatouille references (all of which are great jokes for me).Consider also, that even if you like movies that are more grounded in essence, plot and character, we have a lot of movies like Elvis (as an example only, I know Elvis is good), or Top Gun: Maverick (again, great movie, but it's a sequel, it's more Top Gun), or The Fabelmans (it's another Steven Spielberg movie, directed in the same way, with little innovation). There are not a lot of movies like EEAAO, it shares similarities with other multiverse stories in concept alone, but it uses that concept to explore entirely different things, in a different way, with a shoestring budget and somehow doesn't fall apart.That's impressive to me, it is to be commended, and it's how the art of making movies evolves and avoids stagnation. Just my opinion.
Although I understand that the movie tries to pass messages and all that stuff, and although it has some pretty cool graphics, it is total BS.Total BS.

reviews.review_title: The People giving 8+ stars, did you watch the same movie?
reviews.content: I cant say much about this movie, because it was so bad, and boring, i stopped watching after the first 40minutes. It is all over the place, not funny, nor touching. I have no idea what movie the people giving high scores are watching, but not the same i watched lol. I gave it a one star to average out the high score so people don't get fooled into paying $20 to watch this in the cinemas.

I honestly expected more from an A24 film. With all the hype, I expected this film to be a total mind f$%^ and to leave me excited, confused, and wanting to think more about it.I say it's good because it is, I think it's hyper relevant for today. The movie is all about the infinite possibilities in the one life we live and the crippling anxiety that comes with the choice to live one life out of infinite. This plot is interesting, the cinematography is fun, the humor is, well not my speed. I just think the plot could have been utilized in a more cerebral and thought provoking way.That's all, I hope you found this review helpful. I would recommend going out and seeing the film and I would be interested if you agree or disagree.

I get it now. Watching this movie was truly an experience. For the most part, it was hilariously ridiculous at times that I could not help but burst into laughter but there were some poignant moments too that made me feel a little sad and I even cried at the end. It took me a while to understand that this movie is about love and relationships - with oneself, with a romantic partner, with a family member. And through the Asian American lens it showed a different and thankfully non-stereotypical perspective. I don't know how to explain it but I feel like I came out as a changed person after watching this movie. The cast was amazing too and the awards they won are absolutely well-deserved.

reviews.review_title: Wish it would have been 30 mins shorter
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022)From the creators of LSD, DMT and other tripping narcotics comes a weirdness bonanza that crosses boundaries between comedy, action and sci fi. The enjoyment of this film will come down to how much you are willing to suspend control, strap in and plunge into the madness. For the first hour or so, I was thoroughly loving the ride as I admired the multiverse execution, laughed and even pondered some philosophical elements. Then came a level of saturation as I had my fill of weirdness but the ride was still continuing; only I wasn't enjoying it anymore.The film is about a middle-aged woman trying to make peace with her life choices and the miserable situation she ended up in. In another life, she could have been a singer, chef or even an actress and on the way to filing her taxes, she gets a chance to experience all those possibilities... at the same time. Michelle Yeoh makes this film work thanks to her diverse skillset ranging from martial arts to emotional sensitivity. Jamie Lee Curtis was another standout with the mannerisms and maniacal facial expressions.The chaotic nature of the film blends ridiculousness, Jackie Chan action and comedy which you might find enjoyable depending on your taste. The creativity is next level but as the film progresses, many of the elements begin to look weird for the sake of weirdness. The creators layered the story with philosophical and nihilistic elements but it's hard to pay attention to them when you have a chubby girl with a pig fighting people with dildos. It is also a parody of movies like Kill Bill, Ratatouille and others but instead of paying homage, it looks like one of the Scary Movies.Narrative-wise, they skillfully managed to present a complex topic in a digestible manner while integrating impressive action and humor. There was supposedly some emotion in it, but the lackluster pacing with 5 climaxes spawning endless new cycles diluted any semblance of heart, causing the actual ending to feel unsatisfactory. It is definitely a fun movie that people should see because of its unique premise and cool nature, I just don't understand why is everyone worshipping it.Movies.shmovies on Instagram for honest movie and TV Show reviews.

I love movies, just not this one. Everything Everywhere All at Once might be a good feature film in another universe, but it's not too good in this one!I don't understand how the film received so many good reviews. I could not wait for the damn thing to end.To each their own, but I feel like this thing was a horrible waste of my time.Spoiler Alert: The movie is bad and I have spoken.

This is THE movie of all time. I laughed, I cried, and I was absolutely thrilled. I never could've imagined a brand new movie becoming my all time favorite, but it really happened. Just watch it, this movie will certainly go down in history and I promise you will love it.

I bought a subscription to Showtime just to watch this since it's been hyped so much and I love JLC and Michelle Yeoh. I'm only an hour into the movie and I do not see what the hype was about. I'm going to finish it because my card was already charged the monthly fee but I don't have high hopes at all that it will suddenly be a great movie. I just had to pause the movie and come to the reviews cause I knew I couldn't be alone in thinking how absurd and just stupid this movie is.Also, why is there a required character limit now to post reviews? I'm only typing out all this to fulfill it. DUMB!
Why the high ratings? Poor acting and actors. Sorry Indiana Jones! Everything everywhere all the time was horrible about this movie. Waste of time. These ratings are absurd!

The sound in this movie made it hard to follow or understand what anybody was saying, the actors whispered or talked too fast, too much background noise. Visually the movie is like experiencing an epileptic siezure. Just a confusing mess.

While I do love stories involving the multiverse I found this one to be very fast paced, very weird and confusing.It's on the order of Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy with it's outrageous and nonsensical theme, only this one is somewhat more extreme.The action sequences, and there are a lot, were great and the acting was good with Michelle Yeoh and Ke Guy Quan in the lead parts along with a very unrecognizable Jamie Lee Curtis, but to categorize this as an Academy Award contender just shows me how the Oscars are out of touch with so much when it comes to these action and science fiction films.Don't listen to the critics and their high appraisal of the movie because they don't look at these like an everyday viewer and solely place their opinions on the artistic approach or the type of cast involved. I also have my doubts as to the high approval rating coming from the audiences.But, don't take my word for it. Watch it for yourself and make your own judgement. Just be prepared to say that you want your 2 hours and 19 minutes back.

reviews.review_title: Too much too long all at once
reviews.content: This movie shows many of the good and bad features of modern cinema. As you can see from the rating, the bad wins.It is visually stunning, but too much all the time. You can't digest what you see. For something to stand out, it needs contrast: fast/slow, light/darkness, moving/still, and so on. And there is no contrast here.It is action-packed, but again too much. The tension doesn't build up to explode, it is high all the time. But that is just not the way our brain works. You can't engage in a 2 hour long action scene, so you just disconnect every now and then.The script has interesting and original concepts about philosophy, mother-daughter relations and life as a whole, but those are just drops in an ocean that is too overcrowded, and thus they don't create the impact they should.It feels as if the whole movie were a plateau instead of a mountain (or a mountain range). It is high, but it is so flat it feels like a plain. So it becomes boring.All of the above combined is utterly irritating, and makes the movie hard to watch.On the other side, the cast is great, there are funny moments, and the whole concept of a middle aged wife as an action hero is brilliant. Maybe 45 minutes less would have helped?

The main actors and actresses were good. There was not much of a story to follow and no structure to anything. Everything was a mash of very brief absurdities / bizarre happenings (hence other reviewers referring to it as an acid trip). I kept hoping it might get better and saw it through to the end. It was really long and boring. Confusing if asking oneself - why is this still going on and what has happened to the story?Based on reading the positive reviews, it seems like viewers feel positive from finding hidden messages about emotions and human behaviour. Perhaps too, from happenings in the film triggering personal memories.Maybe you'll like it if you consider yourself full of emotion and have good memory.Not entertaining if you like what you're watching to have something of a structure or a story. It was a sore disappointment.The rating of 8.1 and top #200 makes me wonder if a lot of bots are involved. Always check the newest reviews for more reliable ones.

reviews.review_title: Last year I took psychedelics for the first time. They didn't deliver the insight this film did.
reviews.content: Amazing, cathartic, and intense. Seriously, I'm 63 years old, and there's not much that surprises, let alone dynamicly engages me in a way I have not experienced. Last year, over several months I experimented with several psychedelic substances. They did not deliver one tenth of what this movie did. I'll leave it at that. I do believe that those of average intelligence will hate this film, and the ones and threes bear this out. Either this film will wildly exceed your every expectation, or it won't.

This movie is not bad at all, the message of the movie is that, accept your circumstances and moments and do not regret, otherwise if you want to have everything, it means you want to have billions of possibilities in your life, all your choices, then You become empty and you will not enjoy any of them.She said " There is something lovely about any situation, even the worst " so you just have to accept your destiny and look at the half-full glass in any situation...
I can not speak English very well, I'm sorry for the dictation mistakes. Google translate! :)))

Sounds like a 'syfy' story, starts like a soapie and unfortunately ends like one. In-between is a maze of scenes which could be confused as being classed confusing. One of those films which only those who prescribe to cult-movies will understand and enjoy.Production is tops as well as the acting, the story is light and simple, but its the application of what's supposed to be happening which seems too exaggerated and weird.Disappointing if you're looking for syfy!

Jarringly unpleasant mess of a movie. I wanted to leave before Part 1 title came up. By the time Part 3 came up the man next to me whimpered. I can't believe how someone could even edit this mess. A shame to waste such a great cast.

reviews.review_title: Like modern monty python, without the great humour
reviews.content: So, first. It doesn't deserve a rating above 7 (I gave it 6). The story is not great and a bit immature, the characters are 2 dimensional with (ironically) no character development. It's not really a deep film even though the underlying theme is the importance of love and helping each other.Yes, there are special effects, and it type of fits in the genre of super hero action films, but the story makes jokes around taxes, and has strong mother/daughter relationships theme as well as making a comment about accepting lesbianism (despite tradition), and accepting yourself even if you are rubbish at everything. So it covers allot of ethical ground.Given that there are people with hot dogs for fingers, a world with talking rocks (with googley eyes) as well as a bagel that's looked at with religious fervour, you can see why such scenes are reminiscent of Monty Python. However, it's not really a comedy, just flipant light hearted crazyness.Was it fun? Yes, but story wasn't great and to be honest the film is easily missable. Probably Michelle Yeoh's worst film, through no fault of her own. Will you regret watching it? Maybe not if you are not expecting something truly emotional or serious. Of course effects were good.. and I guess that's the point and the level it's pitched at.So, don't watch if you want something mature, but feel free to watch it if you are a teenager looking for something fun/light-hearted. I'd say for kids under 14 there's a bit where daughter is beating someone bloody with huge rubber dildos and plenty of fighting (but not gruesome), so wouldn't recommend for lower than 14.

If this move had been 1.5 hours it would have been a fun and amusing watch, with good acting and witty connections between generational gaps, Asian parenting set against a clever underlying set of multiverse of you with different skills. 2.2hours turned the movie into one I was just happy ended as it had no new ideas and it dragged out the silly making them dull. Great performance by Michelle Yeoh.
It shouldn't work but it absolutely does. Incredibly creative. Amazing message, acting, emotion, & score. It truly has it all & each aspect is masterful. The hardest I've laughed in years.

This is multiverse of Madness is done right. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a sensational and monumental achievement in filmmaking. With a spiffing and enticing screenplay, and smashing ensemble cast, this one takes you on a joyride that trips you down but you still like in any way. Immaculate writing and a superlative fusion of multiple genres make this an out of a world experience. Drop everything, take a deep breathe and cherish this phenomenal film.When we deal with the multiverse, it is bound to be complicated, but with vivid and colorful cinematography this one explains it more beautifully. You get action, romance, family drama, science fiction, and fantasy all coming in one. The Ratatouille reference was pleasantly done. Superlative performances from Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, and Ke Huy Quan and that heart-touching climax is worth your time.

reviews.review_title: Most stupidest movie I've ever watched
reviews.content: Terrible, most terrible movie. Don't believe the high ratings. I've watched bad movies but this one is the far worse movie I've ever watched. I don't how could anyone rate this movie anything more than 1.

reviews.review_title: How does this have such high rating?
reviews.content: Way too long. And lots of unnecessary, inappropriate scenes that add nothing to the story. Waste of 2.5 hours. Only reason it's not one star is good actors and acting.

reviews.review_title: Just wonderful, everything about it is wonderful
reviews.content: This was fantastic. I laughed and laughed, I cried and cried, the premise was bizarre, the choreography was delightful, the message was uplifting, the excecution was wacky.Just watch it.

I don't understand how people found this movie confusing. Knowing this was a multiverse movie I was expecting it to be very heavy and cerebral, full of convoluted plot twists and turns. This movie wasn't that at all. There were no elaborate timelines or endless characters you needed to keep track of. The means of jumping through universes was straightforward and the motivations of the few main characters were easy to understand. I was actually pleasantly surprised. I was expecting a multiverse story but instead got a love story and I'm all for it.I thought the movie was clever, visually beautiful, utterly absurd and genuinely heartwarming. It won't appeal to everyone but some people are just no fun.

reviews.review_title: What a hot mess of weirdness
reviews.content: After all the acclaim and Oscar nominations, I sought out this film ready to be wowed. Wow, alright.This was just weird and, frankly, boring. Really boring. That people claim to have been mesmerized and profoundly impacted by this film is frightening.I don't care to work that hard when I'm the one who's supposed to be entertained. After nearly 1 hour, I still had no clue what was going on or why I would care in the least.I was so disappointed because, and I'm not joking, this film seemed more like a very amateur foray into, I don't know, Scifi? Action? Mind freaking? Creativity?Bolognie. This is nothing more than David Lynch weirdness or Cronenburg weirdness, just not as good.

reviews.review_title: When you get misled by user reviews
reviews.content: There are many more lower rated movies worth watching compared to this.I always hate movies that are pretentious. People tend to give them interpretations and meanings that are not really there. Aside from it being dragging on many occasions, I find the presentation a bit chaotic; like some abstract art where there is a bandwagon consensus of a deeper meaning and a more profound message that is non-existent.
I couldn't sit through the whole movie. I only made it through part 1. I guess it's just not my cup of tea. To me it was silly and disjointed. I felt like I was watching an acid trip!😂

Literally just made an IMDB account only for me to rate this boring film 1 star. Don't waste your 2 hours watching this awful movie. 30 minutes in and I'm already yawning. I thought the (minor) twist was going to save it but no it just kept going down and down until the end of the movie. These 1 star reviews you see are true, believe us.

reviews.review_title: An oddly poignant goofball masterpiece (2022 list excerpt)
reviews.content: There is too much to say about Everything Everywhere All At Once to neatly summarize it here -- and there's a good chance you've already heard everyone else mention it anyway. I've seen people call this their new favorite film of all time, and while I'm not prepared to go that far (almost out of protest, since the film has amassed a weirdly touchy fanbase), I can see why this has moved a great many people:The way that its relentlessly zany multiverse-hopping actually has thought behind it and stays largely consistent. The way it takes cues from the Wachowskis, Wong-Kar Wai, Douglas Adams, and even Pixar while still feeling original. The way it makes us teary-eyed at even the goofiest sights. The way that its initial craziness -- its full understanding of the fact that an infinite multiverse brings infinite possibilities of comedy and action (take notes, Marvel) -- eventually leads to oddly poignant musings on purpose, meaning, and the futility of worrying over what one's life could've been; in harping on the paths one could've taken, at the expense of what's already there; of endlessly pondering what power we have in the great cosmic comedy that might already have its ending planned when all you really should be focusing on is holding someone's hand (whether or not you inhabit a universe where everyone has sausage fingers).It's not that we're all "small and stupid" and that life is pointless in the grand scheme; it's that the point of life may as well be a simple one.And really, I think something similar can be said of the way that people connected with this film. For all the nifty things about it and all its "grand" ambitions, it's ultimately just a sweet movie about family.The mother-daughter dynamic at the center isn't new, but it's rare to see it mainly from the mother's perspective. She's played excellently by Michelle Yeoh, who is backed by a hilarious Jamie Lee Curtis, a cute-yet-menacing Stephanie Hsu, a similarly multifaceted Ke Huy Quan, and of course, the utterly legendary James Hong, still on fire at nearly 100.I'd say "go see it" but you probably already have.

Everything Everywhere All at Once: A voyage through the Multiverse as Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) tries to survive an IRS audit. She is contacted by her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan) from a different universe as he dybbuks this one. She must battle a supreme villain, Jobu Tupaki who is also her own daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu). The IRS agent Deirdre Beaubeirdra (Jamie Lee Curtis) is also Dybbuked by a murderous acolyte of Jobu. Great fun as alternate Evelyns possess her body and use their skills to fight back. There is even a universe where everybody has hotdogs instesd of fingers and this segment has a great pastiche of apemen discovering weapons from 2001: A Space Odyssey. There is also a film within a film, actually it's kind of this film, watch by it's star another Evelyn. The traverse of the Multiverse occasionally brings the Marvel TV series Legion to mind, both in production design and charcter traits. Essentially it's a story about the search for meaning, understanding and love. Great performances by Yeoh, Hsu, Curtis, Quan along with James Hong as her father. Written and Directed by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert. 8.5/10.

I was really excited to see this after watching the previews. I thought awesome, this should be a decent sci-fi film. Well, like so many times before, the science fiction is a fake wrapper designed to hook more viewers. There is little of substance here in that regard and you'll be angry afterwards. I went back and re-watched Jet Li's "The One" to rescue the situation.The remaining aspects of the film are a blend of cheese, stupidity, crass attempts at humor and of course woke preaching. Funny how none of the 'verses featured a normal nuclear family, since that wouldn't fit the accepted narrative.So ultimately a waste of time.

10 minutes into this movie I felt like I should cut my losses & turn it off, but given all the rave reviews, I felt like it had to get better. Well, I was wrong. At the point when Alpha Waymond was explaining things in the janitor's closet I had a glimmer of hope, but that soon proved false. I'm sorry I wasted the time to watch it till the end. This movie makes "The Giant Gila Monster" seem like Oscar material by comparison. I can only assume all the people giving it 10 stars were on an acid trip, because that's the only way I can see it making any sense. Do yourself a favor and go watch some 1950's B-Movie sci-fi films instead. They may be crappy, but at least they're not pretending not to be.

I was really looking forward to watching Everything Everywhere All at Once, but I was sorely disappointed by this overrated and silly B-grade sci-fi drama. The premise sounded intriguing: a Chinese-American woman who can access infinite realities and use her alternate selves to save the universe. But the execution was sloppy, confusing and boring. The movie tried too hard to be quirky and meta, but it ended up being a mess of clichés and nonsense. The characters were flat and unlikable, the plot was full of holes and contradictions, and the special effects were cheap and cheesy. The movie wasted the talents of Michelle Yeoh, who deserved a better script and direction. I don't understand why this movie got so much hype and praise from critics and audiences alike. It was a waste of time and money. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

reviews.review_title: Totally original movie with plenty of depth. Brave in themes and execution. But not all that exciting or emotionally affecting
reviews.content: This film has great depth and the themes within it were great. It looks at such things as interconnectedness, family, personal power, free will, and the epidemic of the modern age - nihilism. In a world which seems determined to deconstruct absolutely every cornerstone on which society and humanity has been built, even down to the most intimate parts of ourselves e.g. Gender, nihilism to many feels like an inescapable black hole the devil pushes them towards and that they constantly struggle to avoid being sucked into. The Bagel is a representation of that lurking black hole that Joy has almost given into. Though many films have brooding or dark characters burdened by nihilism, Everything Everywhere is brave enough to build a film around it as the central obstacle for overcoming, and to have an open discussion about it, and is brave enough even to put forward an antidote - love. We need more films brave enough to offer people stories and forums for making sense of the challenge of finding meaning in our perplexing and chaotic modern world. So I enjoyed the depth within the film very much.It is also totally original in its style of execution and blending of genres. I've not seen a film quite like it before. It is a mix of superhero, sci-fi, action, comedy, and pulls influences from many places, often in an obvious and conspicuous way which makes it feel rather meta. It is a clear homage to such films as The Matrix, Police Story, and the MCU. It was so original in style that while watching it I was unable to form much judgment or grasp any familiar holds with which to make sense of it. I just had to watch it as if with a child's mind, to take it all in to make sense of only later on. So this part of the experience was also enjoyable and, as a film fan, the inspiration admirable.However, at the end of the day when all is said and done, I didn't get into the story or the characters all that much. The acting didn't match the ambition of the film, the jokes largely fell flat. And it suffered from what most superhero movies do, which is having way too many gratuitous action sequences.So overall, it has depth and enjoyable ideas and is definitely one to watch and has earned its place in film history with its originality. But it doesn't have the characters or emotional affect for me to be excited about watching it again.

reviews.review_title: First time I disagree so much with the average rating!
reviews.content: Worst movie I've ever watched! Yet, the average rating on imdb stands at 8.0. This is so surprising. I usually am not hard to be satisfied by movies, and I had always agreed broadly with the imdb average rating (by a point or 2 at most). But it's the first time I disagree so much with the imdb average, and with reviews in general. I really felt like I lost 2 hours and a half of my Saturday because of this movie. The message shared at the end is a message I agree with, the plot sounds interesting, the actors are amazing actors, and it's great to have some changes in the typical cast of Hollywood movies... but the movie's jokes and comedy scenes felt like they were aimed at teenagers (particularly a few scenes that I would definitely had laughed about with some of my friends when I was in high school). I would recommend to stay away from this movie, despite the amazing reviews you will find and the nominations it has received.

First things first: it's a good movie. I enjoyed watching it. It had mostly good acting, it was funny, most fight scenes were hilarious.But at the same time it's too long, drawn out badly paced, repetitive and sometimes frustrating to watch. The ending could have been done in 10 minutes instead of like 30 minutes without losing anything storywise.The over the top praise this movie gets is a thing I don't really understand to be honest. Maybe it's a sign of the times, showing how bad cinema has become, when a good but also quite flawed movie like this gets so much attention.Nonetheless I'd recommend watching it, as it is refreshingly different to the crap that comes out of Hollywood. Also it's mostly free of clichés that make most modern movies so unwatchableIn summary: entertaining and funny but not even close to being the best movie ever, as some claim.

After all the hype and buzz, we finally sat down to stream "Everything, etc." tonight. My first reaction is, why all the hype and buzz? There's not much here that we haven't seen in one form or another before.* Failing relationships confronted and reevaluated? Check.* Multi-cultural confusion? Check.* Alternate universes? Check.* Altered reality? Check and double check.With the exception of the concept and script, this is a well crafted film. It's visually stunning, with exceptional acting by Michelle Yeoh. At least some of those Oscar nominations are well deserved. The martial arts sequences are technically well done, if overlong. But at its core, it's still a mishmash of pretentious clichés - Kill Bill meets Interstellar meets The Matrix.

The Dans have managed a marvelous achievement with this movie, in that neither me nor anyone with me lost interest for a moment throughout its entire duration. "Everything Everywhere" is frenetic, feverish, beautiful, strange, and ambitious - and it reminds me why I love to go to the movies.I've just seen something the likes of which are mostly wholly original. A dash of culture clash for comedy, a sprinkle of family disconnect for drama, and a whopping platter of multiverse (just barely hanging on to science fiction) are familiar from other works. Yet in this concoction, it's bliss to my dumb little brain that aches to be entertained with something new each time I visit a theater.I loved the whole cast, but I'd like to note Stephanie Hsu, who proved she had chops in The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel but enraptured me with her role as the complicated Joy. I enjoyed the honesty with which other characters were portrayed - their failures, flaws, and even kinks help illustrate (and illuminate) them. I was taken in by their chemistry and made to laugh at their weirdness. And anytime a legend like Jamie Lee Curtis holds nothing back, I know I'm watching a special production.The unfortunate thing is, I think many people will be put off by the colossal questions the Dans tackle. It's not like they were actually trying to solve the mysteries of the universe, but they do prod it and play with it in colorful fashion; and any time you dabble with existential confusion, it can draw away from concrete ideas that actually do have answers. I think the filmmakers achieve something beautiful with this film, because despite their exploration of "the meaning of life" (worded more accurately as "our feeling like small pieces of $#!t"), they manage to loop back to simple offerings. Such as, perhaps simple emotion, shared with a loved one, is worthy of our perseverance. Or better yet - perhaps nothing matters at all, so why not just enjoy our time here. There is brilliance in squashing high concepts into digestible thoughts, and it's done in satisfying fashion here. Credit to the performances who sell their emotions, because without them it wouldn't have worked.Then there's the pure joy of sitting through a hallucinogenic, action-packed, billion-colored stream of scenes, each one with its own hilarious Chekhov's guns and costumes and props of absurd variety. It's excitement you can cash in at the end and chew on for awhile.It's not a perfect movie, but who am I to point out its flaws? I thought the pacing was too delirious in the first act, but someone else might call it effective. Some jokes didn't land because of their goofiness, but a different audience could have laughed. I really have few complaints. It's rare to witness something so unique shine so bright. Sometimes I feel like I've seen every "kind" of movie, but then one like this (or Parasite, Her, Good Time, or the directors' previous standout Swiss Army Man) reminds me I'll never have seen it all.One thing I know for sure is that I'm buying a ticket to every movie these two men make for the rest of their careers. I can't believe this early season of movies includes a gem as lovely as this one.

I gave this a 1, it is probably more deserving of a 5 but I thought I'd try and offset some the ridiculous 10's that it has been given. I watch movies to be entertained not to give my a brain a workout trying to understand what is going on. Movies in my opinion shouldn't be hard work and that's what this movie was hard work from start to ever so long finish. 2 hours and 19 minutes of crazy.

It has been a long time since I've seen a movie this good in theaters. Films like this one are the reason I love going to the theater.This is the first Daniels film I've watched but I'm definitely going to visit all their work after this.

reviews.review_title: Worst movie I have ever watched...
reviews.content: How the **** are these reviews so good? I was tricked by all of you to go see this movie - I have never felt in so much pain waiting for this to end so that I could leave with my date. Such a headache - nothing in the movie made sense, it dragged on forever...I've always been a soft critic but this was easily the worst movie I've seen in a long time. Unless you're on acid or mushrooms and do not have a sane brain, I would NOT see this movie.

Somehow this movie reminds me of 12 years a slave. But where the agony of watching a free man getting caught and becoming a slave again serves the narrative, in this movie the agony is in 2,5 hours at bad attempts: to be funny, chaotic, absurd, original, smart, overwhelming, acting and storytelling. This is not everything: this is just bad.

The thought of paralell universes, the multiverse, has always been interesting and intriguing for our 'noble' human mind; unable to process 'unreachable situations' of such magnitude.We stand scared and fascinated of such a reality, the possibility that another of ourselves exists, needless to say many more, throughout the cosmos. Different paths, alternate life choices.Well, fascinating as this looks, the film does not manage to approach accordingly. It is chosen a more ridiculous, unfunny, frustrating and tiringly long view of the matter. After some time into the film, the desire of the viewer is not to continue and eagerly see what is going to happen, but instead stop watching early; as soon as possible. Continuation feels undesirable and require some kind of bravery and patience.It is true, have not doubt about that, nothing matters really...about this film and in this film, everywhere, everything and all at once!
The film's plot is definitely unique but it got boring halfway. The writing is not crisp. Film is technically brilliant but not it's not a masterpiece like everyone else is saying.

reviews.review_title: Second time I've walked out the movie theater early in my life
reviews.content: Walked out after 40 minutes, was anxiously waiting to tell my gf I painfully can't watch this anymore. The movie was stupid, I love the concept of the multiverse but it was done in a silly stupid way, not scientific. Like how are you going to be stupid enough to go into a different universe when you're in mid convo with the IRS. Why would you fight security in the IRS when they have all of your info... why would anyone think you're a hero for that. I was originally excited to see it because of the reviews, but in my entire patience I sat and watched as long as I could. I think im just a deeper thinker and have read and watched a lot of science based theory's. The execution of the concept was boring and stupid to be blunt. I do not recommend the movie and am baffled at how it has been getting high reviews.

The movie is about a woman (Michelle) handling her laundrette business, juggling between family affairs and unmanaged taxes, and rebellious teen daughter.Things took a weird turn when suddenly in the IRB office, her mind got pulled out into another dimension, seeing both universe simultaneously. Meeting her husband of another universe, telling her what to do.The movie progresses with her discovery of the existence of multiple universes existing at once, with multiple versions of herself and everyone else. And in the other one universe, some people have found out a way to connect.The funny part is how one activates the connection - from wearing shoes in reverse, eating snot, and inserting buttplug-like trophy up their own arse. Lol!Overall an entertaining movie, with action and funny bits appropriately inserted. And by far, the best acting performance by Michelle Yeoh.Great unique story, eventhough it resolves around the familiar topic of multiverse. Must watch!

The movie is about a woman (Michelle) handling her laundrette business, juggling between family affairs and unmanaged taxes, and rebellious teen daughter.Things took a weird turn when suddenly in the IRB office, her mind got pulled out into another dimension, seeing both universe simultaneously. Meeting her husband of another universe, telling her what to do.The movie progresses with her discovery of the existence of multiple universes existing at once, with multiple versions of herself and everyone else. And in the other one universe, some people have found out a way to connect.The funny part is how one activates the connection - from wearing shoes in reverse, eating snot, and inserting buttplug-like trophy up their own arse. Lol!Overall an entertaining movie, with action and funny bits appropriately inserted. And by far, the best acting performance by Michelle Yeoh.Great unique story, eventhough it resolves around the familiar topic of multiverse. Must watch!

reviews.review_title: That's something different that we normally get and it's positive.
reviews.content: I think we can all agree this isn't the easiest movie to watch. You have to be really focused all the time, otherwise you will lose important things in order to follow the story. It's a difficult story but certainly not a bad one, on the contrary, it's a visual fest sometimes. If you don't like slow paced movies you should give this one a try, as it is the complete opposite, very fast paced, jumping from one scene to another in no particular order. I thought the storyline was very imaginative, almost made me wonder what drugs they used whilst writing this story. The acting was also very good, especially from the lead actress Michelle Yeoh, but the rest of the cast was also faultless. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a perfect title for this spectacular movie. Some people might need a second viewing to fully understand the whole concept but since the quality of this movie is of another level that shouldn't be a problem.

reviews.review_title: Ambitious but doesn't work on many levels
reviews.content: I always go for these types of crazy, imaginative, unique, out-there, weird movies. I give major props for the ambition and for showing me so many things I've never seen before. And the fight scenes, although scarce, are pretty awesome. Unfortunately this movie really doesn't work for me.The first major issue is the comedy. I laughed a few times but most of the comedy fell completely flat for me. Comedy is subjective, so others might feel differently. My audience laughed more than me but not nearly as much as the movie wanted them to.Another major issue is the weird factor. It goes way too far. Most of it is amusing but at some point it starts feeling weird for weird's sake. This is especially true when it comes to the story. There's not enough concrete to grasp onto. It starts feeling like a bunch of nonsense.Lastly, the pacing and narrative don't feel smooth at all. It was difficult to tell where I was in the movie (for example, nearing the climax). Here's my theory on why:Some movies will have what I call an epiphany moment. A moment where everything comes together, usually accompanied by heightened musical score and flashes to different moments. It usually happens in the climax and evokes emotion. In this movie, the epiphany moments comprise what seems like 35% of the movie. Scattered throughout the movie, not just at the end. But nothing ever comes together. It just keeps getting stranger with more questions.In the end I had a pretty bad time with this movie. And I'm annoyed I drove 40 minutes to watch it in one of two theaters playing it in the Chicagoland area, which has 100+ theaters. (1 viewing, 4/4/2022)

Wash and repeat, meaning it's a reskinning of a familiar story we have all seen 1 million times before and so many other movies and television programs. The Choices made affecting the destinations to the next choice & the next which her never ending with all decisions made and a nearly infinite multitude of possible timelines for which there is only one. Not imagine all possible conclusions of those happening at once and you have the minor twist in this story. Laying to the selfish nature of people, there expected stupidity of children only wanting for themself, the experience of life's wisdom wanting to teach young persons before they can make they mistakes they don't even know exist and the drama of all of the typical life moments that we are smart enough to know and not waste a moment watching on film. You have seen this one before, it's a skip. There are better things for you out there.

The worst movie I've seen lately. An improvised story, with meaningless characters. Honestly I tried to watch it at least 3 times and try to put a lot of interest in it, but I couldn't stand a pointless and too boring story. 1 star is fine for this "movie"

reviews.review_title: crazy, crazy, crazy, did I say crazy?
reviews.content: This movie is insane. It has multiple universes, an IRS audit, oddball comedy, insane action sequences featuring buttplug statues and dildos to name a few, a main character who is a middle aged low-wage immigrant worker, her husband who is scared of her and wants to divorce her (at least in the main universe). And none of those are really the main storyline. The main storyline is a troubled mother and daughter struggling to connect due to a variety of factors. And it's later revealed that this issue stretched across multiple universes and realities to which it manifests itself in an absolutely bonkers way. The movie sometimes puzzles over what reality....is....man...you know. And how small we are, whatever we are.Overall I felt the pace and moment where the 2nd act meats the 3rd act was the weakest part. I felt like it the pacing near the last 45 minutes seemed too slow as well. I also think it might have been improved if one or two of the alternative universes had been cut to keep the story more digestible.But overall I had a fun time. I want to reassure people that I'm not someone who always loves crazy, artsy, sci-fi movies. I despised, the Matrix movies, Tenet and The Green Knight movies for instance. And all of those films have similarities to this one. However, this movie has moments which I found very funny. It doesn't treat the sci-fi concepts too seriously when they're clearly ridiculous. And it does take the family dynamic between the characters seriously. And that to me makes this movie worth watching and recommending. It's probably more fun to see while on drugs. I'm sure it has as a lot of interesting Easter eggs to spot on additional viewings as well. The acting and cinematography are great. The script is good given how many issues it could have had for how ambitious the scale is for this story. Overall, it's a film I would recommend. Just prepare yourself for insanity beforehand, and you'll only be rather surprised by what you see. Luckily it's also engaging and emotionally relatable rather than just odd for the sake of being odd.

There is so may "what-ifs" in life. So many questions. Evelyn Wang, the protagonist, is able to know the answer.
