2) I thought the film did well to establish set rules to how the multiverse hopping works, but then it throws this out of the window around half way through when Evelyn, with almost no training at all, is able to obtain whatever skills from the multiverse she likes just by doing random things. Waymond has to have a computer screen tell him specifically what action to do in order to get the skill he wants, but Evelyn can just do anything and it always works??3) By the end of the film I felt like it had thrown it's interesting conversations around nihilism and the meaning of life completely out the window in order to have a more smushy and heartfelt ending, even though that didn't really make any sense
4) As the film goes on it just becomes more and more tiresome trying to keep track of all the different multiverses that Evelyn and Joy are running into. There was just no need for the film to rush through all these different multiverses for no real reason other than to be weird.

reviews.review_title: The rating is misleading and it is a waste of time
reviews.content: The movie pretends to be interesting but it is really meaningless. It is a mixture of random ideas without depth or any novelty. It is not funny as well. When the very first matrix came out was amazed by the novelty of the idea and it made you think because there was some coherent basis. This movie has no such aspect. It is really an insult to intelligence.

I'm not even sure what to give this movie for star rating, it looks beautiful, the main actress is wonderful and it's pretty much technically stellar, but I think what's missing is the heart of all filmmaking- storytelling- After a while the constant fighting and craziness just wears on you, the first two 'parts' of the movie are just constant fighting and conflict, I must admit at some point I just gave up and zoned out, it started off ok and to be honest I think I would have rather watched a movie with the lead actress struggling to save her laundromat and Jamie lee Curtis the tax person, that actually would have been more interesting.Edit: 11 nomitations for Oscars, are you freakin kidding me.

reviews.review_title: Completely Bonkers but Also Vibrant and Heartwarming
reviews.content: When Everything Everywhere All at Once begins, it doesn't just show you it's hand. The start of the film is a very sober look at Evelyn Wang's (Michelle Yeoh) complicated and largely grim existence. It could have been an indie drama at first glance, but if you're walking into this movie blind, you're in for quite the surprise. When we make our way to the movie's true genre (science fiction), we hit those universe hopping devices with Evelyn and we're going for a ride. This is both one of my favourite parts of the movie and my biggest complaint. You never know what's going to come next in this movie for better or for worse. There are some moments that perfectly accentuate the plot and the characters and then there are others that are going to leave more sensitive members of the audience either clutching their pearls or stomping out of the room. Everything is truly unpredictable from moment to moment, you can still plot the overall arc towards Evelyn's redemption but good luck determining where you're going next. These choices maintain the tension and the stakes so well but it undercuts the accessibility of the movie to everyone. This is a tradeoff that some people would gladly take but I saw this with a friend and it just didn't work for them with how scattershot Everything is (ALL HAIL THE BAGEL!).One of my favourite choices that the creative team made with Everything was that they didn't paint Evelyn as the hero with the heart of gold who just needed an opportunity trope. Evelyn isn't despicable or even off-putting but she's all too human. She enjoys playing the martyr, she's ungrateful, she's not accepting of her daughter's choices and she's extremely critical of those around her. They have to walk a tightrope with her character being too unlikeable but I found the movie knew just when to pull back minus one or two slips. My favourite character was her husband Waymond from the original timeline. I just wanted to give him a hug and tell him he deserved better but his compassion and his inner strength hidden behind his meek exterior was inspiring (more on that later). The central players also gain perspective as the movie goes along in a way that didn't ring false or feel too sappy which is an accomplishment all by itself.I'd call the cast of Everything recognizable but not truly elite. If you've been watching movies for the past 30 years, you know who Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis are but the names in the credits may not catch everyone's eye. It's nice to see Michelle Yeoh in a true starring role, she gets a character she can really sink her teeth into and she's great. I didn't recognize Ke Huy Quan but he was also noteworthy as largely mild mannered Waymond. I liked Stephanie Hsu as Joy, she played her character well but I do wish we had gotten to see more of a range from her instead of her being just sombre and snarky 90% of the time. Jamie Lee Curtis deserves a lot of praise just for doing so much of the ridiculous material in this movie. On top of that, she was able to do it without winking at the audience. She played her character seriously and I was ultimately impressed with her dedication.Even with all the kooky scenes and awe inducing plot beats, Everything is definitely a movie with a message and to it's credit, it never loses sight of that. Everything doesn't say something that you haven't seen in another movie but I was surprised that I connected with it so completely. As I stated above, Evelyn's dissatisfaction with how her life turned out is understandable but her negativity is sucking the "joy" out of life for those around her. Waymond is the real hero and he breaks it down for her about fighting the hopelessness of the chaos in life with kindness and sincerity and how happiness can be a choice even when things seem bleak and depressing. The overall thesis of the movie is that even if there isn't a purpose to life and we're all doomed to live and die in a what amounts to a drop in the ocean of time, we get to choose what makes our life valuable and there is limitless beauty in that idea. This such a wonderful argument and I almost got emotional when Evelyn uses this realization to stop being so selfish and heal those who she's hurt. Even if the philosophical ground Everything covers has been tread upon before, it presents it in a humbling and heartfelt manner. Even though I had to be patient and wade through some annoyingly crazy stuff to get there, it was still worth it.I feel weird endorsing this movie in the end. Normally, I would be the one calling it too obtuse to translate or too artsy to reach it's audience. But as much as I can't give it a perfect grade, Everything, Everywhere disarmed my preconceived biases. There are good performances, some insightful character development and a message that affected me as the end credits started to roll. Everything won't be a movie I revisit over and over again but it was a unique experience that I'm going to remember both for it's most bizarre and it's most touching moments. Based on it's quality, I'd recommend this movie wholeheartedly but I have to add the disclaimer that you have to be prepared to take what Everything throws at you. It's not going to be your average couple of hours of streaming content, it'll be both better and more memorable.

reviews.review_title: Stop cheering the horrible, awful, poor kid, Totally Overrated!
reviews.content: Just because it's a low budget movie I should like it anyway?This movie is really overhyped and overrated. I hated every possible idea it presented aside from the fact that the movie just keeps contradicting them. " Nothing matters " so if that's true and we can do whatever we want why you do taxes? Why don't you do drugs? I hear they are a kick. Why be nice to anyone if it doesn't matter? Why not rob a bank and go live somewhere eating fruit and enjoy the beach? This idea is totally absurd and unrealistic.Also invites people to the idea that a family doesn't have to stay together if they're unhappy. Then why the warm family gathering why help each other? Why even create a family?My 2 stars are only for the effort in the visuals and editing and cinematography. But just because they made an effort I am gonna praise them, cuz you know drug dealers make an effort too but it's also based on bad roots.I couldn't watch this movie but on 3 attempts and I just hated it.

reviews.review_title: And everything and everywhere all again and repeat...
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All at Once is undeniably awesome in its payoffs, but it just really isn't good at building those up. In this movie, Michelle Yeoh travels around the multiverse, looking at her different lives. Scenes often get thoroughly climatic, like the one where Yeoh's character bursts through all the different lives she lives in the multiverse. The way it was shot, with all the color flying before our eyes, was so adrenaline-pumping that I wanted to leap out of my seat and cheer. But the movie is rapidly losing its magic when this kind of scene is played for about the hundredth time. We have to go to all the universes again. Imagine my exhaustion."Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a fair description of the movie's pacing. Scenes overwhelm us with flashes and blasts. Once in a while, Michelle Yeoh would showcase her performance when the script required her to give a heartfelt speech. Those are touching for the first time, not so much for the twentieth.A big selling point is the martial arts in the movie. Yeoh is obviously an expert, but the fights themselves don't get better than a Jackie Chan movie. I found them maybe too choreographed, and I didn't get the use of extreme slow-mo. The moves are predictable; when a bad guy raises a fist towards our protagonist, we already know that she will block it, and make a counter-attack. And so on.I do get why the story is so beloved: The protagonist doing taxes is a fairly clever idea, except a tax office is too bland of a place to have half your movie take place in. I struggle to take the whole multiverse aspect seriously. Everytime there is a smart idea, the spotlight of it gets stolen by a joke. Example: The backstory of the villain involves them experiencing every universe, every life all at once, but unimpressed by what they encountered. They decide to destroy everything with...a giant bagel. And this whole villain arc is solved by...that's right, another heartfelt speech. I acknowledge the creativity and craft behind Everything Everywhere All at Once, but I don't really buy its structure.

If endless, mindless violence is funny, no question this one's for you. Or at the other end of the spectrum, if you are the kind of worshipper at the high altar of culture who reflexively bows down to critic-Svengalis, then here is another pretentious film they are calling upon you to venerate. I walked out, regretting once again having been taken in. When will I ever learn?

reviews.review_title: Is it sci-fi? Is it comedy? Is it drama? Is it kung-fu? It is all and fails miserably
reviews.content: This is like an film amateur with a budget, tried to emulate Charlie Kaufman for asian community. It is a horrendous mess which tries to be funny and charming. It is neither. I will give cast credit for trying to make this steaming pile work. Michelle Yeoh really did a good job. I can't imagine filming such a weird, demanding movie. There are alot of fight scenes and crazy visuals. The actors probably had no idea what they were filming so kudos for trust in the directors. Unfortunately, the directors failed them in creating any kind of flow or story-line. Mix that with the arrogance that the film needs 2 parts as well as 140m to tell no real story and you get 2022's most over-hyped film of the year. Avoid.

Went in expecting a great film, and even with those high expectations, I was completely blown away. I laughed hysterically, tears welled in my eyes, even the action (though not always perfect) was excellent.Everyone should see this movie as soon as you can (safely of course).

reviews.review_title: It borrows a lot, but still remains insanely original piece of work
reviews.content: I'm just imagining Daniel Scheinert writing screenplay, going: ''BDSM Michelle Yeoh puts gag in my mouth, holds my tie up and spanks me!'', with evil smile on his face. LolOn a serious note, I'm so glad for Ke Huy Quan's return and his well-deserved Golden Globe win. This guy came back to Hollywood after almost 40 years and delivered THIS performance.The movie is fun, what can i say. Acting is just amazing. (Couple of side characters/extras could've done a better job, but that's another story.) It has crazy visuals, cool story and great message. That message is the literal heart of this movie. It is also written really meticulously, with attention to details and great metaphors.It obviously draws inspiration from a lot of stuff (The Matrix especially). It gives homages and winks left and right, it has some memorable lines of dialogue, and it really is, as Daniel Kwan said, them going all in with this, in case this might be their last movie. It shows. They went all in and they won.All that being said, it's maybe a bit too ridiculous and silly at times. The movie never lost me tho, and i was always engaged.

reviews.review_title: It's hard to make a movie about the multiverse
reviews.content: It's a complex film that spans a variety of themes, but does each one justice with a carefully written script, wonderful performances, and a healthy dose of bizarre humor to counteract its bleak story. It's a strange movie because it's brave with its creative decisions; as well as rare, but without getting lost along the way. An entertaining and moving story that is testimony to the ambitious and ingenious vision of its filmmakers and the immeasurable talent of its protagonist. It can occasionally feel excessive, but the directors pause for emotional beats that lend weight to the chaos. The noise is part of the experience, but sheer creativity is the reward.

When the trailer for this film was released, I didn't quite know what to think. As a strong supporter of A24 and as someone who appreciates Michelle Yeoh's acting skills, I was hoping this would be good, but also did not know whether its totally "out there" weirdness and tons of multiverse-related subplots would end up being a film more in love with itself than with its audience. While initially somewhat skeptical, I decided to see it after hearing ecstatic reviews and word-of-mouth from audiences. I'm certainly glad I did, as the film's unique audacity and strong performances make the film memorable, although it's not without its flaws.The film follows Evelyn, who helps run a laundromat being audited by the IRS. One day while working on her taxes, she is sucked into a multiverse with infinite possibilities of potential past lives she could have had. In the multiverse, she is confronted with family struggle spanning a variety of different "verses," and can "jump" between them. One should not go in, if at all possible, knowing significantly more about the plot than this. The film's two co-directors, together known as "Daniels," deliver a visually engaging feast given that the film has an economical budget. Blending high-octane martial arts fights with loopy, quirky visions and a heavy dose of stylization, you can tell the aesthetics of the film took so much talent to produce. It's so offbeat and strange that even if you don't love everything you see, you just have to admire some of the creativity--at least initially. The Daniels previously worked on directing music videos (including the one for "Turn Down for What,") and you can tell their attention to style continues to work wonders in their directing methods today. By blending action with "verse jumps" and stylistic motifs, the film's editing--when at its best--can be spectacular and may remind the viewer of other tightly edited, stylized films like "Baby Driver." The acting is generally strong, as Yeoh provides a clear emotional range with unique degree of expressiveness and thoughtfulness.Viewers will initially be impressed by the level of originality on display here--at least at first, because the film doesn't feel as precise and unique in the second half compared to the first half. While some of the action scenes (such as the first one) are extremely well choreographed, they start to get a bit repetitive and exhausting after a while. They all more or less have a similar style--and sometimes that style can be unique (especially if "verse jumps" are involved in clever ways,) but at other times it can start to wear out its welcome. The pacing of the film isn't particularly disciplined, but given the infinite nature of the "multiverse," that might have been partially intentional. Nevertheless, the gradual increasing in redundancy in a few scenes combined with the lengthy, not-always-consistent runtime definitely means that the film's length could have been trimmed, and that despite the high level of creativity, sometimes it's possible to have too much of a good thing. The film's dialogue and attempts at philosophical messaging are solid, but these elements are strangely not ambitious like its visuals and attempts at crafting a variety of narratives.While the film clearly works the strongest in its first half and may gradually feel a bit exhausting to some, it still is a thoroughly unique independent film that you certainly won't forget about after seeing. 7/10.

4 of us went to see this movie and all of us found it a big bore... SciFi mess of a movie ....it's entertainment value was it's nonsense.... Reading the 10 star reviews ... Seems they are all fake to make you watch this nonsense of a movie ... Similar references to matrix in these reviews... Which this movie was not.....save your money save your time.....
I didn't finish this. I don't understand all the adulation. What a mess. I'll grant that sticking with it might have changed my mind but the odds were small.

reviews.review_title: Nice to see Yeoh, to see Yeoh Nice.
reviews.content: I was a bit concerned that the hype for "Everything Everywhere all at once" might lead to inevitable disappointment when it came to seeing it, and perhaps for the first 10 minutes or so, I felt like that might be the case. Fortunately, though, once the real plot of the film began, I was blown away on a cavalcade of humour, wit, but mostly just ideas, that make the film a pretty unique experience.Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) is generally disappointed with how her life has turned out. None of the three relationships in her life, with her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan), her father (James Hong) or her daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu) is particularly happy and her laundrette is in trouble, and due for a tax audit. One the day of the audit, she's contacted by an alternate version of her husband who explains that he's been searching the multiverse for her, as she might be the only hope against a dark force.Already I feel like that's more plot than I'm happy giving to anyone who might be interested in seeing "Everything Everywhere All at Once". Once the plot starts in earnest it's really a film unlike any other - there are some elements like "The Matrix" and some a bit like "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" but to describe it as being like either film isn't really. It's a constantly inventive story, thrilling just to look at, let alone to follow along with. It's consistently funny, despite its moments of action and occasionally mild horror.It's grounded in a great performance though from Yeoh and terrific supporting ones from Ke Huy Quan and especially Stephanie Hsu. That grounded performance is paid off too, in a resolution that, without spoiling anything, is surprisingly profound and emotional.I can see why it won't gel with some people but with me it absolutely did and I was dazzled, amused and moved throughout.

Michelle Yeoh's protagonist character leads a very busy life and the beginning of the movie expresses how chaotic it is. She's got many different tasks and people calling on her for her time - customer waiting to pick up clothes, another customer waiting to get a refund because the machine at his quarters, husband discussing divorce papers, daughter asking about something, father coming to visit - and all the chaos makes the audience feel very unsettled. I was very uncomfortable not knowing if she was going to be able to deal with each task in a timely manner. This is then exacerbated when she learns that she must spend some of her time in a parallel universe simultaneously; she can't concentrate properly and "be in the moment." Eventually she is able to learn how to "'verse jump" by doing weird things (switching shoes to opposite feet, for example) but it's confusing. Then the movie makes the daughter the main antagonist and then everything turns preachy and sappy at the end. I think the filmmakers are trying to say something about the importance of understanding and forgiveness between people (and particularly between family members), but it felt contrived.It is good to see people of Asian descent portrayed positively and "in-depth" in an English language film, instead of as shallow cardboard-cut-out villains or other objects of derision.

It went totally over my head, didn't really get it. Honestly, I couldn't wait for it to end! My mistake I picked the wrong movie, I was expecting some Chinese family drama but got chaos and confusion instead!!

reviews.review_title: One of the most creative movies to come out in a while
reviews.content: In today's landscape of superheroes, reboots, generic action/adventure movies, this film stands a head above the rest for trying to do something different. It's incredibly absurd, wildly creative, hilarious, and emotional. Try seeing it in the movie theater at least once because I can assure you, it is an experience.

Part 1: Everything was pretty solid. Interesting premise, great action scenes and humour. Was enjoying it a lot.The parts onwards just spectacularly derailed. It became an incoherent loud mess of nothing. It felt long but didn't really serve an overall purpose. I understand the ending and the "message" but it felt messy in my opinion.The final act really had to deliver to be able to fully appreciate and enjoy this film. In which it failed.6.5/10 (rounded down)
Take a sledgehammer.Hit yourself hard on the head.Hit again.And again.And again.....That's how I felt when the 'multiverse' kicks in.20 minutes into it and I couldn't take it any more.So I quit.

Even though this movie is able to present very good acting through an outstanding production, it chose a very unfortunate way to deliver a message. A blend of all sorts of movie genres that did not end up smooth.Unnecessarily long and at times confusing, it keeps trying too hard to push the envelope and ends up losing the audience. It did lose me, at least, totally unamused and confused with all the hype.

This movie is for those hooked on Playstation games. It's for gamers. So it just was not for me. I got dizzy with all the special effects and bouncing back and forth. Thank goodness Jamie Lee Curtis was in it, albeit as a strange oddball character. Who would've thunk she'd be a Terminator-type decades after her old co-star Arnold pulled it off so easily. Jamie Lee's IRS office outfit would certainly make a great Halloween costume.This film was like Battlestar Galactica meets Buck Rogers in the 25th Century.on steroids. Wear a seat belt when watching the film. Be prepared for a futuristic rollercoaster ride.

reviews.review_title: The film's comedic relief was on the most immature level that it continuously conflicted with the more stable and rational parts of the film.
reviews.content: If there was ever a film that I wanted so badly to see, and wanted so badly to walk away from within thirty minutes of watching, but tried to stick it out to the end with the expectation that it had to get better, only to be disappointed, it was this film.Obviously, the main cast of the film was terrific and the directing of the film was incredible. Certainly, the acting was pretty good and the storyline was promising. These qualities gave this film the potential to be one of the greatest of all time, and yet it wasn't.The film's comedic relief was on the most immature level that it continuously conflicted with the more stable and rational parts of the film. This made such an intelligent concept seem at times down right stupid, and I don't' like stupid films.

reviews.review_title: Everything Everywhere All at Once - Bites Off More Than It Can Chew
reviews.content: This is a thought-provoking film; and an entertaining one as well. However, it certainly does bite off a bit more than it can chew. The subject of alternative universes has been done several times before; a few better, but most not as good as this film. The two Dannys do a fine job writing and producing this film. The film can even pass for a horror movie since it includes the IRS, a far more horrible monster than any ever conceived on film. Michelle Yeoh does a very nice job in her role as does Ke Huy Quan as her husband. I think at one time or another, we all would like to be in alternate universes. Just too much on the plate here.

reviews.review_title: Hotdog Fingers, So Creepy And Funny
reviews.content: A simply stunning creative masterpiece.This movie is so well written and acted, the lengthy-ish running time whizzes by in a flash of hotdog fingers and racoons.I spent much of the time watching the show wondering who I thought was the best supporting actor, the Dr Jones kid of Jaime Lee Curtis and at the end I still couldn't decide.Best of luck to the judges of the Oscars on this one. Incredible entertainment, funny, great action and enough dildos to fill a um, thing.An instant cinematic classic that will help drive people back to the movies.Don't miss this remarkable piece of movie history :)

reviews.review_title: Chinese Matrix Meets Legion (not in a good way)
reviews.content: Ow! My head!This movie is WAY too confusing. It's as if someone had an ok concept for a 30-min TV show (Love, Death, and Robots) and stretched it to over 2 hours. It was entirely too long which added to the confusion. There were numerous extraneous characters (grandfather, big nose, etc) that they tried to build up, but ultimately failed because there wasn't enough time. And the fight scenes were confusing because they were meant to be confusing to add to the story.The ONLY reason this is up for Best Picture at the Oscars is because it's Chinese. Chinese actors, Chinese writer, Chinese director, Chinese stereo types (laundry). The Chinese have bought Hollywood and now are buying awards.Take your money and get drunk. Your hangover will feel the same, but at least you had fun getting there.

I'm pretty easily entertained by most movies, but for this one the movie felt like it was dragging on interminably and I even caught myself nodding off more than once. If you're like me, you'll feel that your time was better invested elsewhere.
I was so excited to see this movie, the trailer was awesome! So disappointed that the story wasn't truly about the character shown. It's really about an angsty gay teenager. Who cares!?!

Stunningly bad. Anime-like overacting. Heavily edited jump cutting in fight scenes. Incredibly poor, chaotic story line. Tasteless, heavy-handed attempts at humor. Home-brew quality special effects and props.Everything Everywhere All at Once is essentially the rebirth of Kung Pow: Enter the Fist. Twenty years later, without humor, and lacking the self-deprecation of Kung Pow. At least Kung Pow knew what it aspired to be.

On paper this was right up my street, sci-fi, alternative reality, and challenging concepts. The cast is fabulous, wonderful to see Ke Huy Quan back on screen, and Stephanie Hsu was just fantastic in "Mrs Maisel", I really hope she gets more major roles.But .... It just went over my head. It's like an endless series of vaguely connected visuals. It's done very well, and is great to look at, but overall it's just a bit too bonkers for me. I can see why some people like it though, it's one of those films that you either get, or you don't. I didn't.Five stars, one for the three main character performances, and two for the Rocks. The Rocks were the best part. By far.

reviews.review_title: Came for the nihilism, left disappointed
reviews.content: Went in with high expectations, especially as someone who enjoys mindscrew media and nihilism, but this was a mess of a movie. The first 45 minutes telling the story of a struggling immigrant family had me engaged, despite the rather hamfisted misunderstood lesbian daughter drama, but as soon as they go to the IRS office, the entire movie goes off the rails and turns into a wacky kung-fu romp. I struggled to suspend my disbelief because the writing was so stereotypical that I just assumed they were going to pull back the veil to reveal they were parodying bad science fiction, but no, they spend two hours on this weak plot. Most frustratingly, Ke Huy Quan (Waymond) mumbles and rushes through most of his lines and switches frequently between Mandarin and English, making his frenzied explanations incoherent and hard to follow. This was an annoying and disappointing watch and I found myself constantly checking to see when it would be over.
I love SCIFI and escapism. Wanted to enjoy this move, but including every concept imaginable resulted in a shallow, noisy experience. Ended up watching it halfway through until loosing interest.

Hands down probably the best movie I've seen in 2022. And top 10 all time. Great and tremendous acting. And the story makes you think and overall purpose is fantastic. Very emotional but that's ok. Only cons is it's alittle long but definitely a must see... that's it.

reviews.review_title: In some universe, this was a good movie. Just not in this one.
reviews.content: In some universe someone bothered to hire a writer to transform their random thoughts into a script.And then an editor, who politely explained that you can't just throw your moodboard at viewers. Your acid trip isn't a finished movie.And then a marketing team, who transferred the viewers from that universe to leave reviews in ours. That is unethical marketing practices and should be called out.I didn't hate it as much as others, some parts were sort of cute, but so diluted in endless nonsense that in the end made it just a pretentious waste of time. There was nothing life-changing or thought-provoking, at least not beyond thoughts any functioning brain has dealt with by the age of 15.There was hardly anything funny either. It just tried too hard to be shocking and deep and absurd, but it all stayed on the surface, without being willing to put in any work to create some substance underneath.

One of the few movies succeeding in touching both raw and elevate minds. Like Matrix 1 did, for example.I was surprised by the number of directing instruments used and by the depth of the script. Surprised by the choices made during the narration.By the fluidity of sequences that were apparently separated. It was amazing how small but essential suggesting images were insterted in specific moments/ places to potentiate some ideas.In one word : wow.And final thought for the haters: i do not expect everyone understands some of the idea toched by this movie. However i am amazed by people not understanding, but rejecting.

I tried. Watched an hour even though I'd had enough after 40 minutes. I hung in there hoping I'd connect but it was so tedious I just couldn't keep going. It was hard to follow and hard to enjoy. It still had an hour to go when I bailed so maybe . . . But I just couldn't.I suppose I should be more specific. There is a constant barrage of changing universes which is annoying. The characters aren't likeable although Michele Yeoh's character is tolerable. I got to a point where I didn't want to watch anymore. I don't know how it all got resolved and unfortunately I don't care. Maybe I'll try again but I doubt it.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies ever
reviews.content: My wife and I had to stop watching this garbage after 45 minutes or so. The only reason we watched this long was the 8.1 rating it had with almost a quarter million ratings. We finally got to the point we couldn't tolerate the stupidity and nonsense any longer. Don't waste your time. There isn't one redeemable quality to this movie. Annoying actors, no decent dialogue, no redeemable plot. Nothing. The funny thing was I instantly recognized the one actor as Data from the Goonies and Indiana Jones movies. Jamie Lee Curtis sure got old too. I'm just writing this last stuff to meet the minimum character requirement.Terrible movie. Just terrible!

reviews.review_title: Tries to be Kung Fu Hustle
reviews.content: Clearly a lot of people liked this, but to me it came across as just an attempt to distract the audience with a barrage of senseless images. Kung Fu Hustle pulled this off in 2004, but I don't think it's possible to get away with that a second time. Also, Kung Fu Hustle culminated in a pretty decent martial arts sequence. I won't see this one again, if I can avoid it. It was cool, though, to see Short Round back on the screen!

I have never seen anything like this in my life. This movie left me with dozens of philosophical questions, a giant headache, 8 buckets of tears, and tremendous admiration.Also, great acting is not enough to describe the acting.

A mostly incoherent mess, bewildered re high rating (should have read/trusted the neg user reviews). Dealing with the increasingly tiresome multi universe fantasy. Not much more than a bunch of over CGI'd action/fight scenes for who knows what purpose. 3rd act tries to bring together some semblance of story (or rationale for movie) of mother and daughter coming closer together, but there's no been reason to care or about the characters.

reviews.review_title: Tiw Everything everything all the time
reviews.content: Today I watched Everything Everywhere All at Once and on a second watch it made me cry againLet's bring up something here, I really didn't like the Daniels last movie I watched Swiss Army man. It was overly "quirky" and it's humor did not make me laugh very much at all, often making me cringe. I didn't see death of D. L. but I heard that movie is better than Swiss army Man, though that apparently is also divisive( I will get to it it's on my watchlist). To say the least, I was not expecting much here...But after letting this digest, watching it a second time, I can say this is definitely a masterpiece of film making. The Daniels have made something that is truly special and is so insanely relatable. Like this speaks to me on such a deep level. But even with the deeper meanings of the film, the film making elements of this film are... just... so incredibly unique and impressive.This movie is phenomenal, I love it even more on a second watch. Great cinematography, fantastic fight choreography, flawless acting. It's clear that there is heavy inspiration from the matrix, but inspiration does not stop this film from being completely it's own unique experience. This story is intelligent and interesting, the characters all feel so fleshed out and even though ridiculous... realistic too? It's so well done.It's seriously hilarious and it never stops, it just gets more and more ridiculous and you would expect that to take away from the emotions in the film but it doesn't. The way these directors effortlessly blended tones is just a spectacle, you can go from crying, to laughing, to crying while laughing in a minutes time.The best part of this film has to be the acting and action. Michelle Yeoh gave legitimately a career defining performance. She's gave it her all and it shows so much. Stephanie Hsu did incredibly too, she was very funny, and I loved the way she could change her personality on a dime. Ke Huy Quan was incredibly nimble and his performance was also stunning. Everyone did great. Everyone was super good at their action too, the way these people fight, it's so intense and I love the way the camera follows Certain fighting shots. Also the fights are very funny too, it's great.There is not a single element of this film that is bad, but if there is anything that could be improved it could be some of the music choices, some don't feel as effective as others, but this doesn't mean that the music is bad. I really appreciated 95% of the choices here but as someone who's trying to be as critical as possible, this is my only real critique of this film.Truly, this is an excellent piece of cinema that everyone should see. You'll learn something about yourself.I originally gave this a high 9/10, I wasn't sure if I wanted to give this a 10, but on a second watch, knowing what it is, I am happy to bump this up. I love this movie, it's become one of my favorites for sure.Low 10/10.

reviews.review_title: How stupid are you?? No, really.
reviews.content:
This might be the worst waste of time masquerading as a movie that ever existed in the history of the modern world. So bad, so senseless, so ridiculous, no plot, no writing, just nonsense.ALSO... anyone that thought this "movie" was brilliant, great, amazing, etc...
SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED TO REVIEW A MOVIE... EVER.

reviews.review_title: All the bling without the substance
reviews.content: I see the appeal of this movie but it left a bagel-hole in my soul. The pacing was kept at a good pace, appropriately balancing exposition, action, and character-development for the most part; although the plot slowed down too much in a couple different story-lines. It's generally well-produced, well-acted, and well-written--with a few plot holes still left in--but the narrative is rather self-indulgent and promotes a vacuous philosophy. The writers/directors unsuccessfully deaden their nihilistic bent with non-ironic, melodramatic sentimentality that rings hollow to the ears after all the pontificating that came before. The ultimate ideology of the movie undermines any gravitas or truthfulness of its final moments and its attempted rescue out of meaninglessness.

reviews.review_title: The most overrated movie of all time
reviews.content: Of all the bad copies of Rick and Morty that appeared recently, this one is by far the worst. It feels like an overlong saturday morning cartoon on cocaine, aimed at five year olds with ADHD. I've never seen a movie that felt so long and boring, while also being hectic and overexcited at the same time.It remains a total mystery to me why this bunch of silly nonsense is praised by the whole wide world. I really would rather rewatch Titanic II than Everything Everywhere...oh, I should also mention that the title is a disaster in its own right.If you want some good sci-fi-comedy, watch Back to the Future or Mars Attacks. If you want some headaches, watch this one.

The continuous message of who we might be in various permutations of the universe made me think deeply about my relationship to my mom who died 5 years ago- and to my siblings alive today. I did NOT expect it- I am not a deep thinker or movie crier, but OMG this one required a box of tissues. Loved it.

I am still puzzled by the number of people that give this film such high ratings. I watched the movie with the expectation that it was a great film but a third of the way through I just wanted it to end or just fast forward it to see where it was going. But no, regretfully, i watched the the whole thing, hoping there would be some revelation. Yes, some of the acting is good, but at the end of this too long movie, I left with nothing, not caring for any of the poorly developed characters. There are so many great movies with the same premise, fast action scenes (the fights) and good acting but this one fails in everything and everywhere!

reviews.review_title: OVERWHELMING, TOO WEIRD, CHAOTIC & ALL OVER THE PLACE!
reviews.content: From a cinematographic/visual point of view, the film is something we have never seen before, combined with the concept of the multiverse, and it's true that the film was humorous at times. However it was very gross and utterly absurd and the constant frantic & chaotic fast-paced images/cinematography thrown at us combined with a mishmash of OTT Kung-Fu scenes and ridiculous, vulgar scenes (for a movie that lasted well over 2 hours) proved far too overwhelming, too absurd and weird to my taste!I didn't enjoy this movie (my friend felt the same and even left the room 1 hour before the end of the film as she absolutely hated it!). I felt I couldn't connect emotionally with any of the characters, there wasn't much in terms of character depth... and it was hard and particularly exhausting to keep watching this film which was far too long... All I wanted to do is for it to be over...! I felt this film was all over the place... It didn't make much sense, and you certainly realise this even more so when the film comes to the conclusion that "Nothing matters"... Needless to say, this movie left me empty and drained... - It just wasn't for me!

A total mess, not worth seeing. Bad crew, terrible story if you can say there's a story.A disturbed teenage girl having issues with her sexuality makes her mother have problems in multiple universes dealing with a doughter in love with other girl. That's how the plot should say.I feel like the way they present the movie is false advertisement it makes people believe that they are going to see an interesting multiverse movie and it has nothing to do with it, read more reviews and you will find the truth about this movie, I wonder who has voted with high ratings, is it a group of people that want to push up this move? Makes me question myself about movie ratings.

The movie's production value itself is quite incredible and I found myself frequently enjoying the action scenes and the character growth.I however, dislike the basis of which the plot forms. It centers around a nihilistic approach on life that nothing matters and our dent in the universe is basically zero. The life of the characters is seen as meaningless and that nothing matters. It also puts too much of an emphasis on choices when our reality is that our freedom isn't as much as we think.The movie itself was very difficult to follow. Lots of jumps and cuts. The mechanisms of action are hard to understand. Events happen in the plot simply without explanation as to why. The producers couldn't seem to determine if this movie was a drama, a comedy, or a sci-fi.

Overwhelming in scale yet intimate in scope, 'Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022)' lives up to its title and is easily the best movie about the multiverse since Peter B. Parker crash landed in Miles Morales' world in 'Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse (2018)'. Daniels' second outing swaps farting corpses for sausage fingers, focusing on a woman whose world is cracked into an infinite number of fragments when an agent from an alternate reality informs her that she's the only thing in existence capable of stopping an upcoming cataclysm. The flick is as silly as it is sincere, playing with absolute absurdity but anchoring it within grounded relationships and character flaws. It's utterly ridiculous but oddly resonant, throwing so many high concepts at you that you're forced to accept each of them as soon as they come your way. It's very much a 'go with it' type of affair, even if its mechanics are surprisingly airtight and could be explored even further than they actually are. Just when it threatens to crumble under the weight of its increasingly out-there elements, the feature shifts gears and becomes a much more philosophical experience. Its first half is concerned with the what, while its second is concerned with the why. Tackling the bracing question of what it means to exist, seemingly alone, not just in an unfathomably large universe comprised of billions of galaxies, but in an infinite expanse of universes each as incalculably vast as the last is no mean feat. A trillion possibilities spiral into a trillion more until unfulfilled potential practically becomes as irrelevant as it is inevitable. It isn't a nihilist affair, though. It has an undercurrent of hope and, despite its heavy material, it never drags you down by feeling dour or sour. It dares deal with the existential questions guaranteed to have kept you up at night at least once, and it emerges with a fairly strong grasp on what makes life worth living. On top of that, the movie is just a ton of fun. It's an absolute riot with a quick pace, plenty of laughs and a strong emotional core. It's bright, colourful and incredibly inventive. It's also super stylish, presenting itself as a myriad of genres and changing visually each time it does. The most amazing part of all is that its visual effects were completed by just nine people - including the two directors - who learnt how to do them by watching free online tutorials. If that doesn't give you faith in the film industry, I don't know what does. In the end, the flick just exudes passion. It's an experience that feels hand-crafted to its very core, the rare example of a fantasy epic not stained by the obvious influence of studio interference. It's the sort of thing that puts a big smile on your face for its majority, especially in its more straightforwardly enjoyable first half. There are some truly fantastic action sequences here that evoke the wonder of Jackie Chan's early work, so much so that I'd easily say they're some of the best of their kind in years. That's not to imply the second half isn't successful in its own right. It has a genuine philosophical depth to it and its emotional underpinnings are properly resonant. Even though the affair doesn't affect me as much as it perhaps strives to in that latter regard, it still hits fairly hard and does everything it can to keep itself as down-to-earth as it needs to be for its impossibly elusive concepts to have any real weight. The real stakes are much more important than the just end of the multiverse precisely because they're actually much smaller. It's a really smart way of grounding the feature without dampening its creativity whatsoever. Creative doesn't even begin to describe this, either. It's such a bracingly original, thoroughly interesting and invigoratingly entertaining experience that it's impossible not to recommend. It's weird, wild and wonderful. Of course, it isn't perfect... but what is?

Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh) is a stereotypical Chinese woman who owns a laundromat. Her husband's name is Waymond (Ke Huy Quan) and they have a lesbian daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu). Grandpa is Gong Gong (James Hong). The film centers on the hectic life of Evelyn who does too much. We have indication of things to come by watching the monitors in the background. When they go to the IRS we get more clues about Evelyn as she attempts to write off hobbies as business expenses, hobbies that are her actual jobs in the multiverse. Yes this is another multiverse story and only Evelyn can save the universes from the evil one who happens to be her daughter from another universe.The scenes move very fast for effect. I found it moving too fast and annoying for my old eyes. The movie is supposed to be a comedy and also have a family first message. It was cleverly done. I am just not into the multiverse films anymore.Guide: F-word. No sex or nudity.

reviews.review_title: It's Like The Hitchhikers Guide To The Galaxy Flick...
reviews.content: ...But without the catchy dolphin song.The level of idiocy increases the further you get into the film to the level where you wonder why they didn't just make an animated movie designed to keep little kids entertained while their parents get a short break from family life.Eye rolling ad nauseam.

First I love Michelle and hong, But whoever wrote this had good intentions it's funny to a degree but it's kind of terrible at the same time so it's a bittersweet movie but I will say is More dumb parts then anything.

Me and 3 friends went to see this movie excited because we kept hearing how good it was and for the casting. The theatre which was full of college aged kids including us was fairly packed. This was my first time being in a packed theatre where the joked barely landed. It was dead quiet and everyone was pretty bored and disappointed including me and my friends.This movie physically hurt to watch. I enjoyed my popcorn though. I'm only reviewing because I can't understand the high ratings after watching that movie. It was too much garbage and not enough actual content.

Came to this expecting to be blown away, but what a let down. Just a series of idiotic fight scenes, ridiculous characters and plot less. Note to self to ignore reviewers in the future. Beauty, and appreciation of film, is in the eye of the beholder and this was plain ugly.Make your own judgements of course but my recommendation would be to avoid this like the Plague. A bubonic nuclear powered bustard hybrid of a COVID/SARS mankind ending Plague, wrapped in anthrax. Life's too short to waste watching this, wondering why others love it and when it's going to get better/ become watchable. It doesn't.

reviews.review_title: Best movie I've seen in over a decade
reviews.content: A great film, the type of heartfelt magical film that had a brief period in the early 2000's, when he had movies like I Heart Huckabee's and Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless mind. Filled with imagination, humor in a film that takes on the popular theme of multiple universes but makes it better than any other film.

This is a special film for a special audience. I'm not that kind of special unfortunately. I found the acting lacking. The plot line is all over the map as one can imagine and suspect from the title. A terribly absurd movie that continuously tests the viewer's patience and instinct to walk out of the theatre and get on with something else.

reviews.review_title: One of the few film I've stopped watching half way through
reviews.content: I was really looking forward to watching this film but the constant switching between languages, even half way through a sentence, make it unwatchable for me.

reviews.review_title: I enjoyed this even though it did get too silly at times
reviews.content: The movie is very Asian. The overall story arc is exploring family relations in an inter-generational family. Between daughter and mother, husband and wife, (grand)father and daughter. Expectations, disappointments, maybe lack of expressing love and emotion, all play a part in this film. It's framed in a sci-fi/fantasy thriller, that overall, doesn't QUITE make sense. I guess the director, who previously did the oddball Swiss Army Man, wasn't content with doing a straight up drama.I am leaning to the belief that what happens is more of a construct of Michelle Yeoh's identity crisis as she reaches a crossroads in her life and her business. She escapes into the alternate reality to process her feelings and emotions for everything. That's the only thing that makes sense to me anyway.The action was decent, but it's not the focal point of this film. There are scenes with fights, some really well done. There are some groan worthy moments, sexual innuendos during the fights, and so on. But overall, they're somewhat straight forward fight scenes. I guess Dan Kwan took some inspiration from the over the top CGI comedy of Stephen Chow's action films like Kung Fu Hustle.I'm not sure if this film resonates with non-asians. They might not relate to the cold, judging motherly character of Michelle Yeoh, and not understand why she is distant with her daughter. But judging from all the positive reviews, it sounds like it has appealed to a wide audience.Everyone does a great job in their roles. I can't believe James Hong is still acting. He's several years ago away from being 100 years old. And great to see 'short round' Ke Huy Quan in a movie. His voice hasn't changed much since his child acting days lol. The actress who played the daughter was also really good. And of course Michelle Yeoh sells the character, and all the alternate universe versions.At 2 hours, the movie flies pretty good. There were some moments that were silly, and probably could have been shortened or left out, like the rocks and pinata moments. Otherwise, an entertaining film.

I think I am in the minority when it comes to my thoughts about this movie. As at the time of reviewing this (movie), it had an IMDB score of 8.1 (Jan 2023). I gave it 5 stars, and I was being generous at that.For me, the story was confusing, with only limited spots of action here and there. But overall, it's not an easy movie to follow, and was disappointed for the reason given why all the caos is happening. Its saving grace is the suberb cast. The movie is well acted (it's why I gave it 5 stars), but the story pace is all over the place. Very slow in the beginning, then fast, then slow, then even more slow. Some great action when it happened, but nothing new that we haven't seen before, and they (action) come far and few in-between. The interaction between the characters is not great neither. There is no chemistry with all of them. Although it was good to see "Data" and "Short-Round" (aka Ke Huy Quan), all grown up.I really wanted to like this movie, but in the end it just left me confused, and the journey to my confusing wasn't really as entertaining as I would have hoped.VERDICT: If you're a fan of Michelle Yeoh and like multi-verse type movies, then this could be your cup of tea.

reviews.review_title: Mhs Wang are you with us
reviews.content: This movie made me feel EVREYTHING everywhere all at once the how they showed the action,emotion,Sci fi and comedy was so smart for some reason I actually understood this movie. And boy do I believe that Evelyn was one of the best acting performances of this year along with Evan peters and robbert Patterson and before you attack me no I haven't seen Elvis. I think that this movie deserves a oscar and I just had such a blast watching this movie. It had great acting and a the film looked amazing not as good as avatar the way of water. The story is amazing it has so much depth and layers and can't believe I was late to the party.

reviews.review_title: The art of making a boring 2h19 movie out of thin air
reviews.content: So basically they managed to do a bad 2h19 movie out of a never-seen-before plot (people need to spend time with and take care of each others) and a never-seen-before cinematic trick (going back and forth from one universe to the other) that could have do a good 12 minutes short ... in 1970.Don't waste your time, there are far superior philosophical digests on the same, that you can read on half the time you would spent to watch this.Apart the cuts and speed are nauseating, music is balancing from good to ugly without warning, and nearly 90 % of this stuff is shot in dark places at night, which was probably a deliberate decision to mask deffects.

"So stupid!" is a line in the movie and it best describes it.When you copy so many themes from other movies (Una mujer bajo la lluvia, Matrix, Se, jie and others) you are supposed to make a parody.But this isn't funny.Nor is it an homage.It's just a complete waste of time.So stupid!"So stupid!" is a line in the movie and it best describes it.When you copy so many themes from other movies (Una mujer bajo la lluvia, Matrix, Se, jie and others) you are supposed to make a parody.But this isn't funny.Nor is it an homage.It's just a complete waste of time.So stupid!"So stupid!" is a line in the movie and it best describes it.When you copy so many themes from other movies (Una mujer bajo la lluvia, Matrix, Se, jie and others) you are supposed to make a parody.But this isn't funny.Nor is it an homage.It's just a complete waste of time.So stupid!"So stupid!" is a line in the movie and it best describes it.When you copy so many themes from other movies (Una mujer bajo la lluvia, Matrix, Se, jie and others) you are supposed to make a parody.But this isn't funny.Nor is it an homage.It's just a complete waste of time.So stupid!

reviews.review_title: Too Much! Everywhere All At Once!
reviews.content: I consider myself to have a pretty open mind when it comes to film but this was just too much! Is all the hype surrounding this movie Hollywood's attempt to be more inclusive?Too bad Crazy Rich Asians, which actually had a storyline, wasn't recognized with a few more Oscars nominations a few yrs back.Yes. Every decision we make alters our lives forevermore and puts us in an alternative universe but WOW! Sensory overload!I appreciate the overall message and theme of the film - Be loving and kind and be grateful for what you have. Accept life as it is. Not what it could have been.Everything, Everywhere All At Once in my opinion is a BOMB!

2+ hours of vapid filmmakers screaming at me, demanding that I acknowledge their brilliance. Through 139 minutes of screamed cliches and bumper-sticker psychology, they continue to pound home some meaningless insight(?) like a self-impressed 14 year-old. Loud and piercing, this movie is entirely populated by shallow, miserable characters, none of whom are likable nor draw us into their stories. The movie noticeably changes gears right about the time the viewer wishes it to simply end: realizing that whatever its intention was is not working, it quickly devolves from dumb to ridiculous to patently stupid. A total regret.

reviews.review_title: Good ideas, very bad executed them. I wasted much my time
reviews.content: I wanted to wait until the end to see if it gots better, but I felt that I wasted much of my time, the movie is not worth it. Many people find it very interesting, but I cannot cherish most of it, only simple part of it.

reviews.review_title: I am wondering if there are voting bots that gave this film 30% 10/10 votes.
reviews.content: This film had an interesting premise and some interesting ideas and some interesting images. Unfortunately, those who made the film did not now that "less is often more" and they tried to overwhelm the viewer, reiterating the same ideas, recycling the same (or similar) fighting scenes, hitting you over the head over sand over, until one wants to shout at the screen "enough! I got it already!". It gives the impression of a dish in a restaurant where they pile up the spices, the calories, the textures - just to impress you.If someone would have edited this film to about 70% of its actual length, it may have ended up a more than decent film.I would have American directors spend some time watching (quality) European or Japanese films and learn why "less is more" and that "louder", "shocking" and "overwhelming" are notconveyors of quality.

I watch movies to be entertained. I watch documentaries to learn. I watch comedies to be amused. I watch horror to be frightened. I watch sci-fi's to make me dream of the future. You get the idea.What I don't want to watch is movies, like this one, that I get nothing from. It's someone's idea of a comedy, not mine. It's a bunch of dumb situations, with people doing dumb things to get dumb results.For me, it was a gigantic waste of time. I only watched to the end to see if it had ANY redeeming qualities that would make people want to give it an Academy Award for Best Picture. I didn't see any.But, I guess in this world where people vote in politicians like Donald Trump and company, where crazy theories get people to March on our Congress, etc. The universe really is going crazy and in that crazy universe this just might be considered an excellent movie.God help us!

The women in this movie are terrific: Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, Jennie Slate. But the plot and script are weak. The metaverse aspect asks viewers to suspend more belief than I was able. Absurdest comedic lines fell short. Plot development dialogue rang false. Intimate characters mother tounge is Mandarin and husband and wife talking to other in English. So much came across as unnatural... in the end it was not for me so two enthusiastic thumbs down.

...way too long. Some great moments about crucial wisdom that hopefully every human comes to realize in their lifetime. If this movie helps people gain that understanding then that's great. I definitely appreciated those moments. So much so that I may have gotten a little teary eyed... Yet, the humor aspect of it didn't really click with me. So through most of it I debated walking out of the theater. But I'm glad I was there for the payoff in last 25 minutes or so of the movie.

The title describes itself perfectly because everything is really everywhere and happening all at once during 2 hour 15 mins.I kept asking myself 'What the hell is going on, what kind of absurdism is that ?' in the first hour of the movie. I even thought that, the directors were trying so hard to be philosophical and fathomless. I'm sure many people would quit watching it after a couple of minutes, which they SHOULD NOT !!! That's why I decided to shoot a review, as it may help others to appreciate the movie and not to quit watching. The movie asks for patience from its audience, but it pays the reward.It starts with a unique storytelling that I think, I've never seen in any movies before. It's absurd, surreal, and too complex to comprehend if it really tries to show something to the audience or just tries to be as it is. As I've stated above it's a must watch but hard to finish. The first half of it makes you smile a lot, and cringe a lot at, as some scenes are the goofiest ever, without spoilers, I could say the ways people use to jump from universe to universe linking another version of them will shock you.The second part of the movie (approx. After 1.30), the tone of it completely changes, when the story starts to unfold. All the philosophical tone, and absurdism turn to an emotional rollercoaster between generations. And here we have the most unique way of telling the story of most ordinary people (a Chinese immigrant couple on the verge of divorce who works a laundry in the USA dealing with daily issues of life). Without further ado, I have to say that I've never got so emotional for a long time, and I even cried, and tbh I cried a lot.I haven't watched such a unique movie since Parasite. I just loved the movie so much. I also loved the acting of all the cast, but especially Michelle Yeoh and Ke Hyu Quan. Michelle Yeoh deserves all the awards for which she has been nominated for her flawless performance. I think it's absolutely one of the best movies of 2022 (and all time) and best contender for Best Motion Picture Academy Award.

reviews.review_title: Not as absurdly delicious as Swiss Army Man, but a close second
reviews.content: "Everything, Everywhere, All At Once" (2022, USA), is the Daniels' first feature film since their uniquely absurd "Swiss Army Man" (2016). Essentially the film focusses on one day in the life the matriarch of a Chinese immigrant family in LA. The first act builds a detailed picture of the contributing factors to her life having become empty and nihilistic, e.g., her conflicts with her husband, father, and daughter but also external pressures such as an IRS audit and a serious mid-life crisis. The second act is introduced by her suffering a meltdown / panic attack which forces her out of inaction. Her introspection is cleverly demonstrated through a deus ex magina process where she is both forced to and assisted in accessing the multiverse and to do battle with the physical personifications of her real-life struggles. The third act culminates in an "acceptance" of her place in the universe. The film is written and directed in such a manner as to create a multiverse which is unique, chaotic, absurd, and funny. The fight sequences are highly over the top and almost continues throughout the two later acts (picture Yeoh in Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon). This however does not detract from the story and tends to underscore (similarly to the fight scenes in "Sucker Punch") the stubborn resolve of the matriarch and her "battle" to rediscover her persona. Direction is tight and focused and the cinematography top notch. Both Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis delivered sterling performances. 8.5/10.

There were a few pieces of nice meat in there...but, most of it was messy filler. The movie is reminiscent of The Family Guy episode where Stewie uses his machine and travels to different universes. I think they even hit some of the same places. The nice thing about Stewie's adventures is that was less than 30 minutes. Perhaps it is my age, but I am done with movies that go on and on. Does anything ever end up on the editing floor anymore? Lord, I'm trying to finish this review and I keep getting the message that it is not long enough. Really?

reviews.review_title: When Matrix meets Monty Python meets Crouching Tiger - and sausages!
reviews.content: This is a masterpiece. Definitely the most interesting, entertaining, and mind-bending piece of movie magic in recent years. You'll laugh, cringe, watch in awe and definitely feel something.You have seen a thousand movies? You think you have seen everything? Well, think again. Everything Everywhere All at Once of course takes ideas and inspiration from other movies and books, but it mixes such a refreshing blend of mind-boggling entertaiment for your heart and soul, that it's hard not to walk out of the theater with a smile on your face after the movie (if you belong to the 99% of people that will enjoy this one).Michelle Yeoh plays the part she has been practising for the last 40 years. This is her movie. Such a powerful performance and it contains everything, every emotion, every move, every combination of interesting Chinese-English mix of words. And often time everything at once, everywhere on the screen.And then Ke Huy Quan - where have you been for all these years? Short Round from Indiana Jones is back, with a sweet vengeance! Amazing action scenes, and such a warm presence on the screen on the quieter scenes, and definitely some humour sprinkled in.Stephanie Hsu and James Wong and Jamie Lee Curtis are equally as good, and rest of the ever reacurring cast also do well, everyone gets opportunities to shine.Then the action, cinematography, set desing, music, outfit design, writing, directing - all comes together in such a satisfying way that this has to be Oscar winner in many categories next year.There are so many clever camera tricks, such well edited and original action scenes, so many weird costumes and the whole multiverse thingie is so clearly presented without it being just exposition.And the humour - you either love it or not, but me and my friends and the whole audience did. I could go on and on about details, but see for yourself :)And finally, the heart. In the center of it all is family, and love, to yourself and the world around you. That is the message we need in this decade.

reviews.review_title: A timely masterpiece with a lesson for everyone
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All At Once is a spellbinding action packed heartfelt well written masterpiece. Everyone in this movie is absolutely terrific and while it is confusing and surprisingly hilarious at times,it is also possibly the best movie I've ever seen in my 26 years of life. I cannot say enough about the movie or the actors, everyone here deserves some award and what is most profound is how this movie appeals to quite literally everyone in some way. I am blown away by everything in this movie and will absolutely be buying it as soon as it's available.

It has interesting ideas but it's too long and I'm tired of the daughters that doesn't get along with their mothers. It's clearly written by men.This should've been a shorter movie.It was very corny too.

It is understandable that some people refer to an apparent immaturity in the construction of this film with regard to the dimensions of action or fiction. In fact, it is sometimes a little disconcerting the lack of impact of some script pages or scenes that, if placed in the hands of a better salesman, could become much more memorable for the viewer.Even so, this fact does not have the negative impact that one might expect for the film as a whole.Even so, this fact does not have the negative impact that one might expect for the film as a whole.This is not a film that seems to take itself too seriously compared to its action and fiction competitors, because perhaps its proposal is for a more interesting story, told in a deeper way than they manage to propose.If you are looking for a film with a big heart, with an invitation to reflection that each of us can embark on in our own way, with a generous dose of absurdity, some good mood and very good interpretations, this is a film that will be worth your while.

reviews.review_title: How clever can being silly be?
reviews.content: It's an American trend, goofy lighthearted comedies carrying on their shoulders deep thoughts and delve into real philosophical issues. I already mentioned this trend when I wrote about Free Guy, though in that case these were philosophical issues straight out of the text book, while Everything Everywhere All at Once has thrown all text books away or maybe even burned them - in the best way. It is, as already been said by other reviewers one of the most original scripts ever written, as irreverent as they come. They push pure sci fi ideas deep into the realm of the absurd not to say plain stupid, without ever being stupid. In my opinion the stupidity or silliness is here in order to neutralize what would be otherwise sappy cliche, or borderline preachiness if said straightforwardly. This is so cleverly done the writing is almost genius - a term I don't often use. But it's the second bright film I see in a single month dealing with how destructive motherly love can be and how it's the only cure of its destructiveness, and I speak obviously about Turning Red who also chose the humorous approach but didn't go as far as EEAaO dared to go.This called for an entire cast of superlative performances starting with Michelle Yeoh who's a brilliant actress that I never saw in a role I didn't like. Same is true for Ke Huy Quan whom I didn't see since the Goonies in anything, what a waste, such an amazing actor with so few roles to his credit. Also brilliant are Stephanie Hsu Jamie Lee Curtis sinking her teeth into another juicy role and James Hong as Gong Gong for whom I'll always have a warm place in my heart since his role in Big Trouble in Little China.Bottom line: the creative team of the Daniels, as they like to call themselves has very little fear and steps without hesitation where others wouldn't dare looking. But they do it with style and wisdom that remind me of the very best. I'll be looking forward to their next creation. If you want to see motherhood deconstructed, to its core; if you want to find out about the amazing power of being nice, without ever risking an overdose of sugarcoating - this your film.

I am a big Michelle Yeoh fan.....I knew and liked her before Crouching Tiger made her internationally known. I really like Jamie Lee Curtis. And the actor that played the husband is an excellent actor and was the most believable in switching emotions. Even the guy in the wheelchair is famously known and played the main villian in 'Big Trouble in Little China'. So the movie got it right with the casting but there is another huge problem....story and pacing. While the story seems original, it is a mishmash of 'The One'(multiple universes) & Sense 8(grabbing abilities from other selves) & Matrix(alternate reality).The problem is the movie is trying to be all three while trying to be a comedy and family drama with the already science fiction/fantasy/kung fu elements that exists. Does that statement sounds confusing? Then you understand how this movie will be. It is extremely chaotic, jarring and the combination of drama, comedy, scifi, fantasy brings down the movie. There is so much going on and so much explanation needed to understand that the director should have slowed it down a few times in the beginning so that the audience can understand the rules. Instead each scene is explaining something new as if they are making it up as they go. After a while, you are tired and don't care anymore as the director tries to amp up the action and special effects of a scene without explaining why the scene is even happening.To put this in perspective, imagine Color Purple, Fast and the Furious, Jackie Chan movie smashed together and directed by Michael Bay and that is what you have here.
A crazy story told with a surprising amount of heart. The performances are excellent across the board and it leaves you emotional. It's also laugh out loud funny at times. Truly a great achievement.

reviews.review_title: It Really Was Everything! Wonderful and Sincere.
reviews.content: This movie has everything- kung-fu, action, science fiction, other worlds, and even some things The Matrix doesn't have! That's a joke but there are some obvious similarities. Everything Everywhere All at Once is also really funny. The film was enjoyable and relatable as it dealt with a comic but deep existential search for life, not unlike I Heart Huckabees(2004). The movie also addresses generations and the culture of Chinese-Americans in similar ways to The Farewell(2019) and Saving Face(2004). I saw this movie as jam packed with beautiful ideas, themes, and different elements of film that really made it something special. Oh, and Michelle Yeoh was inspiring with an unbelievable performance. I left the theater feeling a sense of awe.

This movie absolutely consumed me from the first second. My entire being, soul and all, aches in awe of this film. This movie transcends genre and should be considered essential viewing for all audiences. A story of immense loss and heart-breaking love, the actors' performances completely draw you in and make you forget that you are outside of it. So incredibly silly at times, and yet personally relatable on so many fronts. The hype is absolutely real and should be heeded; you will not experience a film like this again for a very long time. Your heart will yearn for what you see, and yet you will see yourself in their shoes at many turns. Just absolutely bloody brilliant. Bravo!

reviews.review_title: Good movie. Nothing else. Besta Movie Oscar? Never!
reviews.content: I finally watched this movie. And I've watched it heavily influenced by the awards and the buzz around it. So when I started, my expectations were huge, although I had no idea what I was going to watch.The synopsis read: "a Chinese immigrant gets involved in a crazy adventure where she can only save the world by exploring other universes". Well, I was already expecting something that would draw on physics and embark on the science fiction genre.And that's it, and it's a lot more, but it's all a little confusing and kind of chaotic. It's too close to those American Jack Chan movies. Of course, there will be those who love it, but I've been a movie buff for over 50 years and I'm not carried away by the excitement of the masses. I have a critical sense.Therefore, I watched the 1st 1 hour and 40 minutes of film, but without ever marveling. The most I felt was a lot of curiosity.In the end I gave it a 7 because of Michele Yeoh's magnificent performance and the last 40 minutes, which are truly redeeming from a human and emotional point of view, but that would never justify favoritism for the Oscar for Best Picture, as I've seen. But Michele might win Best Actress.

reviews.review_title: The best film of the year so far and one of the best movies ever.
reviews.content: "Everything everywhere all at once" is directed by "Daniel Kwan" and "Daniel Scheinert".It stars Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan, Stephanie Hsu, Jamie Lee Curtis and James Hong.This "A24" film follows a Chinese Immigrant called Evelyn is forced into a mission to stop the multiverse from crumbling. In doing so she must try and fix her relationships with her family.I heard a lot about this film and I really wanted to see it. I can truly say not only is it the best film of 2022 but it's also one of the best movies I've ever seen.The positivesThis films message and story are incredibly well written. Every character has a well earned character arc. It's story is wacky but it works. The concept sounds ridiculous on paper but the script makes it work by explaining things clearly and making characters motivations clear and understandable. It also manages to take the audience and it's characters on an emotional journey that never gets dull. All the acting is excellent. The standout is of course "Michelle Yeoh" who deserves to win best actress at this moment in time. The action is amazing to look at. It's clever choreography and flashy editing make it more thrilling. The music fits the movies tone and atmosphere and also adds more thrill especially in the action scenes. The films cinematography is absolutely flawless. The lighting to the camerawork just make the film nice to look. There's plenty of long takes that just add that freshness to the film. Finally, the film is also incredibly funny. So many times me and the audience laughed out loud and I'm so happy that an original idea is making audiences come to the cinema more so that we can have a brilliant atmosphere.The negativesI can't find any big problems apart from tiny nitpicks and that's not affecting the rating.Conclusion"Everything everywhere all at once" is an incredible piece of cinema. It's story and characters are fantastic, the acting is brilliant, the action is thrilling and edited brilliantly, the music adds more thrill to the film and the comedic moments hit nearly every time. This is now one of my all time favourite movies for a reason and I encourage anyone who can see it to watch it.I'm going to give "Everything everywhere all at once" a:10/10.

reviews.review_title: Life can be a bitter cough syrup sometimes, but...
reviews.content:
..there's still honey in this world to make it better. :)If there's one movie I can recommend someone, a movie that is x1000 better than superhero-crap we watch, a movie so accurate, deep and meaningful that it will leave your eyes welling with tears after some bizarre funny and mundane scenes... your heart and soul will feel the jolt ⚡imprinting itself onto your inertia, so you remember it for good! 😊
Life can be a cough syrup sometimes or all the times:
This movie is about a family, struggling to cope up with life on every day basis, being immigrant, working hard at a coin laundromat, you know a typical Asian baggage you carry once you get married. There's just so much to take and bear in life--and, it goes for each and every one of us. We all have so much going, and sometimes it all just seems overwhelming. Pressure, depression, responsibilities, bills, taxes, job, children, and on top of that the love and care you once had slowly dried out... is this the life we signed up? Is this what multiverse have to offer? No. Life is what we make of it, and that's precisely the message of this movie. A hard-working, dedicated, devoted yet not perfect mother, and how she copes up with her father-in-law, husband, and a daughter who is affected negatively by all her struggle.
