She is a bright spot in the film, serving as the quintessential heartbreaker. Jamie Lee Curtis and James Hong bolster the movie's depth. They each compliment the cast's performances. Their acting matches the tone needed for key scenes and moments. Largely, the cast triumphs in chemistry andAesthetically, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a marvel. Akin to the actor's performances, the movie offers are plethora of stages and scenery. Each universe is visually distinct. Various aspect ratios are used throughout the film to distinguish universes. Filters were also used to differentiate each universe. The movie's cinematography appropriately fluctuates from being lush to harrowing. Action sequences in the film were well-crafted. The fight scenes were captivating. Unusual objects were used throughout the Kung-Fu segments, offering a sense of levity and brutality. The movie is a visual spectacle that manifests itself as a potrait of clashing art forms.The Daniels created a multiverse that triumphs in the exploration of themes such as family. They used the complex concept of the multiverse to provide a simple answer to life's mysteries. Plain constructs such as family are used as a bridge to the disjointed structure of the multiverse. As directors, they flourish in capturing many genres into one picture. The use of comedy balances drama. Scenes and sections of the film are written as if they were an escape from each other. One scene is counteracted by another scene, yet the drama and weight of the story is maintained. What may appear to be difficult to follow, culminates in a narrative that is multifaceted in essence. Furthermore, the film is authenticated through its' use of Chinese culture and languages. Simply put, the writing is tangible and awe-inspiring all the same.Overall, Everything Everywhere All at Once is one of the most innovative and original depictions of family and the conflicts that come with relationships. The film traverses the unknown by using the known as a navagation tool. It is an unforgettable, yet picturesque amalgamation.

reviews.review_title: The best movie in a really really really long time
reviews.content: 1995 was the last year a movie impacted me so deeply & profoundly in almost every way, as this one. A movie to scramble your brain while simultaneously rearranging your soul back to wholeness again. Everything Everywhere All at Once is this type of movie. Do not miss it. I recommend you like irreverent humor, family dynamics, The Matrix, and impeccable screenwriting. You are going to have a blast and anchor deeper into your self watching this movie. Congrats.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is an Action - Comedy movie in which we watch a middle-aged Chinese immigrant getting into an extraordinary adventure. She will soon find herself trying to save her own existence by exploring other universes.I was simply fascinated by this movie and I have to admit that it left me speechless. The plot was a big surprise for me since it contained plenty of action and it was combined very well with mystery and fantasy. The direction which was made by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert who are also the writers did an amazing job and they presented their main characters and the plot very well. Regarding the interpretations of both Michelle Yeoh's who played as Evelyn Wang and Ke Huy Quan's who played as Waymond Wang were outstanding and they made the difference. In conclusion, I have to say that "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a nice, interesting movie and I highly recommend everyone to watch it.

"I recently watched a film that can only be described as utter nonsense, and I have to say, it was quite the experience. From start to finish, this film was a wild ride of bizarre events and nonsensical plot twists that left me scratching my head in disbelief. The characters were equally absurd, with their actions and dialogue making little to no sense.Despite its lack of coherence, the film managed to keep me entertained throughout. The over-the-top humor and absurd visuals made for a truly unique viewing experience that I won't soon forget.If you're looking for a film that defies all logic and reason, and is just a fun, silly romp, then this nonsense film is definitely worth checking out. Just don't expect to make sense of it all, because this film is all about embracing the absurdity.Overall, I would rate this nonsense film a 2 out of 10 for its entertaining value and memorable viewing experience, but deduct points for its complete lack of structure and coherence." Well, these are the words of the infamous ChatGpt AI.

reviews.review_title: If A Hong Konger Version Of David Lynch Had An Existential Crisis While Making The Matrix
reviews.content: I must say: I was completely floored whilst watching the movie. Going on, I knew it was going to be an odd watch, but not to this level. It was an awesome, action-packed action movie that also had amazing acting and also had great humor and also had amazing production design, but it also had something to say, something quite profound about the state of life and how we should cherish it. Would watch this 10 more times if I could. 11/10 Guaranteed.

reviews.review_title: A Twilight Zone episode on steroids
reviews.content: This film is like a twilight zone episode on steroids. If it had been a twilight zone episode, it would've been great done in less than 30 minutes given commercials in a half hour show me made back in the 60s. Unfortunately, this movie runs for two hours and 19 minutes give or take considering the end credits. There really wasn't very much original in the plot, considering the twilight zone plots. We're filmed over a half a century ago. There were some good roles for the leads, but like the plot, they lose some of their punch when stretched over such a needlessly long film. It took me four days to complete watching the film because I kept falling asleep and had to stop and watch some thing else and then come back to try and digest another chunk. By the time I watched half of it I had invested enough time in it, that I felt the need to finish it and see if the film had any redeeming qualities. In the end, it's another empty-nester film. How do parents bring up their children to be independent from them and then actually grant them that independence, complete with a heartwarming, happy ending where everyone finds true understanding of themselves and others. Grant you there is the Chinese cultural overlay, but this story plays out in every culture in millions of families every year for hundreds of years and has been made into films and TV shows many times. Again, it could've just an is as easily been made in a 30 minute episode of the twilight zone.

reviews.review_title: Hours of my life I'll never get back
reviews.content:
Crazy production for a weak plot and hours of my
Life I'll never get back. Lacks substance, just another movie with money thrown into the production with special effects with no real story or anything of substance.

This is a fun rollercoaster romp across the multiple dimensions of familial relationships. A fantastic metaphor for dealing with inter-generational despair and disappointment. The gags made me burst out laughing at times and yet the core message was much deeper. That of forgiveness and the the strength of family bonds. Not subtle but fun.That said, I felt the movie was 10 or 15 minutes too long and could have been edited down to keep my attention.Yeoh is fantastic as ever. A great watch just to see her! Took me a while to recognise Jamie Lee Curtis. I reckon her best performance ever!!

reviews.review_title: A Result Of Tedious And Meticulous Teamwork
reviews.content: 10/10, almost no flaw.Once, I thought that my head will explode while I enduring this movie. I mean, I think this is the most awesome movie I saw in 2022 so far!Datuk Michelle Yeoh, simply put, Amazing. Outstanding performance.Perhaps, this is her best performance yet & could win her a couple of film awards this year.I mean, after two hours the credit scene rolls - I still can't stop thinking about the whole movie.This movie is not just about art, but to me it felt like a masterpiece that comes out from a dedicated and harworking team.The casts are perfect. The storyline and plots were more entertaining than I what bargained for. The memorable scripts, the outstanding CGI, the brilliant fighting scene, the awesome-awesome costumes and the small-small jokes scattered throughout the whole movie - it's a movie that I can watch over and over and over again & will not get bored.This movie stood up differently, unlike most recent ones.This movie is not overhyped. It is; Everything Everywhere All At Once.Hats off to Datuk Michelle Yeoh & the team for their hard works and effort.10/10 - hands down, and that's an understatement.

I'm telling everyone this is Multiverse of Madness!But seriously, what a simple story shinning through a bursting-through-the-seams concept. When you settle down from all the trippy visuals and shinny lights, the crux of the story carried by the two amazing central ladies is what a movie's really supposed to be.The concept of storytelling is there to complement the story and not the other way around. And frankly, this movie needs to be seen because no way of explaining it by memory to someone who hasn't seen it wouldn't do the film justice.Love it or hate it, just go and see it for yourself. I promise you don't want to miss this one and see it later on a phone inside your room. Let the visuals and the loud sounds wash over you inside a sparsely populated theatre because this one will stay with you for a long time.
Funny but absurd. Only watchable if maybe high. I just couldn't watch it to the end, I didn't care about the plot, the caracters or anything. It's like a Laurel and Hardy movie basically.

reviews.review_title: There is a tiny spoiler here, but you should read it.
reviews.content: Not much to say. A hodgepodge of absurdity. The premise is interesting and that's what drew us in, but the execution is terrible. The special effects are B rate at best. When they started whacking each other with 18-in floppy rubber dildos we got up and left.

It is not about the science. It is about emotions. The film is not all about martial arts. The family dynamic is strong in Michelle Yeoh. She is the main reason to watch this film.This film examines the multiverse from the perspective that a person pulls in memories from a multiverse counterpart as opposed to traveling to the multiverse themself. You get to watch the protagonist evolve (hero's arc/journey) as she learns/earns the abilities she needs to achieve her goal by the end of the film. By the final act you feel for 'Evelyn' as she has her showdown with the antagonist. It pulls at your heartstrings and came close to earning 9 stars.

reviews.review_title: It somehow lives up to it's title
reviews.content: What can I even say about this movie. It does everything, goes everywhere, and it still feels grounded in it's deeply human story, exploring the strained relationship between a mother, her husband, and her daughter. Every character in it feels developed, and both the lead performances and the supporting performances are nothing less than superb.Evelyn is an aging Chinese immigrant who has to deal with owning a dry cleaner that is being audited by the IRS, maintaining her relationship with her daughter and her husband, and taking care of her father. Her problems immediately escalate when another version of her husband from an alternate universe takes control of her husbands body and explains to her that she is the chosen version of herself to stop a great multiversal evil. She is then sent down a path where she sees the lives of alternate versions of her life and the roads not taken, and begins to understand the meaning of her own life and her choices.This movie is absolutely beautiful. Extremely funny, fast paced, action packed, and emotionally bittersweet. This is a movie I could watch anytime, anywhere, over and over again.Just awesome. 99/100.

What can I say about this movie. It is funny, action packed, dramatic, emotional, ridiculous, and just plain fun. Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan absolutely dominate in the leading roles of this movie. Jamie Lee Curtis is great as well. I cannot say enough for this movie. I went into it thinking it would be another fine movie because of the reviews but came out of it just blown away by the story, the acting, and the directing. I can't think of one thing wrong with this movie. It is so emotional and funny while being so engaging. This one will be an instant classic that I hope will be watched for generations. I've watched it 5 times and it has jumped into my top 3 movies I've ever seen. If you haven't seen it, please take some time to watch it. You won't be disappointed.

My 19-yr-old son insisted that I watch this. I had already started to, got about half an hour in and couldn't connect. It seemed a bit all over the place. But on his recommendation I gave it another go. And I'm so glad I did. I can't really explain the plot, I just know that it's one of the best films I've seen. I laughed (especially at Jamie Lee Curtis' character. I didn't recognise her at first. Brilliant.), I cried, I felt like I'd been through a spiritual experience. It's great. Just watch it. Even if you're not that bowled over, I can be pretty certain that it will resonate even if only in parts, and will stay in your mind.

reviews.review_title: The Multiverse Of Madness Is Moved By Love
reviews.content: I'm so overwhelmed by the dynamic of this movie. My logic and intellect is stretched to its limit and then released. There's like a mini big bang in my head. This movie is crazy, wild and out of this world. Pun intended. But somehow through all of those craziness and dizziness, I've managed a scrap of truth. That the multiverse is moved by love. If you haven't watched this movie, then get ready to have your mind blown into tiny little pieces and then get it assembled back whole again. It's a once in a lifetime experience.

I got excited after seeing the high rating. However this is another good concept wasted in the name of propaganda. When you combine time travel, alternate universe travel with emotions and good character arcs you can make great movies. Although I cannot even imagine what character arc would mean when time is not linear. It requires a great writer to write that script. These guys weren't.First of all there were some really good ideas in the movie. Like crossing paths with the same guy and talking about alternate futures in the alternate universe. However the biggest 2 problems for me where the lack of any logic. You can create alternate universes but usually when you go beyond the lifetime of a person in any time travel movie, that person probably ceases to exist. So alternate branches of reality like sausage fingers and rocks should have been excluded. Also how did they achieve the same level of civilization without the ability to grab things. I though opposing thumb was one of the 3 key advantages over other apes.Second issue is that the daughter lives all alternates realities, experiences everything, realizes that there is no difference in being a rock or human. She realizes "nothing matters". Except the "bagel" of course. She cannot give up the bagel and she will destroy the universe just to prove that she likes bagel. That part is the propaganda needed for an Oscar. And the part that made this movie absurd. At times it looked like "scary movie" or "epic movie" series. Bunch of absurd scenes stitched together.

reviews.review_title: Something for Everyone All at Once
reviews.content: Very well made. The things I loved. Female leads. Original, and made full use of the cinematic medium -- hard to have had the same impact in a book or on stage. Most importantly, the core messages. It doesnt matter what versions of life have passed us. It doesnt matter whether some may have left us wealthier or more successful. What matters is what we want in any given moment. What matters is what makes us happy in any given moment. What matters is family. And an extension of this is that familial relationships can be conplex and the key is acceptance. Acceptance of oneself and the other. With these basic ingredients, nothing else matters.Whats also wonderful about the movie is that its not about what you think at the outset -- the story unfolds and unravels and emerges in a wonderfully engaging way. Highly recommend.

Feels like watching a thousand different movies at the same time. A hilarious, emotional, shocking, touching, unpredictable, deeply woven science-fiction/action/comedy/romance/drama all wrapped around one struggling family just trying to do their taxes & run a laundromat. Superb acting from everyone involved, completely bonkers writing/editing, and an excellent score.One of the most unique movie experiences I've had, and can't wait to see it again.

A lousy movie. The underlying themes are the best there are but are used in a way that is nothing short of shameful. Two and a half hours of pure dementia, arrogance and useless effects without any substance. I wonder how this film can be considered as the best of the first half of 2022. A waste of time, health, expectations and enthusiasm. Garbage.

What a movie. If all the pictures releasing in the theaters would be half as original as this one, the current state of cinema would be way more hopeful. It's insane to think that this movie can throw in a beautiful message about losing hope in life and making everyone miserable and then learning to pick ourselves up and try to do good for our fellow people, while also having over the top absurdity. Few movies has gotten me so emotionally invested. The acting, the effects, the cinematography, the story, the insane ideas... what's not to love. This is probably my favorite movie ever right now. I thought The Batman was movie of the year, but after watching this one, without a doubt the movie of the year, decade, hell maybe even century. If this doesn't win movie of the year, i will... probably do nothing because i can do nothing. But you get it, go watch this movie right now.

reviews.review_title: Once in a while a cult status movie is made. This is one them.
reviews.content: Im still digesting what I watch from the information overload. This movie will be a I hate it or I love it. For me the latter. It is going to be no doubt one of those movies which will get the cult status. Best way to describe the movie is what would happen if you broomed all the edited clips from Sliders and Matrix and few other similar, and put them into a blender with some acid. The reason I enjoyed this movie because it was different and so refreshing change. I like art house movies and I say supporting well-known stars, advisors and was financed because they recognised the potential of something very unique here. Superhero style movie for adults with strong adult themes.

See the vivid portrait that Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert paint with the opening of Everything Everywhere All At Once, of how language barriers can be used to intentionally and unintentionally wound others, of how first generation migrants strafe that liminal space between work and home, of how code-switching becomes a means of survival. Some might argue (and have) that narratives of intergenerational trauma and conflict have become trite, that the overbearing matriarch of Asian origin clashing against the modern, youthful world is overplayed. But these stories are still happening, and as time passes our artists will turn their attention from the journeys of second-generation migrants to their children, and theirs after that. Let's not be too critical of a slice of representation that's still in its infancy. We can have those other stories too; it's good to normalise them. Not everything has to be situated at the point of multicultural crisis, but in the same vein, we don't have to tear down one pillar to raise another.There are other minute details of this milieu which may seem insignificant but will resonate with those in the audience who recognise them. The tangled cacophony of overlapping Cantonese, Mandarin, and English that Evelyn wields to navigate another day in the life. How she crudely masks a semblance of care with insults in order to bridge the generational gap that keeps her daughter Joy at an arm's (and then some) length. And then there are other, more universal struggles that are glimpsed, like how she zooms from one situation to another with barely a glance or nod of recognition towards her husband or daughter (so distracted even divorce papers merit a mere half-glance), a toxic blend of unrealistically high expectations and disappointment that hints at the catalyst for the rest of the film's complications, in both her own world and in the Alpha Prime. And that's just the first ten minutes.In Michelle Yeoh, the Daniels saw the perfect actor to centre the narrative. While early drafts had none other than Jackie Chan as the protagonist, he's been the bumbling goofball before. Yeoh's always had the perfect poise, an international action star and beauty icon for decades. Placing a former Bond girl in a run-down laundromat was an inspired choice, drawing on all the wasted potential that bursts at the edges of the multiverse. One of Evelyn's alternate timelines has her living the Yeoh-esque celebrity archetype, a renowned film star who spurred her husband for a world of glitz and glamour. "He (Waymond) needs to know how good my life could have been," she blurts out in almost desperation, coming to the realisation of all she has missed out on. To see Yeoh finally given the opportunity to demonstrate such range is fulfilling in itself; to see her melt into the role and give depth to the character, have her live out every possible life and outlandish existence she could ever imagine or aspire to and still choose to return to that laundromat, makes it all the more meaningful.In a more subtle meta-twist, Ke Huy Quan's turn as the unassuming husband, a side character in Evelyn's life, resembles his own career, a Spielbergian blockbuster high and then years of Hollywood neglect. Witnessing Waymond snap into action and take centre stage doubles as Quan's own return to the big screen, occupying that Jackie Chan slot himself in an spirited rendition of the daggy dad. Watch how costuming and props combine to accentuate this in his early action sequences, wielding a bumbag as if it were a deadly weapon (it's meant to resemble the Bruce Lee nunchuck). What better object to represent the Waymond worldview? He fights with kindness (and disarms with cookies), cares little of what others think of his appearance and naivety, and manages to find the glee in the everyday, whether it be dimension hopping or laundromat meniality. Evelyn's symbolic acceptance of the Waymond way in opening up her third eye, googly-style, is a bizarre promotional shot, but placed within context perfectly encapsulates the film's blend of silly sentimentality. Eat your heart out, Doctor Strange. It was the Daniels' masterstroke to lure us in with the grit of Alpha Waymond (quite literally an alpha male), only to swerve sharply and promote a different brand of masculinity. Quan switches almost effortlessly between the two, and sometimes crouches on their very edge; the chapstick moment is but one example. He gives life to the narrative, grounding it firmly into something to return to.Everything Everywhere All At Once's style is punchy and direct, a no-holds-barred approach to its brand of absurdist humour. What other film would unironically list 'proud father' as a skill for one of its characters? The same weight and earnesty is afforded to each line of dialogue in its Matrix-esque set-up, from "She's off the grid!" to "She's gone home to finish the taxes!" The action is given its snappiness through edits that enlarge each blow for impact: widening and shrinking the aspect ratio to signal shifts in timelines, dolly zooms to push in and exaggerate, visual puns and match cuts to link the worlds together (see Evelyn being 'pulled away' from his argument with Waymond, or the pizza spinner superimposed over her riot shield heroics). One of its biggest laughs sees the film literally pause in a record-scratch moment as Jobu Tupaki expresses her disbelief that queerness, not mass murder, is Evelyn's most pressing initial concern amidst all the chaos. But more than simply layering callback upon callback (the pinky becomes the cookie becomes the symbolic kindness of Waymond), the jokes are natural extensions of the script's philosophy, of the messy, zany possibilities of the multiverse once we (and Evelyn) realise the ramifications of reaching rock bottom and the potential that lies within. Every one of us know that yearning for lives unlived, opportunities missed, choices not taken; it is, pun intended, a universal concern. The Daniels merge that into their filmmaking, pushing the narrative alongside these sequences. I appreciated hearing the kung fu Evelyn's steps timed to Clair de Lune, and then later could barely hold it together when it returned in the climatic montage via sausage fingers to bring Evelyn's epiphany full circle.The story flirts with the avant-garde in its sub-climax which strips away all of the multiverse gimmickry to place mother and daughter atop a metaphorical cliff, conversing as rocks. Joy, whose arc has been smattered with imagery of depression and suicide ideation, elects to jump off and into the everything bagel, and Evelyn finally allows her the agency to do so. But the crux of the issue highlights choice as a key motif; even as Joy sits on the precipice of self-destruction, she still yearns for her mother's acceptance. In turn, Evelyn must come to terms with who her daughter is alongside all of the other apparent 'disappointments' of this universe, to find fulfilment in the laundromat and doing taxes. It was never really about Gong Gong but her own misgivings of a wayward path, which subverts what would be a conventionally uplifting moment because she's wielding her daughter's personal life for her own self-actualisation. Some have derided the script for its bite-sized exploration of nihilism and its end goals. Admittedly, the depth of the storytelling here isn't cavernous; for its 142-minute length, I would have liked it to have fleshed out Joy's angst further to give her decision to stay more weight at the expense of perhaps one of the timelines. Nevertheless, Evelyn's choice to stick by her family, and subsequently the Daniels' choice to situate the climax in a parking lot, resonates. The film's value in an ever-evolving cultural landscape might lie predominantly in how hard it is to define. We find worth in its uniqueness. Is it a kung fu action romp, or a domestic drama about the struggles of marital life? Is it an absurdist comedy about the meaning of life, or simply an allegory for a mother pushing her child too far? Yes, it's all of these, and more. All at once.
The story keep playing the meaningless scene. No ppl in the theatre got any message but suffered from a 2.5 hours hell.Michelle was trying hard to play but not for any of other roles.

First of all, not a bad movie as many are review as a low 3/10.The movie has some flaws, but overall they are not enough to receive crap reviews. But also, movie is not great.It starts really good, and get pumped really hard and that's good thing, but then it all start happening really out of sense, the rules of the multiverse start to be broken (for the purpose of the film, which is a bad thing in my opinion) and physics... breaking physics really took me out of the fights (stupid fights)((but good fighting moves).The concept was great, the story was good, movie to watch once in a few years. Lead and supporting actor were good. VFX good.Not bad, non great.

Michelle Yeoh does an admirable job of displaying dozens of different emotions in the multiple personas of the same character in this movie. Unfortunately, most are shown in disjointed snippets as the film speeds through high speed transitions.I actually had trouble staying awake while watching this film because of the sensory overload of too many images changing rapidly.Frankly, I think that employing a multi-universe is lazy storytelling. Need a special skill escape to danger? Just tap into a version of yourself in an alternative universe and utilize in your current situation.The hot dog finger universe was funny for a few seconds but required a massive suspension of disbelief. Who, exactly, built that piano with their non-functional hotdog fingers?The movie slows down and becomes emotional and poignant at the end. It was a satisfying conclusion.
Watched 40 minutes of it, couldn't watch the rest. I guess if you're taking your kids to the movie its alright, but for me, as a grown adult, I found it too silly.

Great story opening and mide story
Weird multiverse charactersWtf ending.Waste of timeJust watch jet li movie the one a lot better.Simple and fun to see.

Everything Everywhere All At Once succeeds where even brand Marvel fails: the concept of Multiverse.This requires a right level of ambition and high amount of craziness. A formula which Hollywood couldn't decode, until now.The writer-director knows what they want and also knows what they want audience to experience, right from the first frame.Be it the mundane life of the main character or John Wick-style martial arts.Everyone in the movie is connected, so you don't feel even a second wasted.I believe this is more than enough for you to give this movie a chance.Sit back and enjoy the ride.

reviews.review_title: Completely Lives up to the Title
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All at Once is precisely that, it is a film that defies genres, melts minds and breaks hearts.At its core, the film is a stirring family drama about the potential destructive nature of the intergenerational divide, particularly in immigrant families. But it is also a laugh out loud comedy, jaw-dropping martial arts film and mind-bending multiverse sci fi (eat your heart out Dr. Strange).Absolutely incredible performances from an instantly recognisable and brilliant cast, and a rousing, atmospheric score by Son Lux are the cherry on the cake of my favourite film of 2022.A must watch for anyone, especially when shared with family, friends or loved ones. You will laugh, cry, and surge with adrenaline, and when it's all over you'll want to watch it again.

reviews.review_title: 2h30min ago I could swear I never did drugs. Now, not so sure
reviews.content:
My mistake, I trusted an IMDB rating of 8.0 and thought this would be about an Asian family cultural conflict with US, or something along the lines. Did not watch the trailed.The title made no sense but hey, artistic license, right? Wrong. The title is appropriate and descriptive of the movie.I find the art in this movie is a thin brightly painted veneer over a rock tumbler, mixing and crushing any strand of narrative that may have inadvertently formed during shooting. It's like someone drunk trying to piece together last night's events. It feels heavy, pungent and ultimately hopeless. Flashing lights warning.The whole movie could have been 5 minutes if the loopy kung-fu wannabee art, which felt mostly surplus quality, would be stripped away.Fun factor: 6/10 akin to TikTok for 2h - you will laugh a bit
Narrative: absent
WTFs/hour: new world record
Message: 2/10
Time management: nope, none
Acting: decent.

This is one of the best movies i've seen in years. The Daniels have outdone again. Original, mind boggling, amazing performance, amazing choreography absolutely amazing. It will give you the perfect movie experience. Please go and watch it on cinema. 100% worth it.

reviews.review_title: You've never seen a movie like this..
reviews.content:
Holy crap that was such a good movie...
Interesting from start to finish... Extremely weird but in the best way possible..Such an interesting take on the multiverse and I could see this movie having sequel's,spinoffs, and series based on it.I put this on not knowing what to expect and just as something to pass the time,
I walked away with my new favorite movie of 2022.

reviews.review_title: Eyes hurting from all the rolling...
reviews.content: This movie tries way too hard. Maybe it's an attempt to match the the extreme pace of so many movies these days - trying to dazzle audiences with constant action, humour, emotions and story so we don't lose attention...or something. I suppose many of us have lost the patience to appreciate the character development, subtlety, and simplicity of well-crafted plots. Maybe we have been conditioned by Marvel, tik tok and YouTube to crave bursts of action, CGI, flashing lights and simple, accessible, and lazy comedy. This movie fails to capture my attention because it's all there, all at once. I don't have to wait for anything, and I don't have time to wonder what will happen next. Mind you, it's too random for this anyway. I'm disheartened to see this movie rated so highly. Nothing but cheap thrills here.

reviews.review_title: Poignant, unique, fun, interesting, heartfelt - a must-see!
reviews.content: 'Everything Everywhere All At Once' is a simple story about a family's search for meaning. It also happens to be a mind-bending, multiple-universe, kung-fu, sci-fi epic! Evelyn (Yeoh) and her husband Waymond (Quan - Short Round from 'Temple of Doom'!) run a laundromat and have some issues with their marriage, their daughter Joy (Hsu) and Evelyn's father, Gong Gong (Hong). What starts out as a family drama doesn't take long to turn into a fight to save the multiverse when another Waymond shows up to enlist Evelyn's help.From the directors of 'Swiss Army Man', "the Daniels" sure know how to do surreal well, but make sure there's plenty of laughs and idiosyncratic comedy. The alternate realities are explained quickly and simply - no time is wasted and the plot and action is always moving along. Yeoh, Hsu and Quan are all great, as is Jamie Lee Curtis in her role(s). Yeoh should get extra credit both for the stunts/fights at her age (it is 20 years since 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'!), as well as pulling off both a martial arts expert and boring housewife at once.While there's plenty of bonkers thing going on - Hsu's costumes are excellent, some hilarious sex jokes, great/unexpected use of "Absolutely (Story of a Girl)"- the heart of the film is the relationship between Evelyn & Joy and Evelyn & Waymond. There's some sad moments and some beautiful ones, especially the quiet desert scenes, but we're left with a great underlying message of love and kindness giving the world meaning.

Last night I watched a different multi-verse film: Doctor Weird and the Blabberverse of Nonsense, and tonight this. What a contrast. One is a stupid, formulaic, run-of-the-mill franchise film made with the sole purpose of making as much money as possible and nothing else. The other is a beautiful and wonderfully creative, intelligent, extremely original, and deep story supported by perfect directing, acting, and production. And extremely funny at the same time. A true work of art and love.I can fully understand and respect that this is not for everybody, but if you're tempted this type of unique films, you're in for a real treat. In my book it's the best in decades. It makes me both happy and hopeful that someone invested money in this, while I'm in no way surprised that none of the usual, big Hollywood production companies did.

This film is not only unique in decades but has never seen such a picture in history. I don't want to say which movie is better or not. This is a great human art. The same thing we feel when we read a perfect story without being a storyteller. This film has enough knowledge of classic cinema and made in such a way that the perfection is easily felt in it . I personally cannot ignore the place of this film in the history of cinema. A completely human film. Without any confrontation and at the same time without causing any disturbance in his pure and pure art. A film that is not artificial. It's easier to say, for centuries, no one has designed such an image that is so deep. It has nothing to do with ideology.I'm just talking about the artistic texture of the film.The unique realism of the story in the heart of such a structure is truly magnificent.

The humour feels like a Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer comedy in other words it did not work for me, the action was pretty good with a mostly well perform cast and some interesting visuals. But with a story I already figured out in the first 30 minutes with no interesting twist or turns for me, the movie is similar to The Matrix with a lot of references to it but I don't like The Matrix.It's also funny to me because the movie is about a "Overbearing asian mum" which is a joke that every hack Asian comedian makes.Personally I got nothing out of this movie, all of the ideas I already had figured out when I was 12, And the message is as deep as Rick and Morty, it kinda reminds me of my relationship with Charlie Kaufman movies. Where there basically preaching to the choir.(Could have been a 6/10 but I hate movie theatres)Also watch "The Death of Dick Long" from one of the directors. I like that movie a lot more :)

reviews.review_title: Great commentary on the existential dread we all face & the power of love.
reviews.content: This film spoke to me as a woman, a person who deals with mental health issues, and a person who is constantly trying and struggling to find meaning in the world around me. This film follows a main character who is the epitome of an average-Jane. She has money and family difficulties, wonders if she has made the right choices to land her in her current circumstances, and struggles to make the right choices for those in her life. It incorperates an action-fueled multiverse plot in order to tell a story about how we are all capable of an infinite amount of things, and that no one reality if superior or inferior to another. The life we live currently is indeed a result of a sequence of choices, but no life will be without its complications. In a search to find inner peace, happiness, and a sense of belonging and fulfilment, one must look within themselves and within those they love. Ultimately, if you live a life that is rich with love, that life is valuable. There was a lot of social commentary about how feelings of inadequacy, not belonging, and extistential dread can be improved by finding joy and peace in ones current circumstances, and within the small things that make our lives worthwhile. My favourite quote from the film was 'In another life I would have really liked just doing laundry and taxes with you'. This quote truly speaks to the heart of the message that we get too caught up on the meaning of our lives, what we can do better, where we went wrong, are we going in the right direction, when really all that matters is that we honour, cherish, and nourish the love in our lives.

The film is basically two hours of long, drawn out slow motion effects. That is NOT an exaggeration.I sat in the theatre asking my boyfriend what the time was because it kept jumping into slow motion so unnecessarily. It literally could have been a 90 minute film, but it's basically two hours of slow motion and colours and minimal story. It's all about the slow motion.I was more engaged when they were in the laundromat telling the normal story and lost interest as soon as the film became all exposition from Short Round and all the slow motion Kung Fu that took way too long.Disengaging as hell.

Absurd and chaotic, Everything Everywhere All at Once brilliantly combines insane comedy with brutal emotion and philosophical discovery.It doesn't start off brilliantly though, as when at its most sane the plot is difficult to follow. The switching between languages, rushed speech and lack of audio clarity can make the dialogue very difficult to understand. It's very frustrating trying to keep up with the story and this continues in the early multiverse introduction. Only later do you appreciate that none of this particularly matters, the entire plot is impossible so enjoying the mania at face value is probably enough.A synopsis cannot truly cover the ongoing across three acts, each scene progressively more zaney and inventive. Jumping between universes, scenes can be hilarious and immediately followed up by something deep and cutting. They all add something to the film, keeping it unpredictability and enjoyable throughout.The visuals cover everything needed without going overboard on special effects, and props and costuming deliver on every occasion. The cast is superb, the largely Asian-American roster switching between personas excellently, and wonderfully supplemented by Curtis.Not even the most famous 'Multiverse' film to be released in May 2022, but certainly the most unique and undeniably entertaining.

reviews.review_title: Watch it before you die kinda movie
reviews.content:
This is the real multiverse of madness, an amazing roller coaster ride.It is a full commercial, sci-fi, family/emotional drama, crime, thriller, fantasy, humour, love, life, ALL GENRES IN ONE 👌The film is almost like a combination of these films:
Lucy for in relation to the presentation of the evolution of the human civilisation,
Transcendence for the evolution of the mind,
Inception for jumping between universes like in dreams,
Avatar for connecting with other souls,
Matrix for gaining skills like martial arts, singing, etc, more as you practice it,
12B for the combinations of lives you could've lived,
Interstellar for daughter's love & also black hole.After watching this film, it feels like having had a satisfying full meals.This film is easily one of the best films ever made in the entire film history.

reviews.review_title: Don't be fooled by the rating; this movie is awful.
reviews.content: I was so disappointed in the film, that I actually took the time to confirm my email address in order to leave a review. Completely borrowed storyline, basically a spoof of the Marvel multi-verse concept. Ridiculous, bizarre, shock-value stunts throughout, with no real meat or heart to the plot. Cliche and predictable ending. The only reason I'm giving 2 stars instead of 1 is that they *tried* to have a feel-good movie about life choices and regrets, but it leaves way too much to be desired.I don't understand the good rating whatsoever- usually IMDB is spot on, but not this time. Avoid this movie at all costs.

What to say? Waste of my time...I cannot believe I survived until the end. The story is nonsense and the only good part is the special effects (thus the rate 2 out of 10).Seriously, why is this movie in the oscar nominations? Pointless.Two hours and a half of kung fu fighting with random objects, silly humor, mom and daughter relationship and crazy effects.That is literally all there is. The plot is silly and the end is also bad.Try not to waste your time with this. I have no idea why people hype this s*.Waste of time, I wish I could have my 2h30 back so I could do something worth.

reviews.review_title: Rick & Morty has nothing on this
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All at Once could be described as a movie about relationships (mother-daughter, wife-husband, daughter-father), or it could be described as an attempt to find meaning in one's life against the struggles of existence. It could be described as an exploration of choices and whether we meet our potential, or it could be described as a look at the immigrant experience. It could even be described as an epic multiverse-traversing hero's quest against an evil force threatening to destroy reality.This movie is incredibly energetic, with rarely lull in action or story. The most impressive thing about the film is how it's able to take on so much without getting repetitive or tiresome. It could have collapsed into the singularity of its own premise, or just gotten so silly that the sincere moments were lost, but instead we're left with an experience that's funny, sad, incisive, nonsensical, poignant, thrilling, provocative, and a whole lot more on this Everything Bagel of a film. This film has to be seen to be believed!

reviews.review_title: Totally brilliant. Unique with laughs, tears and violence. It had everything
reviews.content: This film is just so different it's hard to describe. It's a totally novel idea that makes you wonder how it ever got made. But thankfully it did.The film is so fast paced you cannot take your eyes of the screen. The acting is superb and you just never know what is going to happen next.An absolute must watch.
I have no words. Every second was precious and full of excitement. It didnt even feel like a 140 min movie. I left the theater wanting more. Just speechless. Bravo!

This film proves the old adage that 'you can't please everyone' - not even everywhere and all at once. A mash up of Matrix/Parasite/and any Jackie Chan movie you care to name, this film simply doesn't work. It starts reasonably well, however, and in the first 30 minutes shows great promise. But then it degenerates into a farcical parade of kung-fu style dance routines that are not only boring but incredibly poorly choreographed. The premise of the film - some sort of interdimensional slippage brought on by stress and self-worth (or the lack of it) - as only explained in the most convoluted and bizarre way that one can only assume it is because the writers don't really want the viewer to know what's going on (clever eh? Not!). The Jackie Chan throw away comedy is laughable in its obviousness and the sight gags are childish to say the least. The acting is pretty good but then, what ARE they acting? No-one knows, least of all it seems the writers and the director! I suspect this film is doing well at the awards simply because, like the emperor's clothing, no-one in the 'arts' world is game enough to say they didn't get it (to admit, if you like, that they are not clever enough to divine this film's 'deep and meaningful message'. Well, folks, the joke's on them because there simply isn't one. This is a self-indulgent film editor's wet dream masquerading as something profound. In short, not worth the 2 hours invested in watching it.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a pretty new American movie released not too long ago and there are several languages included and unless you speak English, Mandarin and Cantonese, you will probably need subtitles for this pretty long film. It runs for 140 minutes and it is the most recent release by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert as writers and directors. If you have seen Swiss Army Man, then you will know that their films are not exactly particularly conventional and I was not sure if I wanna see this one here because I really did not like Swiss Army Man at all, but after the raving reviews and this title's imdb rating going really through the roof, I got pretty curious. Not gonna lie. In the end, it was a good decision to check this one out, even if I cannot say I saw the greatness that many others experienced. In general, I think it is becoming more and more of a problem in films these days that they are going with the idea that the audience can appreciate the outcome without understanding all that is going on. I do not like this approach, but it is definitely one taken here. You can probably watch this film ten times or even more often and you will still struggle with certain inclusions that can only be explained by the statement: "It's science fiction. It does not have to make sense." Well, it doesn't. Still there are more than just a handful creative inclusions and moments in here. I am not gonna lie, seeing Jamie Lee Curtis as some kind of evil brute stomping around and trying to kill the good guys was so absurd that it was funny again, even if I otherwise do not like the actress. But I should also stay with some of the basics here: Former Bond girl Michelle Yeoh plays the central character and this film is another win for her. She already received stellar reviews for Crazy Rich Asians not too long ago and here at least in terms of the film's appreciation, she even tops it the way things are looking now. She is surely a gifted actress. Soon turns 60. The actors who play her husband here and her daughter are not really familiar faces, at least not to people from western audiences like myself. Nonetheless, they all did a good job. Surprised to see how old James Hong already is. Oh well, he has been in some classic films too over the decades and I am not necessarily talking about Kung Fu Panda here.Back to this film now, a few martial arts scenes are also key in here. The Asian element must through I guess. There was also one brief moment when it reminded me a bit of Keanu dodging a bullet in Matrix the famous shot. Not sure if it was mere resemblance though or an actual tribute. As for the absurdity and also comedy that came with it, I could mention many scenes. This felt a bit like Scott Pilgrim meets Spiderverse and I could add other influences too with the Asian background and the protagonist's age. I shall leave it at that though as it is a film almost impossible to categorize and there is not really a need to anyway. You can decide yourself what is the most bizarre about it all. Maybe the stone/rock scenes? Maybe the Ratatouille raccoon approach. Maybe the very brief moment when the characters turned animated. There is a really a lot of conflict between mother and daughter in here. And Yeoh's character is far from a saint here as well. Look at how she is a bit of a homophobe. No perfect main character. She does have flaws. Same applies to the daughter who turns out to be the main antagonist even. There is a happy ending in store though, which may be a bit difficult to accept from a realistic point of view with all the power the daughter apparently possesses and how evil she is, but still. Her villain name also showed us how this film does not want to be taken too seriously overall. I am of course referring to the ways in which Yeoh's character keeps using a wrong name there. Many giggles in the audience. Most of all when Chewbacca came into play. The scene in which the protagonist randomly out of nowhere decides to tie her daughter to a chair and keep talking about the parallel universes etc. Was also a bit of a comedic highlight there because we knew she was right all along, but of course she sounded like a complete nutjob.I must also mention Ke Huy Quan. He played the biggest male character and maybe he even gave my favorite performance from the entire film. Effortlessly made the boring husband part work and also equally effortlessly he pulled off the cool martial arts fighter part. I really liked it a lot, not only that he got this tender kiss in the end, but also the nice words Yeoh's character had to say about her man and how he took care of her complicated self and deliver through calmness and patience. I guess the divorce is not happening then. Maybe not the best way to write male characters with depth because he went for the divorce initially and in the end he just takes it back. Well, we are not told, but it is pretty obvious that love prevails, even if the film is surely more about love between mother and daughter than between husband and wife overall. From my review, you can also see maybe that it was rather the comedy moments when I appreciated the film the most. The more serious stuff and supernatural elements did not do too much for me to be honest, even if I liked the elaboration on how we are just such a small inferior presence in an endless universe and let's not even get started how it is even considerably smaller if there are all these other parallel universes in existence too.One of the darkest comedic moments is probably when the daughter is shot, already in her evil form and seems to be dying from the bullet, but then makes a joke about how it is just organic and pulls a ketchup bottle. Pretty sadistic. This is surely also a film that fits in nicely with the current liberal mainstream in Hollywood. There is drug abuse, even if just very briefly (of course with Jamie Lee Curtis), several inclusions of same-sex romance (not just the daughter at the center of the story, but also between Yeoh's and JLC's characters on two occasions or so in an alternate universe) and we have a character briefly use two gigantic male genitalia as weapons to slap a (male, of course) character really hard. So the slightly questionable inclusions from perspective of moral are also depicted in a playful manner to avoid controversy. The "Be kind" statement was one of the more emotional highlights of the film for sure, but I must say the moment in which the alpha husband dies was something that did not leave an emotional note on me at all. Not one bit. So it is impossible for me to give this film a higher rating. If I had to decide, I would even say it is closer to 2/5 than 4/5 to be honest. It could have been 20 minutes shorter I'd say, maybe even half an hour if they manage to cut the right (i.e. Wrong) scenes and sequences.Finally, let me mention the extraordinary inclusions of bagels (okay, I was a bit off with the donut play on words in my title, but you get the point) and hot dog sausage fingers. So flexible. Unreal stuff. We even get an evolutionary elaboration there to explain how this happened. The film was really not scared of anything or the two people who made it I should say were not scared. It also shows that somehow you can really get away with everything almost these days in film if you don't mess up terribly. We also get premature closing credits at one point in the film pretty early and these are explained through one character sitting in a movie theater. Or how there are three sequences and the first is two thirds of the film and the third (final) one is basically just the epilogue. These segment titles also make the movie title. That is all then. I think it is a film worth checking out on the big screen and it is more enjoyable there than on television or your laptop screen, but I would not say that it is a film that really must be seen. Nonetheless, I find it interesting which directions Asian film has taken over the last decade, especially with a lot of the glorious success these films have achieved in Hollywood and with awards bodies, even if this is not a pure Asian film of course. It is American if we are strict, but the influences could not be any more obvious. Interesting though that two American filmmakers make a movie that has at least 50% foreign language. It is a good film here and there, but clearly also on the overrated side all in all. Maybe this is why many people think it is the ultimate film to watch when under the influence of a drug and I have heard that also about Swiss Army Man, but I personally think that you should always only watch a film when you are in a sober state and not in advance allowed any substance to enter your bloodstream. Same nonsense like these drinking games. Now, that is really it then. I give this movie a cautious thumbs-up. There are strengths and weaknesses and the former are slightly more frequent and dominant I'd say.

The mind that produced this incredible movie is either that of a madman or a genius. Visually stunning and wildly Imaginative as well as dramatic, funny and moving. Brilliantly acted by everyone, astonishing writing and the smartest movie I have ever seen.
One of the best movies I'd the year.It's like a Looney tunes cartoon mashed with Crank on drugs. Darkly funny, great performances by a cast who look like they're having a blast.

This is a movie that is hard to explain but not hard to understand. In my opinion, those are the best movies that give you spectacle but also make you feel something. Every actor in this deserves acknowledged for the hard work they did, right alongside the film makers themselves. The only sad thing about this film is that we will probably never get another movie like it. I will just ha c e to continue to watch it over and over again as it gets better with each view. You get to see things here that we have never seen on the big screen. Couple that with incredible story telling and it is a hit for sure.

One of the most original films I've seen in a long time. If you think the new Doctor Strange film looks crazy wait until you watch this acid-trip. The Daniels managed to create a film that is wildly creative and entertaining whilst also making it profoundly touching. It's insane, unique, hilarious, emotional and I recommend you go out and support it.

I can't say anything that will do this movie justice, but:Other than a very slightly drawn-out ending, it simply gets everything right.Yang Ziqiong and Jonathan Ke Quan were both absolutely brilliant, start to finish.The combination of action, sci-to, kung-fu, everyday life drama, misery, powerful emotional plays, subtle comedy, crude comedy, and the flat out weird, probably shouldn't work but completely did.The scenes pulled their weight, the sound track did, the splashes of arthouse (which I generally dislike) fit in perfectly and worked so well.The natural Chinese-English hybrid conversations between husband and wife were a nice touch, too.And the ending was exactly what it needed to be.

reviews.review_title: We go in a circle, do laundry, do income taxes, do laundry ... is that all there is?
reviews.content: Besides anything else this is a very manic movie. It plays on the (certainly fictional) concept that there are an infinite number of parallel universes and each of us exists in each of those, with particular traits and skills. We witness each character exploring a number of their alternate existences. Distilled down it is about finding your true self and building loving relationships with others. My wife and I stared watching it, she gave up after just 10 or 12 minutes, too off-kilter and manic for her. I watched all of it but in three different sittings.The focus is on Michelle Yeoh as Evelyn Wang. Over 20 years earlier she starred in "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" and here she gets to use some of her martial arts skills. While I admire what the filmmakers did here, for ME it would never become one of my favorites, to re-watch periodically. Too manic and off-kilter and too many symbolic elements to make sense of.This comment by a reviewer reflects my own take:'Though I usually like high-concept creative films, this time I must admit I felt lost in all its odd layers of storytelling and couldn't emotionally get with such an incoherent film that just kept piling on absurdly illogical sci-fi things to its base plot until I ultimately had enough.' (Review by Dennis Schwartz)At home on DVD from our public library.'

reviews.review_title: I got bored one day and put everything on a bagel
reviews.content: There is literally a little bit of everything and everywhere pretty much all at once! It's a pure assault on the senses which not only shows the amount of skill these two directors have at keeping things somewhat under control, but also underlines just how creative they truly are too! There's a LOT of ideas floating around here but if you can mentally keep up, this is a hugely rewarding film that deserves every bit of praise it's been receiving.FYI: I wrote this review with my toes... Literally impossible to type with my giant hot dog fingers.

reviews.review_title: Optimistic nihilism and pure absurdity as the cure for existential dread many need right now.
reviews.content: I would rate this a 9.5/10 if I could, not in the habit of giving out 10s as the perfect film seems impossible to achieve without cinematic obsession the likes of which would drive the average person to early death.Regardless, EEAaO is a fantastic film. Think Kung Fu Hustle x John Dies at the End with a backbone of Mr. Nobody if all were the best possible versions of themselves and had more heart than all three combined.Definitely one of the most daring, beautiful, and off-the-wall insane films I've seen in a long time.High octane action flits back and forth to heartfelt tearjerkers and the absurdly hilarious, possessing a raunchy randomness only Daniels can evoke. Give them the multiverse and the Russo Bros, you've got a cohesive epic with excellent performances from everyone.Genuinely moved by this film. Despite the exceptional components, it transcends these to become greater than the sum of its parts. I teared up on two separate occasions, all while the crowd was roaring throughoutI will need to see this movie a few more times to get every moment, as there is very little breathing and blinking room-one of my largest and only qualms was the lack of time spent exploring alternate paths to a degree I would like overall. This, however, ignores the message of the film which I believe has to do with optimistic nihilism or the idea that the meaninglessness of the universe is a chance to make your own meaning with what you have.It's an important message that we all need to hear every once in a while. Hug someone close and tell them you love them; for all we know we only get one path-but make sure you scream it in a language they don't understand because life is unfair and absurd (Then take them to go see Everything Everywhere All at Once, it slaps).

I had no idea what this movie was about and was in NO WAY expecting it to be as incredible as it is. The acting was phenomenal, the costumes were beautiful, the special effects were perfection, the story had me laughing and crying at the same time. I cannot recommend this one enough.

reviews.review_title: For adults, like me, who feel they MUST watch this...
reviews.content:
....but have options. Everything, Everywhere, All at Once (EEA from this point forward) had been critically acclaimed and is now been nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars (not that it means anything any longer). For me, that meant I had to view it-in its entirety- to give a fair assessment of the film. I had my reservations going in, I'm really not fond of martial arts- although I'm a fan of both Kill Bill films- and I view stories about the multiverse as generally offerings that use the concept as a crutch because they can not tell a coherent story based in the one universe we all live in. After hearing all the praise and accolades that were applied to this film across the board, I figured I would have to at least acknowledge that, although this was not my cup of tea, the film was pretty good. What a shock it was, then, to find myself embroiled in such a juvenile exercise with such a simplistic meaning. Two hours and twenty minutes of sturm and drang (all at volume 11) to come up with "There's no place like home"? There is actually a scene of two rocks talking to each other- seriously, two rocks- well there ARE two Daniels after all. Suspend your disbelief to accept thousands of other universes for "All you need is love"? When I suspend my disbelief, it comes at a price-EEA fails to pay that price and has a sophomoric sense of humor that one might find in the subgenre of porn/comedy (see Flesh Gordon)
that almost makes me think it's a neo-comedy (you know, the ones where you never laugh- because there's nothing funny). It's truly disturbing to see how the film has connected with so many younger people- although juvenile and simple is the way to go these days. This is certainly not a film for serious adults and my advice is: if you think you're going to hate this film, you're probably right- certainly DO NOT PAY in any way to see it, and have a back up film ready to watch that could save your movie night if you dare venture in. Just remember that Everything Everywhere All at Once could also be an accurate description of projectile vomiting (used in the film) or explosive diarrhea- wonder how the later failed to make the cut in here.P. S. The use of Debussy's. Clair De Lune in this film is an actual abomination- pearls before swine.

reviews.review_title: The most accurately named movie title ever
reviews.content: This is definitely the most difficult review I've written because when I think about this movie my mind is literally "everything , everywhere, all at once". The only comparison I have for it is like Inception meets Matrix.There are definitely many ways to interpret the film but one major theme stood out to me. First, I think the biggest theme is that while nihilism may be easy to succumb to and even a tempting comfort , there is so much more to life if you open your eyes to everything around you and cherish the simple joys of life.With regards to the movie itself, I wouldn't say that I was really enjoying it while watching, it is certainly overwhelming and difficult to keep up with, but all of its themes really made me reflect which certainly is valuable.For this movie you truly need to watch it yourself because your interpretation of this movie is probably impacted by your own personal background and circumstances more than any other movie I've seen.
Ridiculous, funny, intelligent. This is what happens when someone is allowed to create their crazy, clever, independent vision to the fullest. The best film of the last 10 years.

Every new film/series is just a reminder, that we've barely scratched the surface in the infinite possibilities of storytelling and who knows what great new film/series is coming next... to make us feel even more tiny in this vast world of cinema.Been wanting to write a review for this since long ago but I couldn't really frame what I had to say for it up until now when I rewatched it today.This film is as absurd as it can be in it's presentation, and that's a good thing. Filmmakers are afraid to tap into weird and absurd things nowadays because of the possible financial losses. Which makes this film feel really fresh in it's concept, it's storytelling, it's action, it's humour, everything is a result of peak imagination from the writer-directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert.Michelle Yeoh. Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, James Hong. Jamie Lee Curtis, each and everyone in the cast is so good that there is not a single loose thread in the acting. They're all just perfect.The story, phew. I can't really describe it to you but just to summarize, it's essentially a story about a mother who is a failure but doesn't want her daughter to be the same, but even if she's a failure, it doesn't matter because it does not change the fact that she is always gonna be her daughter and nothing in this vast multiverse can change that unconditional love a mother has for her child. Michelle yeoh literally travels the entire multiverse to save her daughter and is stubborn (as she should be) in not letting her precious child go.I didn't think this film would manage to make me cry when I stepped into the theatres to watch it for the first time. But so happened the first and, lo and behold, even after rewatching it today, I cried. The film manages to tap into every human emotion possible and makes you feel things. Makes me happy, sad, angry, surprised, bitter and so much more.The aspect which I loved the most? The editing. If this film hadn't been edited the way it has been. I think it wouldn't be able to achieve the status it has achieved as of now. It's so good, it's mind-boggling. I will try my best to recreate some of this in the future if I can because this film really opens up a lot of editing techniques which I've rarely seen before.Just watch this guys, it might become your favourite film of the year. A huge shoutout to A24 for producing this risky project and releasing it before the over-hyped Doctor Strange: Multiverse of Madness which, let's be honest, was barely about the multiverse and straight up disappointing.

Quite literally the best movie that I have ever seen. Everything comes together perfectly; editing, cinematography, acting, directing, VFX, writing, music, and comedy. Definitely very weird and will probably be too much for some people, but I loved it.

reviews.review_title: This Must Be What Being On An Acid Trip Is Like
reviews.content: It was well shot, well acted, well choreographed and well edited. Almost everything about it is awesome. That having been said, it falls short on what really would have made it amazing... watchability.It is simply far too far "whacked out" and we found ourselves waiting for the cacophony to stop... but the maelstrom continues from beginning to end. We didn't enjoy it as much as we had hoped we would. This movie is what a novel written by Picasso would look like: random visual chunks thrown against the canvas.Sorry, but we definitely would not go to see this movie a second time. As much as there certainly was a great effort put into producing it by all who were involved, it is far, far too avant garde and did not impress us very much.
This is a wonderful think piece movie. I can't explain it and I won't. Lol. This will go down as one of those movies people talk about for generations. Watch it.

This movie is an amazing experience. One of the best movies I've seen in my life. Incredible talent and execution on all fronts. It is a movie unlike any other. It takes you into a different reality with many fantastical ideals and odd creations and somehow makes it not cheesy and awe-inspiring. Just incredible. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Bold. Imaginative. Realistic. Exciting. Depressing. Motivating. Happy. All at once.
reviews.content: This has to be the best thing I have ever experienced. The movie wins at so many levels. It answers so many complicated questions that we ponder on everyday in such simple and entertaining way. It breaks so may social stigmas and fictional barriers that we as humans have been facing everyday since forever. This is a masterpiece to be cherished forever. Thankyou Dan and Daniel for making this. So much grateful to both of you!

Spare yourself - this is a turkey of epic proportions. Way too many subtitles, impossible to follow. It feels like Chinese investors bankrolled this and insisted on it being entirely in Chinese. I've seen reviewers giving it 100 out of 100. Unbelievable. I gave it 30 minutes more than it deserved and you shouldn't give it 3 minutes. Awful on every level. Truly the "emperor wears no clothes".What a waste.Am I the only one? You people are giving this 8+ out of 10? Hell no. A confused expensive mess pandering to Chinese investors. Bafflingly bad.

This is a frenetic, bombastic visual spectacle that will either leave you flabbergasted, overwhelmed, confused or nauseated ; or possibly a combination of these feelings.At the heart of the film there seems to be a heartfelt message. However the journey to get there takes you on a acid fuelled wild ride full of hotdog fingers, rubber phalluses, bum-bag nunchakus and racoonouille.In turn this fast-paced vomit-inducing journey detracts from the overarching conclusion leaving you overwhelmed with everything you've just witnessed.There were certainly parts which were hilariously ridiculous, filled with adrenaline fuelled action and emotionally deep but my overall feeling at the end was just exhaustion.They tried too much, everywhere, all at once.

reviews.review_title: One hell of a multiversial ride
reviews.content: I couldn't stop comparing this with The Matrix since both these movies share a common technology but in EEAaO there is a catch. I don't want to spoil these moments but these goofy elements are what makes this movie an original. There are so many inspiration and Easter eggs of other movies but still there's uniqueness in this movie. Everything in EEAaO is a masterpiece - Stunts are funny and serious at the same time , The cast have aced their roles , Editing deserves an Oscar and the Cinematography is a contender for Oscars ( Though I'm sure The Batman would win it ).The themes of Nihilism and Existentialism are discussed in a scene consisting of rocks and if that scene doesn't convince you to watch this movie then I don't know what will.

Laughter-seriousness, sadness-happiness, beauty-disgust, and a feeling of profound existentialism...I couldn't stop tearing up during the last half of the movie. The writer is able to convey the meaning of life, and able to deep connect to my soul. Being kind to others is my strength, and how I fight.I really don't want to go into any more details because this movie has to be seen by everyone who is able to read subtitles.Best movie I've seen since Free Guy.

I've been trying for days to find the words to describe this genre-defying movie. At its core, this is a film about family, acceptance, and learning to embrace the better parts of the here and now, despite the noise and pressures of the lives we live and the choices we have made. The vehicle Evelyn takes to her realization is a mind-shredding roller coaster of energy, sight, sound, and conflict, as she travels the many paths of lives she never led to the ultimate goal of happiness and contentment in the life she chose to lead. It is a ride that takes the audience places they could never have imagined they would go. I loved every minute of it.This movie is packed with action, laughter, humility, love, silliness, crudeness, and depth, as the "everything" of Evelyn's multiverse existences join forces to guide her to a life-affirming understanding of what really matters. Quite simply, it is one of the most original, creative, and rewarding films I have seen this millennium. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Its a bad movie which caters to a lot of people
reviews.content:
This movie is inherently bad.its all style over substance. There is no clever storytelling, heck there isn't a story.So heres the reality
This movie just caters to a large demographic
1) people who belong to lgbtq community
2)people who have immigrant parents
3)people who come from broken homesSo this is the reason why many people consider it a masterpiece. In reality its just an average movie. People who have seen enough cinema in their life would never ,never call this a masterpiece. Usa,france,uk,china,india,spain,germany all these have movie industries and to call this movie the "Best film ever" is a joke.

Do not sleep on this.Like with their previous movie 'Swiss Army Man', the Daniels take you on another ecentric mad adventure with Everything Everywhere.Their vision is one of the most ambitious things Ive ever seen on film, and the level of talent on display is breathtaking.Leave your hesitations at the door and buckle in. Its going to be a bumpy ride!

reviews.review_title: Off the rails ... and into the ditch
reviews.content: Although the first 30 minutes of this movie was quite compelling and showed much promise, the remainder of the film consisted of senseless vignettes that failed to engage me and included various attempts at humor which were often in poor taste, if not outright disgusting. Eventually, it became an embarrassment to watch.Did I understand the plot? Yes. Was it easy to follow? Yes.A movie like this begs to be watched multiple times, to discover the hidden gems inside (think, for example, of Mulholland Drive). Unfortunately, I could not bear to watch Everything Everywhere All At Once a second time, let alone a 3rd, 4th, or 5th viewing.

Wow. Where to begin? Without giving spoilers; this was the most entertaining, well made, intriguing and heart warming film I have seen in years.The action was fantastic and hilarious, the concept original and gripping. Michelle Yeoh and all the supporting cast were flawless. Best film of 2022 and it's only May.

Good premise, sadly badly executed... The acting is quite fine, but it's not enough to make up for the nonstop absurdity of this movie. Rocks with wobbly eyes... hot dog fingers? Rather than creative, that shows someone has not been taking their pills... Perhaps someone somehow can someday fix this mess and make a real movie out of it.

Wow!! What just happened! An amazing unique feast for the eyes. I can't even imagine how the creators of this film managed to depict the themes in such a fast paced visual explosion of ideas. Multiple universes on steroids ! A beautifully crafted film, with a heart-felt message, plus excellent martial arts, and so much more, hilarious!

reviews.review_title: The best film of the year?
reviews.content: Well, I was really looking forward to this film and probably it was even my most anticipated film from this year. Because the Daniels delivered a great film with Swiss Army Man, which quickly became one of my favorite films. Well, and together with A24 and the creative trailers, this can only go well. Nevertheless, I also have my problems with the film.But be that as it may, one thing is certain, because Everything Everywhere All at Once is undoubtedly the most creative film of the year. If not the most creative film of all time. This becomes clear in the first shot alone, in which you can see the family through a mirror in the film. And even if this shot is quite short, you already learn so much about the family. Well, and that also extends over the entire film, this incredible creativity. For example, when the characters talk and in the background you can see something that is actually much more important, but the characters don't notice it. And there are so many scenes that are brimming with creativity. But of course, this creativity comes to the climax when it comes to the multiverse. I mean, there are so many ideas that are simply unique and that you have never seen before. For example, if the characters want to gain access to another universe and then have to do something specific for it. The scene with the paper somehow hurts more than any fight scene and the same applies to the scene with the dildo. I mean, who comes up with such ideas? And then there are so many other ideas that you could talk about it for an eternity. Everything that has to do with Ratatouille is just so funny or the scene with the stones, with the pinatas. All this is just so great, so unique, so unforgettable and thus without a doubt probably the most creative thing I have ever seen.By the way, someone else noticed that the melody from "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia" appears. It may also sound similar, but I could swear it's the same melody.Well, the fact that the film is so creative doesn't mean that the plot is good. In this case It does. Because Everything Everywhere All at Once is not a film about the multiverse, not an action film, not a typical hero's journey, it's a family film. About a family, for the family (even if some scenes are probably not suitable for everyone). I actually expected something different and rather a typical hero story in which Evelyn has to save the multiverse, but instead it's more about understanding what family really means, that you can overlook little manners, accept everyone as they are and should appreciate everyone who loves you. Well, there is so much more behind the creative facade. A damn multi-layered film that you won't soon forget.Another great aspect of the film is also the characters and the actors who embody them. All the characters in the film are just fantastically written. This is because they all have their weaknesses and are not perfect. I hate these films in which the protagonist is just perfect in every way, masters everything immediately and has no weaknesses. But in this film, every character has any blemishes, weaknesses and bad qualities, as every real person has. Nevertheless, all characters are likeable. Evelyn, for example, is a great protagonist.
