The quality of the comedy is very low and it's too damn exagerrated, like what is supposed to be so funny about a girl using two d****s as weapons? It's rather depressing because nowadays almost anything has to be sexualised.

This film is a reminder of what can happen be when it's made not as a cash grab but a piece of art. I have never been so emotionally affected by a film before. Some people won't get it. But if you're burdened by a nihilistic thoughts and in search of some meaning in a depressing world, this film is a wonderful reminder of why we keep going.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest films in recent memory
reviews.content: I seldom write IMDb reviews. Even rarer that I write them for a movie I enjoyed. That I am speaks volumes about how fantastic this film is.I've seen a lot of movies. Including most of the top 100 films of all time (according to IMDb). This movie easily deserve a place among those. It's witty and funny while simultaneously poignant and thoughtful.It's a rare movie where I walk out gushing like this. You deserve to see it unspoiled - go see it.

I want to say that Everything Everywhere All at Once is completely unexpected, but if you saw the trailer for this film or watched Swiss Army Man (the previous effort from this creative team,) you kind of go in expecting things to be extreme and odd. The film is delightfully off-the-wall once the action gets started, and I was ready for anything. What I can say completely surprised me about this film is that it made me laugh more than I have in a theater in a long time. When sitting in a theater with a dozen other people who clearly weren't getting the same enjoyment out of the film, I felt no guilt whatsoever when I was all the only one laughing like a fool at so many of the crazy moments. I know humor is extremely subjective, and there were a few things that some might find offensive instead of funny, but I was tickled by it repeatedly. I also think they abandoned some logic in order to embrace the insanity. Discussing logic might seem like a fool's errand in a movie like this, but there is still an internal logic established that should be followed, and I'm not sure that was always the case here.The cast was remarkable in Everything Everywhere All at Once, particularly since they are all playing so many different versions of the same people. I struggle to think of anyone who could have done as much with the lead performance as Michelle Yeoh did. She is brilliant and crushes every insane thing she's asked to do. It was fun to see Ke Huy Quan doing his best Jackie Chan impersonation in a role that seems like it was clearly written for the latter actor. I haven't seen Quan in many films lately, so it was great to see him crushing it here, and holding his own. This was the first time I've seen Stephanie Hsu, but she did a great job playing the daughter, who becomes a vital character in the plot. Jamie Lee Curtis was almost unrecognizable, which worked great for me because I had no idea she was in the film, so I got the slow recognition as I started to register I knew that actress. I will say, one of the coolest things about the film is that there were so many powerful women driving the story, although that's diminished slightly because it still required the man to fix things.I think part of the reason Everything Everywhere All at Once is being highly praised is the way it tackles some heavier topics despite the insane premise. I wanted to be overwhelmed with the way they delved into the complexity of the relationships in the movie, but it never quite brought a tear to my eye. I feel like they undercut some of the emotions by handling it through such odd visuals and a number of weird worlds, so when they returned to normalcy it didn't click as much for me. Although it's possible I simply didn't like the way it was resolved at the end. There was a moment earlier in the film that totally worked for me because I connected with the lesson that the protagonist learned, but the conclusion didn't pack the same punch. I also wonder if the filmmakers (and most of the reviewers I've read) think the movie is far more profound than it is in reality. It's hard to say, as I've only seen the movie once, and there's certainly a lot of crazy stuff to digest. Perhaps on further viewings I'll get more from Everything Everywhere All at Once and rank it even higher.

reviews.review_title: A self aware crazy film that you can appreciate
reviews.content: To state the obvious. This is a crazy movie. It's over the top. It's extremely convoluted. It's a complete mess. But that's what the filmmaker was going for. And while I think a lot of the movie is enjoyable, I find you become numb to a lot of the action quicker than the creators would have liked. Nonetheless this movie has all my respect because of just how crazy and original it is, especially in a industry that loves to churn out safe, formulaic movies. This movie is not perfect by any means, but it's a jolly fun time that is worth a watch. Just don't expect to understand most of what's going on.

Do not waste your time or money on this movie. A giant mess completely throughout with no redeeming aspects at all. Everyone must have been stoned who like this movie. Rarely do I write reviews. Created an account specifically to warn others from this train wreck of a movie.

What a bonkers, insane, emotional and hilarious ride. This film proves that Disney may have all the money but that is nothing in the face of good writing. Disney's multiverse movie (Doctor Strange: ITMOM) had a budget $200 million yet is trounced in every aspect by Everything Everywhere which has a budget of $25 million. It's all in the writing.The film seems to start off as a conventional family drama film, with a past-her-prime mother running a small business, who is struggling to make meets end, her husband who she becomes more distant from, the daughter discovering herself but moving away from her parents in the process and the grandfather whose views are dated. The film starts off like this, but then goes absolutely bonkers, delivering some insane action-sequences and dropping a ton of information on the audience. Yet it all makes sense. At no point are you lost in the madness. You're invested the whole way through with strong characters, excellent performances and excellent handling of themes such as nihilism, existentialism, regret, love and kindness.The acting is top-notch across the board with particular praise going to Michelle Yeoh as Evelyn and Ke Huy Quan as Waymond. Their relationship is central to the movie and the actors give it their all and deliver some truly stunning, inventive and bonkers action sequences. The visuals are also fantastic, with excellent uses of colour, lighting and camera tricks to give the film its own unique style.The biggest takeaways from this film are the lessons it teaches. You feel like a better human being for having watched it. Despite all the madness, the emotional moments still hit hard and by the end all the pieces fall into place, leaving you satisfied. This film doesn't need to lecture the audience on modern world problems, or explain that because of its diverse casting it is some cultural moment. No. All you need is good writing.Overall, Everything Everywhere All At Once is best described as indescribable. It has to be seen to be fully appreciated. The characters are wonderful, the acting excellent, the visuals and action are wacky in all the best ways and the deeper emotional meaning of the film really shines through. If you have to watch one multiverse film this year, make it this one.

So many dumb things in this movie, like impossibly unreastic type of stuff. If you like scifi tv shows/movies, don't watch this. Tbh i am 50/50 on multiverse theory, but multiverse does not = every possible or impossible universe can exist. Life takes time to evolve, the sausage fingers universe was unbelievably stupid. It is impossible for humans to survive nor evolve that way and progress that far. Racoon controlling person by hair, facepalm.

This is the strangest film I think I have ever seen, that being said I was compelled to keep watching when I didn't want to. Some of it made me feel uncomfortable whilst other parts made me confused but again I was 'forced' against my will to keep watching. I can't leave a legitimate and complete review because I don't know what else to say. It's strange, rubbish, magical, odd, watchable, terrible and wonderful all at the same time. I will never watch it again but will remember every part of it.I'll say this though, the cast was superb and managed to make sense of a script written by either toddlers, junkies or geniuses. That's all I have!

Surprised that none of the comments I read (although I probably missed a lot), didnt compare it to the Matrix. Although certainly better alternative than messy and ugly Matrix 4, has pretty much the same introduction and location where the dimension travel begins, while the links to philosophy and religions are also present.Michelle Yeoh has grown to be my favorite Asian actress and is certainly great here. The levels of imagination used and the ludicrous moments are outstanding.However it feels that the budget was limited and that we watched an extended director's cut.

reviews.review_title: Not as original in plot and premise, but sheer creativity and ideas keep it engaging and entertaining
reviews.content: Best described as Sam Raimi, Hideaki Anno & Satoshi Kon by way of the Shaw Bros, with bits of Inception, The Matrix, Slaughterhouse Five and the cult Don Coscarelli film John Dies at the End. That latter pic had similar style and ideas but a more original plot. If not for the standard "chosen one" premise that has long since been exploded by The Lego Movie a decade ago, EEAAO could have been a masterpiece.And it does come close - VERY close. Seriously, never before have butt plugs been so crucial to saving the universe.However my biggest gripe is that it reaches its climax at about the 1 hour 40 min mark - then just keeps going. I started zoning out and wanting the movie to just get to the point of it all. I'm all for creativity and invention, but the final act of this could have been tightened up way the hell more in editing.Strongly recommended, though. Go have a blast!

reviews.review_title: Unlike anything you have seen before, it's Everywhere all at Once, a modern masterpiece - My Ultimate Review
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All at Once is the second film written and directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, you really see how they have grown as filmmakers and storytellers from their previous feature film "Swiss Army Man". Everything Everywhere All at Once has been described by The New York Times as a "swirl of genre anarchy" and incorporates elements of comedy, science fiction, fantasy, martial arts films, and animation. It's a unique movie and the interesting thing is how Kwan and Scheinert had researched the concept of the multiverse as far back as 2010, and they began penning the screenplay by 2016. So it's been like a passion project, in a way. Before watching this film, I thought it was supposed to be this action packed sci-fi film, but I was wrong. Everything Everywhere All at Once is actually a bittersweet domestic drama and a marital comedy, a story of immigrant striving and a hurt-filled ballad of mother-daughter love. Then it incorporates multiple other genres into the film, thus giving us some impressive sci-fi sequences but also some superb action sequences which are choreographed in such a great way. It's just 139 minutes of entertainment. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert have created something special and worth watching.An aging Chinese immigrant is swept up in an insane adventure, in which she alone can save the world by exploring other universes connecting with the lives she could have led.Michelle Yeoh plays the lead role in such a brilliant way, showing her impressive acting range when she ultimately ends up portraying different versions of her character. The same would be said about Ke Huy Quan who plays her husband and Stephanie Hsu who plays her daughter, but Michelle Yeoh is terrific and her performance is one of the film's highlight. Meanwhile the supporting cast has names like Jenny Slate, Harry Shum Jr., James Hong, and Jamie Lee Curtis.The film explores the concepts of the meaning of life and nihilism, also themes of existentialism and Asian-American identity. Anne Anlin Cheng wrote in The Washington Post: "It's not only that the multiverse acts as a metaphor for the immigrant Asian American experience, or a convenient parable for the dislocations and personality splits suffered by hyphenated (that is, "Asian-American") citizens. It also becomes a rather heady vehicle for confronting and negotiating Asian-pessimism". The theme of meaning of life and the deep story regarding the relationship of mother and daughter and the marital themes was my favorite parts of the writing, well all the themes really were brilliant.Everything Everywhere All at Once is a complex film that encompasses a variety of subjects, but it does justice to each of them with a superbly written script, spectacular performances, and plenty of bizarre humor that doesn't drag on too long to counter its bleak story. It's a film with a deep message that executes its themes perfectly, making you think and reflect about them. It's directed, edited and written with such brilliance. Acted perfectly. The humor might not be for everyone, sometimes it was too bizarre and extreme, but it works if you get immersed enough into the movie which was easy. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert has a strong imagination, the film wouldn't have been as good if it wasn't for just that, their imagination. Beneath the bizarre humor and over the top sequences lies a film worthy of everyone's attention, it's deep as it's extreme, it's a masterpiece that could have easily been a failure. But it became a box office hit (A24's highest-grossing film at the domestic box office) but also universally acclaimed by critics and audience.

reviews.review_title: Visually stunning and ambitious but ends up boring and empty.
reviews.content: Everything Everywhere All at Once started ambitious and interesting but ended up being an overlong boring mess with an orgy of random colorful stuff thrown around, and non-stop action, that doesn't allow the audience to breathe. My head hurt so bad after.It's always fascinating to me how much people's opinions differ. Contrary to the laudatory reviews, the film has very little substance and message. The creators laid the foundations, but did not fill it with content, the conclusion is quite a cliche, and yes, in the end, life is a bunch of old truisms that can be deep and charming in their simplicity if the road leading to them, is real. But this film quickly gets lost in a madly spinning merry-go-round of colors, movements, words, and sounds. You can cut half of the movie and it won't change the message or the ending, the movie is 40 minutes too long. This isn't coherent vision at all and it just leaves you confused and with a headache. Someone may say that this form is intentional because that's exactly how life is, but sorry, the creators can't get a pass so easily. If you claim you made a movie with a real message it's your job to make the audience care, to show something that is raw and true not bore people to death and just throw random things around over and over again.Everything Everywhere All at Once is in the end tedious and loud, and it leaves you with very little not some grand wisdom.It's absolutely not an 8, 9 or 10. It's technically and visually well done, but the story itself pretends to be more profound than it really is. This is def one of the most overrated movies this year.

A science fiction martial arts movie about nihilism??? You'd be forgiven for thinking it could never work, but it does - and wonderfully well. It's a creative and anarchic film, with plenty of action and humour, and a talented cast. Michelle Yeoh is great as the women who is angry and disappointed at how her life has turned out, running a laundromat with her good natured but feeble husband, daunted by her father and scornful of her resentful angst-ridden daughter (well played by Stephanie Hsu). A meeting with an officious IRS apparatchik (Jamie Lee Curtis) brings everything to a head. In a different reality things could be so much better - and so much worse. Buckle up and enjoy the ride!

Its not often I go into a movie without knowing something about it. But I was told it had to be done.In the first 20 minutes, my mind was blown. Stunning visuals, great storytelling, and a powerhouse of acting talent.No spoilers - just watch it and prepare for a ride.

Such a mess, awkward, waste of time movie .. I tried to give it a chance but I didn't understand anything the whole movie, it is very strange the rating is high!!!!! I didn't laugh or enjoy watching although i was waiting till the end mybe i understand something but it was so complicated and unclear, i feel like this movie was made to transfer hidden messages only with no appropriate scenario or clear script.. i wish if it started slowly then the action part starts so we could watch the rest 2 hours with passionIn my opinion, the idea itself doesn't worth to make a whole movie to discuss such an issue, what a joke ..
With this professional production you could make better movie and interesting story ..NOT RECOMMENDED AT ALL!!!!

The movie does not let go from the beginning to the end. After The Squid Game, it's the second film I really liked. I don't understand who the people are who give the movie a 2 rating. What is wrong with them. Acting 10/10, Idea 10/10 Humor 10/10. Tearful scenes 10/10.

Ah, this film... Looking back, it would've been much better had I stared at a wall or graphic pictures of crime scenes for two hours. I suppose there is room in the universe for a movie like this: Two hours of nonstop A/V assault on the viewer. A thin plot, endlessly restated.Heed my warning, gentle viewer. Set aside two hours of your life for literally any other purpose. Meditate. Pet a dog. Do the dishes. Read to blind orphans. Then congratulate yourself for dodging the bullet that is this movie.Do not, under any circumstances, watch this movie. I do not believe any of the people who birthed this movie are inherently evil or beyond redemption, but they need to seriously reexamine why they are on this earth.

reviews.review_title: Like most A24 movies, this is another extremely overhyped pile of trash
reviews.content: The 8.4 score is unjustified. The movie has nothing going for it. The comedy is predictable. The story is boring. The telling of the story is amateurish. The characters are stereotypical. The length of the movie is too long for the substance that's there to work with.I would rather watch paint dry than to watch this steaming pile of garbage.

reviews.review_title: A film about multiverse which explores the idea of choices
reviews.content:
Finally got the chance to see this much hyped movie and I absolutely loved the idea it portrayed.Basically, we're just consequences of our choices compounded over time. And with every choice we've an opportunity to re-write our destiny! This is the idea explored in EEAAO.Most sci fi films tend to loose plot in the nitty gritties of technical details but this one had a top notch plot (and a realistic one at that, i mean who's not fed up with taxes?) which gives it an edge over other similar films.The cast is great (the IRS lady did frighten me!!!)
The eerie music complements the family tension very well and keeps the viewer engaged.I just feel they over did the chaos in the 2nd act, otherwise a great film!

reviews.review_title: I'm glad I stuck till the end
reviews.content: I was reading a few minority reviews here about how confusing it is at the beginning and I totally agree, but you need to hold on to let the crazy parts go to experience the depth of the story. But isn't that how life is? This was thought provoking, full of weird humor that you can laugh off, and my god, the tears because the story in the end, how it all comes together is just beautiful. I could so relate to the mother-father love story and saying "we always find each other" and the mother-daughter relationship and unexpectedly I was in tears watching all this.So pleaseeee, stick till the end, I promise everything will make sense.

First and foremost, this movie is definitely a masterpiece in my opinion. Disclaimer, I'm not saying it is the only masterpiece. In the history of movies and TV shows, there are so many shining stars. 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' is destined to be one of the stars.MusicThe music goes hand-in-hand with the story and emotion development. Take the first 12-minute intro clip as an example, it goes from stressful, disordered, conflicting and confusing music to spooky and mysterious music, and then to calm but sad music. In the meantime, in every little highlight / climax in the plot and emotions, background music was left blank to allow the audience to focus on the key conversation and get ready for the next chapter of story or a different feeling / atmosphere / emotion with a different feel of background music.All of these brilliant uses of background music in the first 12-minute intro clip of the movie, together with all other things make me feel an immersed emotional experience in the character and life of Evelyn as an audience.Dual StorylinesI see 2 storylines in this movie. One is the entertaining sci-fi storyline and another one is the touching family interrelationship repair and self-salvation story. It feels like a top quality double-side sweater. You can wear it with either side and all the threads are intertwined and woven together. Most lines can be read with two different meanings that serve well for both storylines.So Many Elements with Different TastesCommercially, I believe it will be a successful movie as well, because I can see so many elements in this movie, which will satisfy a wide range of audiences.It has so many fun setups and humour, such as the jumping pads that are only triggered by the weird stuff.The fighting scenes are comedy action style, which remind me of a lot of the Jackie Chan classics. Plus the good amount of martial art performance experience of actors and actresses here make the actions more legit, like Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan, Andy Le and Brian Le. Plus plus in some side shots of the actor Ke Huy Quan (Waymond, the husband), he really looks like Jacky Chen somehow. As an audience, I really enjoyed every fight scene in this movie, which certainly brings up the energy level of the movie.This movie touches so many topics, such as family member relationship management, especially from generation to generation, self value, communications and interactions with other human beings, and depression, which are all embedded and integrated well in the plot and get me as an audience thinking more after watching. Especially the two highlights like Waymond saving Evelyn and Evelyn then saving her daughter are really engaging, moving and encouraging to think more and beyond the story itself.With so many elements, the crew doesn't turn the movie into chaos or a stitching product, but a greatly balanced movie.Using Peter Marshall's definition of a good movie, I think this is an excellent movie because it tells a compelling story with believable characters who make me feel Everything Everywhere All at Once.So at the end, a big thank you and many congratulations to the Directors and Writers Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, all the talents, performers and every production team member who made such a brilliant movie for everyone!

I honestly can't even begin to describe this movie except as a complete mess. I love Michelle Yeoh and she certainly showed her superb acting chops in this movie. I just wish I understood the movie. It is a complete mish-mash of confusion, under the timely guise of the very popular notion of multi-verses. I am a fan of sci-fi, comedy, action, martial arts and acrobatics, bullet-time, slow-mo fight scenes - but geez, all in one scene!? And, what's with the raccoon? A nod to Rocket? I son't know. All I know is that Michelle Yeoh's character comes out of it ok.Sorry, it's just waaaayyyyy over-rated.

This maybe the worst movie experience I've had. It is a waste of time so watch this movie.... to try to watch it till the end, but I absolutely had to give up halfway because I was feeling I could lead a completely different life if I just stopped watching this senseless waste of my time.Only a tech head who likes cool special effects will be fascinated by the overly long and tedious Kung Fu movie. Somewhere in there, a message is buried. I will be horrified if this film receives the Oscar for best picture.I'm sure you can do better things that watching this horrible film , if o can call it "film "

reviews.review_title: A whacky chaotic absurd and beautiful love story
reviews.content: I know that this movie will not be everyone's cup of tea. If you are not an Asian growing up in an Asian household or know the Asian culture really well, it might be difficult for you to understand the issues presented in the movie. The words from Evelyn to Joy about she's getting fat might be harsh but it happens a lot and it's actually coming out of love. I know that doesn't make it right but it's how it is in the culture.The movie can be chaotic but that's what the point of the storyline is all about. The world is chaotic. Our life is chaotic. Even the ever expanding universe is chaotic. It can be exhausting to watch the movie with that crazy pace. But isn't life is just like that?This movie is a love story. Between man and woman. Between parents and their kids. Between friends. Even between strangers. The messages might be cheesy but they are always true and they can always be applied to the life and relationship. It was wrapped in absurdity and outrageous scenes. And that is life. Even in the crazy world we are living now, the messages will always be true. That kindness, understanding will always the right way to deal with chaotic life. Some of the lines really hit home for me personally. That 'I would have really liked just doing laundry' or 'that's how I fight' are so poignant.I really like Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis. I was excited to see them in one movie. And what a treat for me to watch them in this movie. The other actors are also amazing. Playing a character in a movie with this kind of storyline and mix of several different genres are surely not easy.I do genuinely love this movie. It will be one of those movies that leave everlasting message to me personally. In a crazy world like this where we are bombarded with terrible movies, it's nice to still be able to find gems like this. I hope this is not the last.

Funny, original, chaotic, charming. We were off to a good start. Problem here is, that things get redundant. Why not leaving it at 3 parallel universes? Instead they showed us some universes that absolutely didnt matter to the plot. And this whole bagel-thing? Is that supposed to be funny? And this hot dog-finger-thing? Where is the need to show this more than once? And...OMG....just finish it. Why is this movie so painfully long? It should have ended when they started the "Everywhere".

Philosophy aside, the absurd goings on in this movie are worth the laughs. I don't laugh out loud near enough, but I lost it several times. Plenty of 'right in the feels' as well. A brilliant intertwining of cosmic/metaphysical/moral/existential nihilism, absurdism, Buddhism, and existentialism (and probably some other philosophies I missed the first time) with a simple a clear demonstration (eventually) of love, meaning, and courage.Let go...,

I absolutely do not understand how you can seriously evaluate this popcorn-tiktok-absurd movie for acting, etc. Well, except for the editing and costumes. I don't mean it's a bad movie. This is a good movie for once. I have a feeling that there are 15 years old teenagers of Marvel fans sitting in the film academy, who, in addition, are also preoccupied with various types of perversions. Are you seriously? What's wrong with you? You just spit on the entire history of cinema. You are losing respect for yourself. It feels like you haven't watched the movies before at all. If you think that toilet humor is worthy of an award, then I feel sorry for you. Create a separate award for such movies. Don't touch history. It's not professional at least.

reviews.review_title: Strap in for a genre-bending thrill ride. A must-see for a million reasons.
reviews.content:
Pro's:
Imagine a movie that has the imagination and mind-bending impossibilities of the Matrix, while also pulling off the reality-jumping acid trip of Dr. Strange. Well, we have one and it's called Everything Everywhere All at Once. It's hard to describe the movie without simply retelling the story, as it truly transcends any traditional film genre. It's not an action movie per se, but it's packed with action. It's not a family drama per se, but you'll feel shades of Beautiful Boy. It's not a comedy per se, but there are genuine laughs peppered in. The movie successfully rolls the best of all of these genres into one and executes. It's also wise enough to not get mired down in any one of the subplots. It keeps moving, often at breakneck speed, too busy warping through absurd and awesome scenarios to get stuck where lesser movies would. The action and effects are thrillingly done. The production value is blockbuster level, a fact quite astonishing considering a team of only 5 people produced all the digital effects for this film. There's a lesbian daughter, but at no time does it become a "message movie" about that. There's a predominantly Asian cast, but at no time does it harp on how "important and brave" it is to tell their story, it just simply tells it without patting itself on the back. The film falls for no traps, it's interested in the plot. The runtime is on the longer side at almost 2 and a half hours, not that you would ever know. It practically crashes and bashes through to the end once it takes off. A ton of thought was put into the visual design of the film, too much to go into here. But of note is the motif of circles, which appear all over the set and costume design, representing the "too much-ness" of everything happening everywhere all at the same time. The movie opens on the image of the family reflected in a circular mirror, the daughter's "everything bagel" is a black circle (echoed when Jaime Lee Curtis circles tax forms with thick black circles), googly eyes pop up on multiple surfaces including main character Evelyn's forehead. Even the family's laundromat is a room stacked wall to wall with the circular washer doors surrounding the characters. This attention to detail is present in everything, everywhere, in the film (pardon the pun). All performances are strong and well done. Veteran Michelle Yeoh's makes her stressed laundromat owner Evelyn a real person. And in a surprise comeback is Ke Huy Quan as dopey husband Waymond. You'll remember him from his 80's stint as "token goofy Chinese kid" in The Goonies and Indiana Jones. And the first half of the movie might have you thinking he's back now to simply put on his "goofy Chinese man" hat. But by the end of the movie he's delivered the most heartfelt moments to the audience, and expanded into a layered, wise character. Rarely does a film deliver on an interesting and inventive plot, thrilling action, and real drama in a way that lands without getting distracted with any of the aforementioned pieces. It's simply a treat.Cons:
There's not much to pick at here in terms of weaknesses. If we're feeling fussy I suppose there may be a consideration, not a plot hole, that could have perhaps led the characters to a solution a bit more expediently than they pursued. Without spoiling major plot points it involves the reality jumping aspect of the film and having access to all possibilities. It seems that maybe certain avenues weren't explored that could have been in order to solve their problem. However, we as the audience have the benefit of sitting back and thinking up scenarios and solutions. Without Monday morning quarterbacking, a different (possibly better) solution may not have occurred to us in the moment either, which the characters must live through in real time and don't get to sit back from removed from the scenario. Especially in a movie like this with the adventure whizzing by at lightning speed. One other, more legitimate, quibble has to do with the Matrix-esque skill acquiring Evelyn is able to do. From what the movie tells us, that should be perfectly possible mentally. But physically, it doesn't perhaps make immediate sense why her body itself would gain or lose functionality (floppy hotdog fingers and hulked-out pinky fingers, alternately). Played more for laughs here, but still. Something to consider.Bottom line: This is without a doubt one of the best movies of the year, as well as one of the best movies of the last few years. Genres are blended and transcended with astonishing finesse. The action comes fast and creatively shot, the drama is grounded and real, it's funny when it wants to be and it will freak you out when it wants to get freaky. It's one of those movies you just have to see to experience this strange but effective blend. It's a little bit of everything, that will take the audience everywhere, all at once. 9.5 out of 10 stars.

reviews.review_title: Has everything. It's funny, it's depressing, it is an original mind bend
reviews.content: I did not have the highest expectations going in, but I left thinking it was the best movie I had seen in quite awhile. There were times when I couldn't stop laughing, truly. There were times when it made me think about the depressing aspects of life. It had bold moments including about a 2 minute bit in the middle that can only be described as incredibly risky, but I thought it worked. With all of the multiverse movies out now, it managed to be an original premise. I will be recommending this movie to everyone and I suggest you give it a watch too.

reviews.review_title: WEIRD. I don't understand the crazily high reviews
reviews.content: This film is the strangest thing I've ever watched. It flips through multiple universes and it's impossible to keep up with what's going on.It's so overrated. I would not recommend. Two hours later I have no clue what the story line is.

I felt... all of the feelings.All of them. Often at the same time (or at least in varying combinations).This film deserves to win Best Picture and Michelle Yeoh deserves an Oscar (which she's not gonna get...)...but we can imagine the universe where she does. And that universe, like this film, is beyond lovely.

reviews.review_title: I wasn't prepared for this movie.
reviews.content: Nothing could have prepared me for it.I knew a few basic plot points, and I'd seen the trailer, and I'd heard the praise. Praise is usually a bad thing for me, because I get overhyped for movies very easily and it's rare they live up to my expectation.And yet, I was still not prepared for this movie.I pity the people who hear about this movie in broken fragments from friends, who have its best moments spoiled by memes, who will never experience the sheer joy of being blindsided unaware by this movie's brand of chaotic, loving insanity.It is better that I was not prepared, because this movie pried open my heart and shook my soul.Shame there's so many bright, flashing lights, though.

reviews.review_title: Not as Good as I Hoped
reviews.content: I heard a lot of great reviews going into this movie and was very excited to watch it; unfortunately, it didn't quite live up to my expectations.The movie starts with about fifteen minutes of introduction to Evelyn's and Waymond's characters, the laundromat they run, and their daughter Joy. It was a great start to the movie with interesting characters, relationships between those characters, and unique circumstances.Then we moved to the IRS office, which brought with it the start of the shenanigans. We are given the same infinite multiverse theory that every sci-fi show proposes, and at first I rolled my eyes.I hate this theory because--while it could be true--the vast majority of universes would consist of us doing stupid and abnormal things like switching your shoes to the wrong feet or eating chap stick... I loved that this movie leaned into that idea, utilizing the bizarre possibilities to access other universes. This is when I really started to enjoy the movie.Then we meet Jobu Tepaki, the main antagonist of the film. I feel like we meet her way too early. There could have been a tense build-up to a reveal of her identity--Joy--but instead it was anticlimactic and predictable. I suppose this gave Evelyn reason to maybe kill her own daughter and instead decide to become another Jobu, but something about it made the pacing rough for me.I will admit that I didn't realize this movie was a comedy until I was watching it. There were parts I really appreciated, like when Jobu says the Ketchup is organic--that was very funny. I appreciate one-off jokes like that, but am not a huge fan of big plot points being gags, like the Bagel being the end of everything, and I don't love comedy just being absurd concepts, like the hot-dog-finger universe. Also, instead of being a throwaway bit, we also got probably at least 5 minutes in that universe across the movie, which seemed rather excessive and got stale fast.Call me a hater--probably true--but I like a solid, serious plot to really get me into it, or I need it to be a full comedy. I'm not saying there can't be a balance of drama and comedy, but I'm not a fan of dipping so far into the absurdity while trying to maintain a serious and emotional story line.I enjoy when a movie has a bit of a moral; usually it's a bit subtle and more of a theme then blatantly telling the viewers what to get out of the movie. But in this case, they bombarded us with multiple blatant morals: Waymond says several times in a row to just be kind, which is a good message, but felt super random and unnecessary; Joy talks about how we only have specks of time with each other; the rocks say how we're all so small and stupid. I just felt like they tried to pack in all these takeaways like homework at the end of a college class.Also, the infinite multiverse theory says that anything that can be done has been done in another universe. But does that actually mean it would be possible for our consciousness to be in a rock or a pinata or a 2D animation? Seems like a stretch to me.I felt the pace was off from when we first met Jobu, but that was especially felt during the last 20-30 minutes. The movie felt like it was wrapping up for almost half an hour, but kept throwing us into different tangents before finally coming to a close.I won't deny there were things about the movie I really enjoyed: (most of) its take on the infinite multiverse theory, a lot of the cinematography was interesting or downright beautiful, and there were definitely some parts that made me laugh out loud. Overall, though, I couldn't take the stakes seriously because the villain's terrible creation was a freaking bagel.
I have no words. I don't even know if I liked it or not. This is the most bizarre film that I have ever seen. It's original, with humour, and has great action scenes. I guess I liked it.

reviews.review_title: Totally amazing No-attention Span movie making
reviews.content: Ive never written a review here but had to this time. It may be the most creative and original movie I've ever seen... How they ever wrote it is beyond me, the editing is mind-boggling, the sound design is breathtaking, it's funny as hell, insane, and deeply touching. I've never seen anything like it... Like trying to describe The Matrix for the first time but crazier and more fun. I urge you to see it.

The story is awesome it tells us don't let your loved ones go so easily. :)
There can be more solutions for the problems. You just need to figure out.

This movie has moved me so much, their so many hidden details and messages one can easily miss during the duration of this movie becsause of all the crazy stuff going on. The message the movie this gives is amazing. To not care about the little things and to accept eachother for who we are, so many realities and ways life can go from just one single choice you make. Whether or not they are good everything in life is infulenced by the choices we make. WATCH THIS MOVIE WITH A OPEN MIND.

This movie verse-jumped straight to the top of my all time favorites. An absolute MUST see in my opinion. I laughed, I cried and I have never seen a cinema audience so completely enthralled by a film before.

reviews.review_title: Frick'en a, best movie of 2022, calling it!
reviews.content: Every emotion felt. I got a lump in my throat more than once. Laughed, cheered and applauded more than a couple times. A lot was going one but I was never lost. Exceptional writing. This was a top notch, well written comedy-drama. Thank you for not treating the audience like they are incapable of understanding a multiple layered comedy. I hope more films like this emerge because it's pieces like this that truly should be a game changer. I want to go out and do weird stuff to connect with my other dimensional self now hahaha! Excellent film, wow!

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of all time!
reviews.content: This movie is funny, creative, different, refreshing, and emotional, all at once. It wasn't afraid to be different and not take itself too seriously. Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu were absolutely fantastic! Would definitely recommend this movie, and I can see this movie getting better with each watch. There's just so much to appreciate and enjoy.10/10!

reviews.review_title: Randomness Weaves a Web Between This Movie and Us
reviews.content:
Just to get this down somewhere so others who have seen the movie will understand...
The morning before we saw this movie was the Saturday before Easter. Our girls, both about the age of the daughter in the movie, were decorating Easter eggs. One of them got the idea to put GOOGLIE EYES on some of them. Earlier in the day, I was filing an amended TAX RETURN, while my wife was doing a lot of LAUNDRY, mostly for our youngest, who came home from college for the Easter holiday. For breakfast, my wife offered our youngest a BAGEL, but she opted for something else.We then saw the movie not realizing in advance any connection to it and the above seemingly trivial events from earlier in the day. For those who saw the movie, I am sure you can see the connection....and it has us amazed. Yes, apparent random events in our lives can, by coincidence, also show up in movies we see.....but for this movie?...given its objective and that our trivial events happened within our family? Something is going on here! (I changed my rating from a 9 to a 10 because of this insight---see yeah, it's a 10 for me purely for personal reasons given the course of events that led up to seeing the movie)If randomness *weaves* a web of events, is anything truly random?For the movie itself, one reviewer elsewhere suggested you 'strap in' and hang on. This movie is a wild ride successfully attempting to give significance to our own seemingly trivial lives if only for a few brief moments in this one particular universe. In the end...be kind.

reviews.review_title: The bagel will tell you the real meaning of things
reviews.content: Some things matter.I have had high hopes for this film and got more than I hoped for.It's hard to go on and analyze this film since the title gives you a short summary. It's a lot and the most essential things simultaneously. Everything is complicated, but all makes sense when you think of it simply.As for the technical part, the production, acting, and humor, everything was just done the right way.Yet the best thing is that you can relate. It shares its emotions with you. No more words - give it a try. It's a great film.

Very confusing story. This movie just tries too hard. I got nothing out of watching three quarters of it. Then I shut it off and I thought to myself, "what did I just watch? I couldn't think of a thing.

Everything Everywhere All at Once proves itself to be an fantastic, immersive film. The direction stands out as some of the best I've seen in quite a while, with only an executiion as amazing as this being able to pull off this sort of wild ride of a film. The acting is really good, with Michelle Yeohn being an absolute blast throughout the film to watch. Along with this, all the other supporting actors are amazing and ultimately deserve Oscar nominations, no doubt. Overall, this movie is excellent, and I implore everyone to watch it. Nothing compares to it out there today, and I really do not you all to see it.
If you love creativity and physics and action and a lot of visual stimulation, you will LOVE this movie. It's in my top 10 for originality (although, there are Fringe vibes) it's well done.

Not much to add to what's been said, other than anyone that wants to do a movie in this kind of genre should not only watch this movie but also study it. A truly masterpiece of its genre.Might be confusing for some, make sure you watch it when you really feel like watching something this brilliant, it's definitely not your sunday lazy afternoon type of movie.It's really Everything Everywhere All at Once and the fact that it was amateur people that did the VFX speaks volumes! So well done!

reviews.review_title: Just hoping for it to be over
reviews.content: If you think racoons that remote-control chefs or a cult that worships a black donut are funny, then this may be a movie for you. I did not find it funny and couldn't await for it to be over. Many things are straight out silly, especially the "landing pads", some supposedly funny activities that people have to perform in order to jump to another universe and gain some special skill.

I watch a lot of movies and take the time to watch those that are thought provoking more than once.Everything Everywhere All at Once is a very special as this is the first film that I have watched twice and can only conclude that in hindsight, I wish I had watched it zero times. This movie is a mess. It takes nihilism to the next level. I cannot ever recall watching such rubbish and trust me, I have seen some extremely bad movies over the years. Even with such a great leads with Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan at the helm of this sinking ship. There is no turning the tide. This is one ship that needs to be torpedoed, as at 139 minutes, it is taking far to long to go down. I suspect that most Millennials will love it (though not this one), as it takes pretentiousness to new levels. If you are curious to see for yourself, watch the first thirty minutes and you have seen the whole movie. Just remember, it is thirty minutes that you will never get back.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the Most Creative Film made Lately
reviews.content: A woman tries to do her taxes, and finds out that life is far more quirky, weird, and fulfilling than she ever imagined.This is a strange movie. The concept has been done to death lately (multiverse), but this film takes that concept to the next level and blows away most attempts of others to make a compelling and meaningful multiverse movie. (The first Spiderverse film is still my favourite in this category). Nevertheless, this movie is ambitious, has lots of heart, and really explores what it means to have a fulfilling life.I think lots of people would enjoy this movie, but it isn't for everyone. It is strange, but the acting is superb, the visuals are ambitious, but often stunning. I don't know if it's quite 'best picture' material - but it is probably the most creative film produced lately.

"Everything..." is groundbreaking in creating a new genre, for which it may well be the only movie ever made. Nothing before; nothing after.Following the title, this 140 minute movie is divided into 3 parts, quite arbitrarily. Part 1, Everything, starts at the beginning, needless to say. Part 2, Everywhere, comes somewhere in the middle. Part 3 All At Once occupies only the last 10 minutes.Underneath the multiverse cloaking, "Everything" is an exceptionally affecting family story, "exceptionally" because while dysfunctional family stories have been told often (perhaps even too often) this one does it really well, thanks, among other things, to its brilliant cast.In the center is Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh), a traditional Chinese immigrant who is now running a reasonably successful laundry business. The three people closest (albeit sometimes feels most remote) are daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu), husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan) and father Gong Gong (James Hong) which means grandpa-on-mother's side, from Joy's perspective. The issue she has with each of them I do not need to elaborate here. You'll find them very familiar.The multiverse adventure in Evelyn's life really starts in an IRS auditor's cubical to which Evelyn, Waymond and Gong Gong have been summoned. Acting a conduit to the various parallel universes is Waymond, who shifts at will between the timid husband we know and a hero of sorts from another universe, "Alpha Waymond", who tries to save all humankind in all universes, from an ultimate evil called Jobu Tupaki. This ultimate villain soon manifests in the body of Joy. Right there is your glimpse of the abundance of allegories in this movie. In real life, mother and daughter are often nemesis personified.Alpha Waymond triggers "jumps" that take Evelyn to other universes. When this happens, we see two Evelyns engaging in parallel activities in two universes. These actions often mirror each other to some degree, in one way or another, more or less, give and take........ That is about the best I can do to deconstruct.After endless searches, Alpha Waymond finds our Evelyn, who is the worst (loser) among the universes. Because of that, she is the best for the job of challenging Jobu Tupaki. Another allegory? You bet.What happens in this titanic struggle in the assortment of different universes is beyond your wildest imagination, bizarre, silly, outrageous, allegorical, funny....and a lot of martial arts, which reminds us that at 60, Yeoh is still in top form. With emotions coming at you like tsunami waves, the dynamic duo Evelyn and Joy appear in every shape and form imaginable and unimaginable, including two cloth puppets hanging from tree, or two pieces of silent rocks in inaudible dialogue carried as on-screen texts. Yeoh is beyond amazing but then Hsu matches her scene for scene, scene after scene. Quan and Hong are solid supports.Playing the tax auditor is Lamie Lee Curtis, described as "unrecognizable" by some lazy critics. Colin Ferrell in "The Batman" is unrecognizable. NOT so for Curtis in "Everything". Even after four decades and under a silly wig, her facial feature are easily recognizable. It's her persona of a stereotyped bureaucrat that is, ironically, quite refreshing.

reviews.review_title: A message we are all familiar with put in the perfect way
reviews.content: I absolutely loved this movie! The pacing and structure of the film were both ridiculous yet great, and the underlying message was truly thought-provoking. At its core, the movie is a theatrical debate between Nihilism and Absurdism, tackling the challenge of finding meaning in an uncaring universe. The fight between "Nothing matters and we might as well die" and "Nothing matters yet despite that, I find meaning even though it doesn't make sense" is particularly relevant in today's world, where both ideas seem to be increasingly common.But it's not just the philosophical depth that impressed me - the movie also contains some of the funniest gags and jokes I've seen in years. I especially loved the bit about racacoonie.My only minor critique is that some parts of the movie drag on a bit, which is why I'm giving it a score of 9 instead of 10. However, considering that it was made by such a small team, the movie is a true marvel and incredibly well made. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a blend of humor and philosophy in their movies.

This was an interesting film, with very strong visual and sounds effects. Obviously many people loved it, but to me it was incredibly long and somewhat confusing. Felt like 30 minutes of good short film and 2 hours of a well-engineered video game.

reviews.review_title: The message everywhere all at once
reviews.content: The movie is a big message itself. It contain despite the sci fi genre the same message in all universe: tolerance and choices in life. The relationship between the daughter and the mother can relate to every mom and daughter. I enjoyed also the same scene where they was near the restaurant and the laundry store and the mother let her go without being with her and seem really careless and we can really relate at the scene when the mother immigrate to China and her father didnt tell anything when she leaved the country without holding her or something. The message of the let it go whatever our choices we made in life. The comparison of the mother life with the different universes that make us understand that they are not perfect choices but just choices and whatever they are lead to some consequences and thats all. Live with indifference because sometimes we dont really know and we need to be gentle with ourself. I found also the movie pretty funny but the "jump" in other universes was just an excuse to make some sexual scenes and pretty extravagant ones. And we have some pretty unexpected scenes with that Racoon and Chad and the way that man needed the racoon to be someone, the two rocks on the cliff, the hands's sausages. Was very funny but the sci fi genre get me off sometimes of the movie and the too much comedy was sometimes annoying but except that the message behind the movie its pretty exceptionnal and we can really relate to our choices in life and the consequences and the way that we idealize always other lifes if we did this or that and really was suprised by the authencity of the movie in that side. Nice movie anyway.

reviews.review_title: Waste of time, messy and not worth one oscar nomination
reviews.content: I am not into hypes, and experienced why while trying to watch this. It is without a doubt the worst movie i have seen in ages. It is a plain rip-off of the midnight library with bad acting, thin storyline and a lot of crappy plots.I lasted 45 minutes but then had to fast forward while it still did not 'grab' me and probably wasn't going to.I am an honest scifi lover, but this has nothing to do with that. It is simply a collection of stolen ideas, brought together in one -much too long- attempt of a movie.The fact that this is nominated for 11 oscars, shows what is wrong with that institute.

Please make movies like they used to....that was a real waste of time It's not depressing that the movie was bad.....what's depressing is that it is so highly rated and that too by contemporary critics.

Everything Everywhere All at Once - High 8/10This movie deserves all the praise it receives. The most notable thing this movie exceeds is its uniqueness due to its amalgam of genres and visuals. From the writing, cast performance, and visuals, these components, under the guidance of the writers and director, created one of the freshest and over-the-top films of the year. Reviewing this movie in detail seems like an impossible task, for many factors contribute to this movie's level of success. So this review will dissect the thing that stood out the most.The movie has incredible diversity, not only a variety of people but also visions. The movie focuses on the theme of life, people's dreams and choices in life, as well as the theme of family. A film that explores the idea of the multiverse is truly represented when the filmmakers make us see the different universes, where it seems like we are watching another movie. The visuals are amazing, from its practical effects mixed with VFX, in most scenes and its action scenes. This movie blends a lot elements from it's various set pieces, costumes, and even character design. However, despite all the other elements, the film revolves around a single lesson: everybody always has a choice every day.The film grasps many themes like passions in life, optimism, family relations, and the idea of nihilism. However, all of them are connected with the idea of the choices we make. On the side of passion, Evelyn is shown countless universes where she is succeeding in life and not working on a laundry mat. Furthermore, she feels she wasted her life and has certain regrets. Her daughter Joy has her struggles, thinking her life is meaningless and wants it to be over. However, not for her sake, but for bringing burdens to her family. Both Evelyn and Joy are burdened by the weight of family expectations. But thankfully, there is Waymond. Let's say his answer in the vast universe is being optimistic in life. Where life can bring you down, you smile up above.Overall, this movie has a lot of things that can be explored. But one thing I love about this movie this feels like a love letter to cinema with pure maximalism. By handling different tones and settings, this movie is one of a kind. Although part 1 of the movie is rough, everything else is near-perfect. Everything, Everywhere, All At Once invites the audience to have an overwhelming experience of emotions with its artistic endeavors but never strays away from the message of choice. And the people who made this movie made many right decisions, and hopefully, you will choose to watch it.

reviews.review_title: This movie has become one of my all-time favourite movies. I deem it a must-watch!
reviews.content: It is long however, unlike many other movies, there are no parts I could pick to cut out. It keeps a brilliant balance between sci-fi/fantasy and being grounded in reality. Exploring the complex challenges of being an immigrant, family dynamics and that show kindness is not a weakness. The acting from all the actors is phenomenal, and trust me, these characters are no easy feat to achieve, yet these talented actors flowed through the roles, never making the illusion feel broken or disjointed. They take you through a roller coaster of emotions, making you want to cry, laugh, and re-evaluate your view on life in just the 2 hours it's on-screen. It is truly one of the most original, genuinely moving, and profoundly deep movies I have seen in a long time.
Cannot believe these reviews, overhyped and such a boring movie. I watched it for 60 minutes but then had to stop. I am really lost why this should be such a great movie.

reviews.review_title: Unique amazing movie that should win all the Oscars
reviews.content: This is one of the biggest surprises in Movie history for me. I had zero expectations, and I only watched this by coincidence but oh boy oh boy is this a marvellous piece of cinematic wonderfulness.I only hand out 10s to the very best flawless movies and this is not that, however it comes darn close and this certainly deserves a 9/10. The main negative is that the production value is sometimes low, and a couple of times you can tell. Don't get me wrong, they do a fantastic job with a limited budget and this outshines all the superhero movies, but imagine what they could have done with double or tripple the budget? The only other "complaint" I have is that I want more. This should have been a 10 hours movie or a 10 seasons TV show and I would eat it all up. I feel a bit cheated that there is no more.The movie is however pure brilliance. The acting is fantastic, the directing amazing, the story so unique and original that I hope all of Hollywood feel ashamed. Music and sound design is brilliant, and I cannot remember when I laughed and cried so much to a movie before. The emotions are strong with this one!Fantastic movie that should win at least 5 Oscars, but I would not surprised if it wins more. Best movie of 2022 so far, and I hardly see any movie surpassing this. Absolutely stunning watch and I cannot recommend this enough. Go see! And see it again!

reviews.review_title: Great film degrades itself with unnecessary dirty jokes
reviews.content: It's a shame that the makers did have to use all these dirty jokes , if they added to the story I would have been okay with it. But they didn't.SO instead of a mature movie with a pg 12 rating it ended up being an immature movie with a pg 15 rating.Daughter and mom are terrific in their roles.Again. A shame about the dirty "jokes" otherwise it would have come close to "eternal sunshine of the spotless mind."

reviews.review_title: Exactly as the film name says
reviews.content: Trying too hard to state the obvious. Too fast, no time to be ... original but still boring fighting scenes ... weak script overall. Michelle Yeoh is indeed a joy to watch hence the 2 stars.

reviews.review_title: while watching, have an airline vomit bag handy
reviews.content: This has to be one of the stupidest, most worthless movies I've ever seen ... or tried to see, because I couldn't bring myself to watch it from beginning to end and had to take a break in the middle. I have no idea how anybody could like, let alone love, this movie. After watching even a portion of this movie, I underwent a neurological scan at the NYU Langone Ambulatory Care Center in Manhattan, to see whether I had sustained permanent brain damage. Thankfully, I had not. Thereafter I consulted a psychiatrist for an evaluation of my post-traumatic stress disorder. Unfortunately, our meeting did not end well: when I described the movie to him, he began foaming at the mouth and became hysterical and had to be sedated.

Am I the only one who feels like 70% of the movie was written by AI?(I also think I saw "Toblerone" chocolate in one of the fast scenes).I don't really want to have an opinion on this mega ambitious movie. I understand the rating, it has many awesome elements, dealt with many different topics, acting is awesome, and it showed eternal mother-daughter problem in a very deep and new way. But for me personally it didn't work, maybe because of its fast-paced bilingual start that I didn't get too involved. It feels a bit like a forced "Hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy" type of thing with all the modern internet topics about your purpose, full potential, multiverses and all. Always makes me wonder did author really felt these things on his own skin or it's just an exploitation of major themes of the mases. But definitely something in sync with all this current AI revolution, somehow.

If I can sum this movie up, it's about a mother who goes throughout the multiverse just so she can tell her father that her daughter is a lesbian.Jokes aside, watching this movie is a really wild ride, more "Multiverse of Madness" than the movie that claims to be it by putting together all the wild
fantasies about the different universes the filmakers have in mind while developing the script only to tell us that maybe, just maybe, the ordinary and mediocre life we have right now is the best one we can ask for out of the infinite multitude of choices we could have made, be thankful with what we
already have right now, accept what and who our loved ones are along with their flaws. Thought it wouldn't be as simple as that in real life, taking the
first step to improve our lifes will always be the best direction anyone can move towards.8.5/10.

Well, that was a lot. I guess I shouldn't be surprised considering the title. That being said, it seems odd to critique a film for having too much going on when that's kind of the point, but I'm gonna do it anyway. There's a lot of fun, entertaining, and even emotionally resonant stuff going on, but there's also too much going on to allow the kind of focus on any one thing to have the kind of impact this could have had. Is it about mothers and daughters? Finding connection in the world? Finding meaning through other people? It's all of these things, but emotional resonance happens when attaching these ideas to characters and their stories in a specific way to actually let the ideas flow through them while giving us the emotional connection to the characters going through it, adding intellectual depth to something that pulls at the heart strings. Having roughly five different variations on the same idea compete for attention undermines them all.Okay, enough complaining for now, because while I do think the film needed a good bit of cutting down, there's so much to enjoy.Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) is the co-owner of a little laundry in Los Angeles with her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan). They have one daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu), who has a girlfriend Becky (Tallie Medel), a situation that they are trying to hide from Evelyn's father, Gong Gong (James Hong), visiting from Hong Kong. Evelyn's life is a mess. The laundry is failing and in massive tax problems. She has this propensity of picking up new hobbies and then filing the expenses as tax deductions. The strain of the whole situation has led Waymond to gathering the paperwork for a divorce that she's too busy to even notice. There are regrets that she has made the wrong choices in life to lead her to that moment.They have an appointment with Deirdre (Jamie Lee Curtis), a tax auditor at the IRS building, but as they go up the elevator, Waymond suddenly removes his glasses, starts speaking differently and with more confidence, while scribbling out random instructions for her to follow (including putting her shoes on the wrong feet). Sitting there with the auditor figuring out the sad, pathetic story of their lives through their receipts, Evelyn figures that there's nothing to lose, so she tries it, and she's suddenly in something much, much larger than a tax audit of her laundry. Alpha Waymond, the form of her husband from an alternate universe, has reached out to her because she is the one version of Evelyn that will become powerful enough to defeat Jobu Tupaki, an incredibly powerful being that has been moving from universe to universe killing Evelyn's all along the way.The painting of the portrait of Evelyn's life is wonderfully (and perhaps overly) detailed, providing us with a very clear picture of the miserable little life she leads. It becomes ironically funny when we find out that she is literally the most pathetic form of herself across the entire multiverse, failing at literally everything, which, in handwaving logic, means that she has the capacity to become the greatest version of Evelyn to face off against Jobu. Her discovery of the multiverse is both fun and frustrating. Fun because the rules established are so consciously absurd (doing something completely random and out of character slingshots your consciousness in the right direction of another version of yourself that you then tap into in order to gain some kind of skill that you don't already have like, say, the mastery of kung fu), but frustrating because there is a lot to explain. It's not just the rules, but also the central conflict which gets treated opaquely for a while until the movie just gives up and lets you know a couple of moments later.Jobu Tupaki is another version of Joy from the Alpha universe where Evelyn was one of the great scientists and discovered how to communicate with other universes. She pushed Joy to the breaking point where she became able to jump between universes without the aid of technology like everyone else, and there's been a race to find the right Evelyn ever since. What Joy actually wants with Evelyn is never as clear as it should be, I think. What she wants overall, though, is just the logical application of nihilism: she wants to commit suicide. This gets manifested in another of the movie's intentional oddities, a cosmic everything bagel that will consume Jobu and erase her existence.The second half of the film is Evelyn slowly growing in power and also becoming more like Jobu herself. There are a lot of fights as Alpha Waymond works with Evelyn to try and keep her safe. She ends up at war with herself, mostly manifested with her desire to lose herself in a reality where she is a big movie star, but it also happens to be a reality where she never left Hong Kong with Waymond. So much time is spent on this that one would imagine that this is the central conceit of the film, but the antagonist is a version of Joy. So, this is about her connecting with her family, right? I could buy that, but then there's Deirdre. A surprising amount of time in the lead up to the finale is about connecting with Deirdre, mostly in a universe where people have hot dog fingers (an idea alternatively funny and really gross) and connecting with her. So, it's about relationships being what's really worthwhile? That makes sense, but this is where we're getting really diffuse. Oh, and then there's the Ratatouille parody called Raccacoonie where Evelyn works in a hibachi grill with a great chef who's hiding a Raccoon under his toque. I mean, it's funny, but it just goes to show how overstuffed this film is.Why does that matter if it's funny? That it's funny is what saves it from being a drag at all, and it's obvious that most audiences feel like that's enough. I just get frustrated when there's obviously a point and the film can't get to it. In fact, it throws everything out of focus when there is a point and the film intentionally obfuscates it. Does that make it a bad film? Not at all. The movie is so filled with attempts to entertain and an eagerness to as well, that I can only hold this narrative frustration against the film so much. Still, it's there.So, I've complained enough. I really do like this film. It may be overlong and overstuffed, but it's fun from beginning to end. Its colorful, light, and energetic approach to its concept overcomes a lot, especially when combined with the quality action choreography. Both Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan's talents are on full display as they fight their way all around the large IRS building set. Quan's early fight with nothing but his fanny pack is a real highlight. It should also be noted that virtually the entirety of the film (I'd estimate about 90%) takes place on two sets (the laundry and the IRS building), while never feeling constrained. Finding new places to film within the sets while messing with lighting help really give the small-budgeted film a much larger sense of scale than expected.Yeoh carries the entire film on her back, and she is the film's foundation. She gives Evelyn in every reality a sense of life from her lived-in exhaustion early through to her bewilderment at discovering the larger universe around her to even her take as herself at a film screening, she's imbues the whole film with emotional truth. Quan reveals himself to be far more than Short Round or Data several decades later, easily alternating between versions of Waymond, one weak and wounded the other eager, smart, and proactive. Hsu as Joy is solid, and it's always a joy to see James Hong, especially while decked out in a mech-suit made from office equipment.It's really not hard to see why Daniel Kwan's and Daniel Scheinert's creation captured the imaginations of so many people. It is Joseph Campbell's basic hero journey given a crazy, unique skin. At its core, it tells the kind of hero myth we've been telling each other for millennia told well, with energy, and uniquely. That it's overlong and overstuffed doesn't seem to bother most people. It just bothers me a little bit is all.

Matrix meets kung fu husstle in the multiverse. Nothing was outstanding in the movie. I got the Jokes but wasn't actualy funny for me. The humor in the flight scenes wasn't for me allthough that was probably the best scene in the movie. The title is correct but another title could be one big mess in the multiverse. Maybe i missed something. The actors did a good job because i do think this was the idea of the movie . So If you like a big mess the actors will not dissapoint. Looking at the other reviews either you like it or you hate it. Good luck If you want to watch. If you don't you will never know.

This movie is terrible and weird. I hated the characters and performances. All around artsy garbage designed to push the approved Hollywood agendas. Cinematography was interesting and shots were interesting but overall the story was so corny and riddled with cliche and common tropes.

Did this movie deserve to be the phenomenon that it became? I would say it did, because of how much the filmmakers clearly put into it. You won't get any good reasons as to why this movie is special in the first few scenes, and even when things begin to unfold, it's still not entirely clear why so many have responded so strongly to it. Over the course of the runtime, however, you are bombarded with an endless series of unusual, unique moments that just keep coming, right through to the end. Just when you think this movie has gotten so off-the-wall that they can't possibly throw anything else that unexpected at you, they do. The main drawback is that during the final third of the movie, we get too many drawn-out, overly sentimental moments of reflection that really needed to be trimmed down to be effective. It gets a bit repetitive, to the point that I am hesitant to re-watch the film, even though there is so much to like. I still have to praise it, however--there haven't been very many movies that have gotten as bat-s%#$ crazy as EEAAO.

reviews.review_title: Sentimental psychodelia: powerful but partially ruined.
reviews.content: It has to be said that, for all its originality, it's still the same three-act movie Hollywood has been making for decades, the only one they'll ever make, this time spiced up with sentimental chinese psychedelia. A24 is still part of the industry. But, for a moment, it really is fresh, fast and fun. Michelle Yeoh is a star, the action is great and there's one of the funniest scenes I've ever witnessed on a screen.Some very strong film-making. However, at one point, the film disintegrates. First, it struggles with the task of actually explaining what's going on, and suffers from it. Next, it struggles to maintain an ever-increasing momentum, throwing at the viewer, well, everything all at once. Like making a cocktail with everything at the bar, nothing sticks, it becomes something on your screen for a period of time (sorry). And yet, some occurrences, such as the raccoon, are still absolutely irresistible.My main issue is in the end it shifts priorities, it becomes worried about being taken seriously as a thoughtful piece of drama with pseudo-philosophical musings. That hurts the film immensely. I was disappointed, checking my watch, wondering why this movie suddenly was trying to over-explain basic human emotions. I guess a big part of the audience needs to be reminded of what makes them human. I'm ok with it, though, I'm not going to complain about a possitive message, the problem is there is so much noise the emotional climax is non-existent, or maybe I was numb.Of course, as expected, there is a subtext of criticism of the Chinese family, supposedly severe, diligent and demanding, contrasted with the permissiveness, communication and affection of the "new" American family. The daughter is eventually the one being right, conveniently English-speaking.It will undoubtedly be one of the most powerful films to come out of USA in a few years, it's got everything to please today's film fauna. I enjoyed the first half greatly and I personally hope it soon establishes itself as the best multiverse film because that would mean no more are made.

reviews.review_title: Of all the many worlds...I'm glad I live in one where this exists
reviews.content: If there was ever a film with a fitting title...this is it, alright.So much so that I think this might be the single most creative film I've ever seen, and almost certainly the craziest genre mashup I've ever seen. It's a sci-fi, it's a kung fu movie, it's an absurd comedy, and it's a family drama. It is, quite literally, "everything, everywhere, all at once".It's the best Matrix film since the first one, it's got a beautiful anti-nihilist message, it's an exploration of Asian-American identity and generational homophobia, I laughed, I cried, and it's that rare kind of film that just makes the world look a little better to you once it's over.I realised when I rewatched The World's End that I'm always more impressed by a film that's doing so much stuff that should not work together on paper, and this is like Daniels took that idea as a challenge. Can we make a film that's like Rick And Morty, Police Story, The Matrix, Inside Out and Monty Python And The Holy Grail all had a massive orgy and produced a baby that should be a mangled heap of organs because of how much none of those things should work together, and yet it goes on to win Mr Universe (and hopefully more than a few Oscars too, unless they decide it's too interesting for them like they probably will.)And as if all that wasn't enough, the performances are all incredible, the narrative is somehow tight and consistent to no end, the directing, editing and cinematography are gorgeous, the dialogue is hilarious, the characters are all extremely interesting...really the only thing I could possibly complain about if I had to is that the beginning is a little slow.It definitely does all need to be there to set up later events in the film, but I did find myself wondering where it was all going and wishing it would get a bit more unique - which, well...needless to say that wish was fulfilled in absolute spades. Maybe the next time I watch it that'll be more entertaining now that I'll be expecting it, who knows.But even if that remains an issue for me, I couldn't possibly call this anything other than a masterpiece for the sheer amount of stuff it's doing all at the same time and doing it all so well and perfectly balanced.Well okay, I will also call it a work of sheer sodding genius. But I'm done now, I swear.

reviews.review_title: What the f is this rubbish?
reviews.content: Honestly this is the worst movie I have ever watched for a long time, couldn't bare any longer than 45 mins. I can understand why Jackie Chan was originally supposed to be the main character but he didn't act in this movie.It's a disgrace to the movie industry and to Asian community as well...

reviews.review_title: Please, please, please!!! Watch this movie
reviews.content: I can't encourage people enough to give this film a chance. I've laughed and cried equally. It's warmed my heart. This is truly a work of art. I'm watching it again.

I can't really explain what I just watched. It started like Matrix on steroids. Goes on to what Dr Stange and the multiverse could have been. And ends up as a heartfelt movie. 3 movies in one, that don't always make sense, it took me a bit to get into the story because I didn't understand it. And then, it clicked. And all the beginning that was a bit blurry became clear. This is a good movie, what I want to see in the cinema, something with a diverse family, people actually speaking other languages because they come from other countries. Different cultures. All mixed within a terribly clever story, with great visuals. I loved it, and will probably watch it again, now that I have the key that was missing.
