I thought it would never end. It took 20 minutes into the movie to announce part one; in another century or two they announced part two; then they had a pretend ending followed by part three.
I get it. I understand about the ricocheting consequences of choices made early in our lives.  I understand not being able to cope with the fact that every choice is a trade-off of good and bad. I understand reconciling a mundane life in valid existence of family and loved ones. I even understand the rest of the banal universal themes. But why do I have to go through torture to hear someone make these points? Afull third of the movie is fake kung fu fighting with unrealistic consequences. I'm sure there's lots of 13 year-old boys who love this stuff. But why put sentient adults through this?

It starts with a family mirror.
...and then we see an agitated Evelyn, a broken mirror, a multiverse of different fragments of herself.
An App gives Evelyn access to skilful versions of herself to deal with a disturbance in her fragmented world, and still, Evelyn decides to remain an unskilled, but better-resolved, loving mother.
We all left some goals or better versions of ourselves behind, and in a certain way, all the goals can be seen as futile achievements compared with the infinitude of outer space.
In the end, Evelyn is less frantic, all at once, enjoying the small miracles.
Mitski & David Byrne offer the final balm - "This is a Life".

Hats off to Michelle Yeoh for her complex portrayal of Evelyn and kick-butt action sequences. Ke Huy Quan gives a delightful and surprising performance as her husband. I really loved this movie.

I just came here to say that this was an interesting movie and it deserves credit for it's uniqueness but I'm not seeing why it cleaned up at the Oscars. Furthermore, it is absolutely blasphemous that Jamie Lee Curtis could win best supporting actress over Angela Bassett. Yes, Jamie Lee Curtis's role was very diverse in Everything Everywhere All At Once, but it certainly did not deserve recognition over Angela bassett's performance and Wakanda Forever. More credit should have been done to the costume and makeup team for Jamie Lee Curtis's character. It was not emotional, it was not groundbreaking, it was not moving, and you would barely know she was in it because it was such an insignificant role as far as impact is concerned. On the other hand, Angela bassett's performance was emotional, it was heartfelt, it was strong, it was passionate, it was memorable, and she was absolutely snubbed. The academy should be ashamed of themselves because this choice seemed more of a racially biased move or political move, I can't put my finger on it but they definitely got that one wrong and missed an opportunity to give a premiere actress her flowers while she's still with us. I noticed that there's been criticism of the movie Wakanda Forever as there are many people in the United States, and across the world, that have a hard time grasping the idea of an elite African nation, on top of the food chain that, couple with the fact that the movie highlights some injustices on behalf of the white man. I get it, but let's take off our blinders and be real. Conversely, EEAAO is receiving positivity biased kudos due to the industry's recent infatuation with Asian inclusivity. And don't get me wrong, the actors in this movie are absolutely phenomenal and this is nothing against them, this is against the academy, this is against the biased critics. Yes, the movie is different and refreshing but that does not make it a better movie than some of its competing films.

Another Kung Fu movie dressed up as something "meaningful." A lot of razz ma tazz and little substance. A write up says it was about how one's life could be different if different choices were made? There is a story for everyone within this movie if you pay attention to what it's telling you and watch it with your heart.  One of the best movies I have ever seen.

Are you kidding me?  Replete with stereotypes.  Love conquers all and permeates, flows in all different planes of existence.  A bagel as a gateway into time and dimensions.  Passive or aggressive personalities in fighting moods, but no middle ground.  Violence as silliness.  An Asian Laundry thrown in for good measure, as well as an accented IRS Inspector talking about her personal divorce with the laundry manager she tried to forcefully evict five minutes prior.  Martial arts thrown in because this is a movie with Asian stars.  Oh my!!!  You either agree or not.  Divergent viewpoints, polarizing movie.  The BEST picture of the year???  At the level of the 2019 movie PARASITE??  Please!!!

If art in its purest form is our effort to explore and understand ourselves, this mind-boggling and beautiful film creates a new standard for how to approach that effort.

I think the acting was phenomenal, and that the general storyline held a lot of promise and significance.  I believe they chose a heroine and a storyline in general which provided a lot of social commentary about modern American life, and the overwhelming nature of our capitalist culture and how it punishes minorities the most.  

Unfortunately, the film seems to lack an articulated or properly-maintained plot at points, and tries to juggle way too many different themes and directions at the same time to be comprehensible.  I was very frustrated by how often the plot took off ramps onto another theme or action scene, without fully developing and explaining what was going on (descriptively or symbolically) in the previous scenes.  I'm guessing this may have something to do with the average American's ever decreasing attention span and critical thinking skills, which seems to have negatively influenced Hollywood film directing over the years.  Regardless of the real reason behind these directing decisions, it made it very difficult to absorb the material at times.

I was also disappointed with the character development of Jobu Tupaki/Joy.  I never felt the audience got sufficient explanation or context behind /why/ she was so suicidal and hostile toward her mother, beyond some superficial information detailing typical parent/ teen child antagonism, or the story of split personalities due to too much multiverse switching.  Someone who is going through complex suffering and struggles to develop into that character deserves a comprehensive backstory and contextual interpretation.  Perhaps some of the explanations for her pain lie in inter-generational conflicts within Chinese American families, in which case that explanation may have been lost in cultural translation.  But I also think aspects of her backstory and character may have also just been poorly written.

Also, there are far too many kink and BDSM material to make me feel comfortable. Unless these BDSM scenes were poorly-developed attempts at satire, the film seemed to otherwise be promoting a culture that for many people is often one of out-of-control consumerism, exploitation, and abuse.  I get it, adding this material gives the illusion of adding prestige, exoticism, or 'intricacy' to a film.  That's often the effect BDSM references have on general audiences, since that culture is taken at face value as a 'rebellion against normalcy'.  Introducing BDSM themes out of context also has some kind of shock and awe effect, and can be injected in content that may not otherwise be sufficiently thought provoking.  But that's just it, the real value of this material is illusive, and putting motifs of kinky practices in film to substitute more powerful messages or ideas can't fool everyone.  That's not including how gross and disturbing a lot of the kink content was to begin with.

An incredible film blending genres and cultures into an enjoyable and heart-felt experience. EEAAO perfectly captures the struggles of most first-gen Asian-American families. The heavy expectations set on the son or daughter, the constant need for success while ignoring the people surrounding them, and the perpetual financial struggles. However, this film speaks not only to the Asian diaspora but for everyone. Sometimes we question why do this or that, and we spiral into some sort of nihilistic view of the world. Not every choice has to be perfect or meaningful leading to a cascade of successes. In the end, the millions of possibilities you denied for one that you thought mattered, that's pretty beautiful and significant.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" is an outstanding movie that takes the audience on a mesmerizing journey through multiple dimensions, blurring the lines between reality and fantasy. The film showcases a brilliant and diverse cast, who all deliver powerful performances that leave a lasting impact on the audience.

The film's visual effects are stunning, seamlessly blending the real world with the imaginary realms, and immersing the viewer in a unique and captivating cinematic experience. The storyline is intricate yet accessible, weaving together multiple themes such as love, loss, and self-discovery, that are universally relatable and emotionally resonant.

The film's score is equally impressive, with a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that adds an extra layer of depth and emotion to each scene. The direction and cinematography are also top-notch, masterfully capturing the film's complex narrative in a visually stunning and cohesive way.

Overall, "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is a must-see movie that is sure to delight audiences of all ages and backgrounds. Its rich characters, stunning visuals, and powerful storytelling are a true testament to the talent and creativity of its filmmakers. It is no surprise that the film has won all the Oscars, and it is a well-deserved honor.

An absolutely crazy brilliant MASTERPIECE! Every once in awhile you stumble across something that just… fades everything else around you away… and you stare transfixed, knowing at that moment you are watching something truly special. 

NOTE: This movie is not for everyone. It definitely isn't an ordinary movie. It is more of an indy that focuses on pushing the creative envelope and dares to be strange, if not straight-up absurd at times. Personally, I love movies that are unusual. So this… was right up my alley. 

It was dramatic, confusing, funny as all hell, deeply philosophical, action packed, surrealist, eye-popping, pure wtf crazy, that literally had me laughing my ass off at one moment and then crying like a big baby man later. 

If I had to sum this movie up… in just one word… it would be "beautiful". 

We are all such a mess dealing with a world that is such a mess, but being a mess is… "beautiful". 

Probably one of the most poignant movies I've ever seen. And it had people with hot dog fingers, a guy with a raccoon on his head, fight scenes using butt plugs, and long long silent scenes with rocks with googly eyes that moved me to tears. 

A true piece of art that just got me. 

2 huge hot dog thumbs up!

I hope this opens up opportunities for film makers to be able to delve more confidently into the "weird but wonderful" genre.

This movie seems to be like marmite with the audience - so many 5 star reviews followed by 1 star reviews. For me, it's a masterpiece and it quickly became my favourite movie of all time! I don't like the fact that everything nowadays is either a sequel/prequel/remake. It's like people are running out of ideas! But not with this movie - it was the most unique movie I can remember watching. It had everything: humour, sci-fi, action, martial arts and so much raw emotion. The emotion was so strong that I cried one minute and was belly laughing the next. At one point I didn't know if my tears were from laughing or feeling emotional. All thanks to the incredible acting and brilliant script! It must be so difficult for the actors to do comedy acting one minute and then pour so much emotion into the role the next, not to mention all of the action scenes. I appreciate some won't get it, for me and my easily bored ADHD brain it was absolutely perfect! I wonder if the ones that walked out did so when the movie pretended to end! I've watched it three times and could watch it many more. You always see something different the next time you see it. I'm so glad something so unique has won so many awards, and I was rooting for them all during the whole awards season and so happy with the Oscars wins. Although I would say Stephanie Hsu should have got best supporting actress at the Oscar's over Jamie Lee (even though she was excellent too). I hope there's more unique movies like this in the future rather than another remake!!

I love symbolism, metaphors and deep storylines, even whimsical, but EEAAO throws all of this at the audience in such quantity and force as to try to shock your system and force you to conclude it's the best movie ever. Not even close. Contrived, nearly 20 minutes too long(I was begging for the end once I knew exactly what was gonna happen). At the end of the day it's a glorified "Mom doesn't understand her family and wants a better life" movie. The storyline with the husband was good, the acting was amazing, but it was pretty easy to see from the beginning that we were working towards acceptance of the daughter's partner. Also the rock metaphor didn't track cause she lets her fall off the cliff and then  when she's convincing her to stay she falls off the cliff after her? Didn't really make sense. At the end of the day though this movie's composition rings true to its' message: Nothing really matters. Yeah thanks that's what I needed 😂

If you look on a different movie reviewing website, one like Letterboxd, you will see reviews from people who actually understood the meaning of the movie. I just want to make sure that everyone knows, just because you didn't personally understand the meaning of the movie, doesn't mean it doesn't deserve the awards.

I saw this movie shortly after it first came out, not knowing much at all about it and absolutely loved it.  Partly, at its core it is a story about an immigrant family and their relationships and as the daughter of an immigrant mother a lot of the issues beneath all the crazy multiverse scenes were familiar and heartfelt.  Partly it is about nihilism vs love/kindness/connection which for me was another relatable piece.  And partly I was impressed at the overall creativity, acting and humor.  It was not like most films nowadays that are all focused on action or gratuitous violence or predictable tropes.  Yes, the pace was a bit manic at first and took me a bit to fully get where they were heading but I left the theater deeply moved.  I saw it a second time recently, now knowing the plot (and the hype) and it didn't land quite as strongly, but I noticed a lot more fun bits that I missed the first time and I remain impressed at the creativity and basic heart/feeling the film has.

This masterpiece is all about everything happening everywhere, just like the title. And I assure you that you will feel the same way as I do when you watch it. So there will be a question about what is even "everything" to start with. Everything is about your life and those people who you are surrounded with. This movie may be fictional by the inclusion of a multiverse but the depiction of underlying philosophical meaning about the realistic view of family issues, life choices, and all the possibilities we could create from small insignificant decisions in our daily lives reflect and wonder about our lives a lot. The whole plot itself takes place in the multiverse which might be something confusing when people who are unfamiliar with the concept hear that but surprisingly it is very simple to comprehend the whole plot. 

It will give you a tremendous amount of different emotions, some of them which you might not have even experienced before. At least, it was that way for me. Many types of comedy also take place in the plot frequently and all of them are fantastic and in perfect timing. Despite having so many funny and ridiculous scenes, the plot itself is very serious to the point everyone can relate to either characters or situations in their lives such as the scenes when the movie depicted the young couple making "wrong" choices in this universe, the parenthood focusing on both the perspective of the wife (Evelyn)  and the husband (Waymond), their teenage daughter (Joy)'s problems concerning her life choices being unaccepted by her mother, ruined and shattered hopes from a young couple,  their business situations, the typical dead romance between the long-married couple (especially Asian couples), and many other characters' plots and viewpoints.


There are no villains in this movie. At the first glance, you might probably think (as it is stereotyped) of the mysterious character who seems to have bad intentions toward the universe, Jobu Tupaki (Joy) as the villainess. But if you can truly apprehend the way she becomes who she is, her actions are not justifiable but are understandable. Then, her mother would be the one you would want to blame for making Joy the way she is. But turns out, that is also not the case as everyone always wants the best for themselves or their loved ones. Her mother's action is also understandable but not justifiable. So in short, either her father, her grandfather and his organization, her mother, herself and everyone and every version of them in different universes cannot be blamed as it is going in a circle, and not one person can be blamed for one exact cause. 

Last of all, "Nothing matters", the main concept of this movie. This line mentioned by Jobu Tupaki(Joy) is a very simple yet powerful line for everyone everywhere it also shows her belief in one of the most famous philosophical branches called Nihilism. She tried to end the whole multiverse and universes by sucking everything into the giant bagel with her superpowers because nothing really matters to her anymore. But the fact that she wanted to end it together with her mother from the far multiverse shows that someone still matters to her and if we think carefully about Joy, she is doing all these things because of the concept of "nothing matters" matters to her. And yes it actually feels nice to think that way because if nothing matters, all the pain and guilt we feel from nothing of our lives go away as it is stated by Jobu Tupaki. But on the contrary and concluding from the ending and Evelyn's fighting scene against her daughter to stop her from going into the bagel, we can say that because nothing really matters, it is our choice to decide what and who matters in our daily lives and give and try our best for them no matter whatever the hardship we may face. I think that everyone should watch this movie at least once in their lifetime. You will get an unbelievably amazing experience and feeling in the duration of these 2 hours.

I'm going to be blunt: This movie is like a bright speckled donut injected with some super stale bland bread and with a hollow core.

We get it. It's a story about a mother of a depressed, anxious suicidal young adult, but the treatment is so shallow that if you try to dive in you'll break something. 

Daughter: The writers never really get into the daughter and present her as a flapping conundrum for the mother. The writers see fit to laminate a layer of gay in the daughter as if somehow that helps support the daughter's feelings (offensive meter is ticking), but never really delve into the experience of being gay and they never show a moment of gayness in the film, they just slap a label on her, make her hold a girl's hand and the job is done. Instead they focus on presenting the daughter as a writhing ball of whimsical existential angst - and that's it.

On to the mother: Just a trope of a character. Maternal angst meets bored middle aged woman stuck in a rut. Yay.

Their relationship: They don't have one. It's just two shallow characters, one pulling away and the other trying to cling on, "SAVE" the other from themselves and neither really understanding the other. Hot tip for the writers: without you guys writing these characters as more than a window shop painting, you can't write true connection between them. How do you display human understanding between two characters if there's nothing for the audience to understand either?

The rest of the movie was shiny and silly. 

The shine: The shine was pretty. Lots of pretty things. They were shiny. They were well done. I liked them! But you can't watch 2:20 of shiny things alone… well I cant. Gummies aren't legal where I live.

The silly: The kind of silly people who wear Depends appreciate, but for everyone else it's like trying to share a meal with the same person after they've taken their evening Xanax.

A smart, funny, action packed, and simultaneously sincere film that is incredibly fresh. While definitely a strange concept, it uses the multiverse setup to discuss difficult concepts such as nihilism with an incredibly honest and well thought touch while maintaining its wacky antics. Great acting from all involved especially Michelle Yeah (Evelyn), Ke Huy Quan (Waymond), Jamie Lee Curtis (Deirdre) and Stephanie Hsu (Joy), the first three of which won oscars for their performance at the 95th academy awards. despite the complex storyline the film is easy to follow and understandable. This credits the co-directors, Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert ("the Daniels"), winning the academy award for best screenplay and best director. The film was nominated for 11 oscars going into the ceremony and came out with 7 of them, including best actress in a leading role (Michelle Yeah), best actress in a supporting role (Jamie Lee Curtis), best actor in supporting role (Ke Huy Quan), directing (The Daniels) and best picture.

When I first watched Everything Everywhere All at Once, I thought it was one of the best movies I've ever seen. But after rewatching it after some time, I am convinced that it is the best form of any storytelling I have ever come across.When I first watched Everything Everywhere All at Once, I thought it was one of the best movies I've ever seen. But after rewatching it after some time, I am convinced that it is the best form of any storytelling I have ever come across. Granted, I haven't watched, read or played every movie/show/play, book or game ever created in the many languages that exist. But of the significant portion of my life I have spent experiencing stories and my subjective & biased parameters for what an exceptional form of storytelling should ideally be based on, I am certain that this movie is the best I've come across yet.Why do I think that?Because it combines the most investigated philosophical question of the purpose of life, the most complex metaphysical theory of multiverses and the most consistently prevalent emotions of hope & despair, all together, in 150 minutes that span almost every storytelling genre there is.And it does this with a series of truly extraordinary & powerful acting performances, elegantly simple yet extremely compelling dialogues, absurdist yet coherent editing & transitions and one of the most narratively complementary cinematography ever.Furthermore, the exceptionally intelligent use of various styles of humour, balanced with a metaphorical yet deeply compassionate use of relationships, to construct a narrative that - though may appear comically-absurd & entertaining on a casual first-watch - is actually so much more; being consistently deliberate, methodical & profound on a second viewing.All this coalesces into a unique emotional journey - with an abundance of excellent humour - that inevitably transitions to a rollercoaster ride of hope crescendos & despair diminuendos, while offering convincing justifications for these ebbs and flows, concluding in an extremely cathartic & appropriate ending.Everything Everywhere All at Once - as the title suggests - is truly a story about everything, everywhere, told all at once. It's the most conclusive story of existence. And as cliched and inaccurate its ultimate moral may seem, it ingeniously conveys it in the single most hopeful & captivating manner possible.And that's why it is the best form of any storytelling I have ever come across.

I started watching it and I had to stop watching it in the middle of the duration because of how incredibly stupid and meaningless the movie seemed to me, with effort I finished watching it later. As a comedy it fails, its humor is veryI started watching it and I had to stop watching it in the middle of the duration because of how incredibly stupid and meaningless the movie seemed to me, with effort I finished watching it later. As a comedy it fails, its humor is very childish and ridiculous, there are comedy movies from the time of our grandparents whose humor still seems funny to us today, the humor of this movie is almost purely visual by showing ridiculous fights or characters dressed in ridiculous to say an example. As a science fiction genre, it also fails, despite the fact that the genre is fantasy, in general, the universe that we are presented with has consistency, it is credible, it has logic and if there are elements that are not very credible, they end up being few or scarce. The science fiction of this movie is so silly, so unbelievable that I can't really immerse myself in it. The story and relationship between the mother and her daughter, and how it develops, doesn't seem bad to me, but the other elements that I mentioned before are like ruining the experience of the movie itself. The film is new, I don't know if you could even talk about a new genre because of how incredibly chaotic it is, but even so, the stupidity of the plot, the stupidity of its universe, the bad humor, the nonsense of how several of the events take place that make me unable to recommend it and rate it negatively.

Some critics say the art of cinema is saturated with superheroes and stories that don't bring anything useful to the audience. That they don't challenge them, and they're not inventive enough. But when they break out of the mould, theySome critics say the art of cinema is saturated with superheroes and stories that don't bring anything useful to the audience. That they don't challenge them, and they're not inventive enough. But when they break out of the mould, they dismiss them as too ambitious and complicated for those same audiences.So what the hell are we doing? Or are they telling the crowd they're too dumb?And I comment on this because one of the many things I've heard about this film is that it would be too much for the average audience, but that's not the case at all.Everything Everywhere All at Once is perhaps a film that pushes its concept a bit too far, but that doesn't make it any less appealing. Because as far as I could tell, once its plot explodes, the chaos of everything it presents is the cornerstone of the story, and therefore you must embrace that chaos.The irony of it all is that in the end it's actually a pretty ordinary story.Yes, of course, it is still an emotional, philosophical and profound journey through a complex narrative device such as the multiverse, but the underlying idea is still a story in which its protagonist must confront and question everything about her life. From her family to the decisions and failures that have brought her to the point where she finds herself when it all begins.Perhaps the teaching addressed in its conclusion is nothing earth-shattering, but the journey to reach it was thoroughly entertaining, chaotic and exhilarating, and that was something really, really good.And above all, what a great performance by Michelle Yeoh. She is the absolute captain of this film. Her co-stars do a great job too, but this is her show.

Creative, thought-provoking, fun, and original: a blend of all of those aspects is rare in modern cinema, yet Everything Everywhere All at Once manages to be all of those things and more. The acting and cinematography are top notch, theCreative, thought-provoking, fun, and original: a blend of all of those aspects is rare in modern cinema, yet Everything Everywhere All at Once manages to be all of those things and more. The acting and cinematography are top notch, the multiverse story is insanely innovative and wacky, and the writing is so perfectly done and impactful. Furthermore, while the comedy comes rapid-fire at points and lands almost every time, the film takes its time for slower, more introspective scenes that leave one wondering about how their multiversal selves are and how we can make the most of this life we have here, even if it may not be as impressive as we hoped. This is a must watch film, and, as of now, my favorite of 2022 without question.

I have never seen a movie like this. It is filled to the brim with ideas some being absolute crazy in the positive way, has great humor, a near perfect cast and fights that made the older Jackie Chan movies jealous. A wild and crazy ride thatI have never seen a movie like this. It is filled to the brim with ideas some being absolute crazy in the positive way, has great humor, a near perfect cast and fights that made the older Jackie Chan movies jealous. A wild and crazy ride that was more enjoyable than almost any other movie I have seen in years. The story starts with the worst day Chinese immigrant Evelyn Wang could imagine. Her laundromat business she had with her husband is investigated by the internal revenue service (IRS), her husband wants a divorce, her lesbian daughter wants her family to accept her white girlfriend while her estranged and traditional father just arrived while they prepare for the new year celebration. Things take a sudden change when in the elevator of the IRS building her husband completely changes personality. He says a multiverse exists and he is from a different universe / reality. The whole multiverse is in danger and Evelyn is their hope to stop the catastrophe. I stop here to avoid spoilers. The story is amazingly well written. It has so many ideas, craziness, humor and highlights. No movie I remember in recent years could compete. We think drugs were involved for a lot of ideas but everything works excellent which is the prove for the quality of writing. Think about it. If done poorly this would be a laughing stock of a story and movie. So I have to praise all writers, directors, producers and the whole team behind the camera. The actors were equally amazing and I think it is a close to a perfect cast as it could be. Michelle Yeoh is Oscar worthy and I am deeply impressed by her performance. Stephanie Hsu, Kee Huy Quan, Jamie Lee Curtis,  James Hong and Tallie Medel are all excellent and improve the movie. Then there is the humor. I laughed a lot and cant remember the last movie that was as great for the humor. The fight scenes are amazing and some put Jackie Chan to shame. Lastly I must praise the sets, costumes and CGI. They nailed the movies atmosphere and style with those. Overall this is a masterpieces and truly unique. It was so good that future movies will be rated against this for me. A strong and worthy 10/10.

This is a pretty frantic, colourful, somewhat madcap film, with some scenes featuring almost Matrix style choreography and the plot and pacing making me think of something like a constant neon coloured pinball machine, with the ball pingingThis is a pretty frantic, colourful, somewhat madcap film, with some scenes featuring almost Matrix style choreography and the plot and pacing making me think of something like a constant neon coloured pinball machine, with the ball pinging about from one corner to the next. I liked that its set in such a domestic, dare I say particularly boring setting as an IRS office. The visual effects are great - I liked the cartoon strip feel to some effects in particular (I won't elaborate so as not to provide potential spoilers). I found it difficult to follow all the plot details but I certainly wouldn't say that affected my enjoyment of the film overall. Watching the fast paced fight scenes reminded me a little of kung fu or samurai films of the 1970s. At times Chinese songs are played in the background and it was nice to see the various family members speaking in their (I assume) mother tongue. As over the top as it undoubtedly is for the most part, there is a point in which things slow down significantly - that is somewhat poignant. I should perhaps note that a fair amount of the dialogue is in either Mandarin or Cantonese, hence subtitles are often present, which may or may not put you off it. Its a very engrossing and yet also somewhat baffling film, with a quirky, arty feel to it to an extent but enough mainstream CGI to entertain the audience well, I reckon. It's definitely a film to re-watch, as I was left thinking 'what did I just see?' by the end.Needless to say, I would definitely recommend this film, yes.

This movie skillfully utilises symbolism and humour to1 month ago This movie is truly an immersive experience where you follow the main character Evelyn played by an excellent Michelle Yeoh through the multiverse to defeat an unknown force. This movie skillfully utilises symbolism and humour to address themes of nihilism, sacrifice, depression and intergenerational trauma. Uniquely, this film could also be titled Truly All Genres All At Once as it incorporates comedy, drama and action into its core identify as a sci-fi film. There is bound to be many laugh out loud moment as well as many moments of introspections which makes it a cognitive experience as well. Adding to a mind blowing plot, is the artful directing, sound score and costume design which adds vibrancy to the message being conveyed. This aspect of the film truly makes it a sensory experience. Your brain will undoubtedly be stimulated. Overall verdict: a cinematic experience once must experience in the cinemas. This will undoubtedly one of the front runners for Best Picture.

An angry lesbian girl whose conflicted mother doesn't want to accept her girlfriend creates a bagel of despair that turns into a black hole, threatening to destroy countless parallel universes. I cannot understand how this was widely proclaimed one of the best movies of 2022. This movie is a pretentious mess that only professional movie critics would like. The editing can induce an epileptic fit, the story paper thin. The humor is crass and childish - there's a parallel universe where people have hot dogs for fingers. There's a scene where two men kung fu fight with butt plugs. Not hitting each other with butt plugs, no they fight with butt plugs inside them. In their butts. That is how you make the "movie of 2022", folks.According to the Wikipedia synopsis this movies handles themes like existentialism, generational trauma, nihilism, absurdism, and Asian-American identity, and I say with great confidence that I didn't see anything of the sort. Sure, it pretends to, with pretentious hand waving and preachy yelling, but there is nothing you can take away and apply to your own life. What this movie does have though is a talking raccoon, under a chef's hat.
What a mess.  So overrated.  Are we so desperate for new ideas that we fawn over anything different?

My criticism of the film has nothing to do with the directing or the acting but more so to do about the story and how difficult I found it was to get into. To me, It was a really out-there, bonkers movie that just didn't work.

“Morbius”?  Never heard of it!  “Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore”?  Literally who?!  Man, stop paying attention to all this mainstream, normie-ass hoopty-doopty-ass rubbish, and go watch a quality movie.  I am, of course,“Morbius”?  Never heard of it!  “Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore”?  Literally who?!  Man, stop paying attention to all this mainstream, normie-ass hoopty-doopty-ass rubbish, and go watch a quality movie.  I am, of course, referring to “Everything Everywhere All At Once.”Brought to us by the same creative minds as “Swiss Army Man,” “Everything Everywhere All At Once” is a purposeful and profound experience.  This film had me laughing in a way that I haven’t laughed in a movie theater in a long time, and even had me getting a bit teary eyed at certain parts.  There were even a couple of scenes that managed to crack me up and tug at my heart strings at the same time.  All of this, coupled with AMAZINGLY well choreographed fight scenes creates a brilliant movie that hits every mark.  I don’t want to get into too much detail, as everyone should experience this movie with as little information as possible just for the sheer “Rollercoaster Effect” that this movie has on it’s viewers.It's so refreshing to watch a movie that isn't a reboot, or a remake or a reimagining of something else!  This is easily one of the best movies of 2022 and I can’t see too many other movies topping it.  9/10

Everything everywhere all at once. This movie is over the place, dreamy, 天马行空. It uses the facade of multiverse to discuss real family problems. Every small decision we make has huge implication in our life and other universe. The fighting scene reminds me a lot of The Matrix- uploading skill pack. The first 30 mins audience can still try to understand it. But after that, it’s just impossible to grasp. Director is great at using slow mo, cinematography, and music to manipulate audience emotions- basically an intense emotional roller coaster. The simplest way to understand this movie is that lady has a lot of stress- from IRS audit, from divorce request, from daughter being gay and abandoned family, from father’s disapproval, etc. Everything is fake and in her head and she’s trying to find resolution. She finally found peace at the end. Such a complicated but beautiful movie

Top marks for originality, and also great performances from everyone involved. However I have to say I felt exhausted after watching this confusing, overlong, mess of a movie. The multiverse concept is already a well-worn trope, andTop marks for originality, and also great performances from everyone involved. However I have to say I felt exhausted after watching this confusing, overlong, mess of a movie. The multiverse concept is already a well-worn trope, and ultimately the basic message of the film is quite simplistic. Too many effects, too much cgi and too many comedy kung-fu fights made me feel as though the director was making it up as he went along and throwing everything possible at the screen in case some of it stuck. I hear they originally wrote the main part for Jackie Chan, and it's a shame as he would have been ideal for this - though Michelle Yeoh was a good stand in. Overall I can't say I enjoyed this movie and felt it wasn't nearly as clever as it thought it was.

I pretty much HATED the first 2 hours and I actually considered walking out.  It was hyper-dense , overly expositional and I hated the music. My biggest gripe with the film is its art direction - it has the thrown together aesthetic of aI pretty much HATED the first 2 hours and I actually considered walking out.  It was hyper-dense , overly expositional and I hated the music. My biggest gripe with the film is its art direction - it has the thrown together aesthetic of a Gondry movie but without the charm - if it had a lusher more expensive look then the juxta-position of the ludicrous and the logical would have landed better for me and I would have been seduced. BUT at a certain point  the heart of the movie is  through the noise, the music actually gels and I found it quite touching. So in the end I'd rate it as an interesting failure with strong  performances but with writing and aesthetics which let it down.

It was so bizarre and different, even though the story that it was telling was quite universal. Acting was great, action scenes were great, there was a lot of funny moments, although some stuff went a bit too far for me into Jackass territory, but a lot of it still worked somehow. The ending was nice, although a bit cheesy, but I love cheese, so there you go. Really awesome and creative movie, great to see something original that is not a sequel, prequel or an existing IP.

rt_summary: Directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, collectively known as Daniels, the film is a hilarious and big-hearted sci-fi action adventure about an exhausted Chinese American woman (Michelle Yeoh) who can't seem to finish her taxes.
meta_summary: Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh), a flustered immigrant mother, is contacted from a parallel universe and told that only she can save the world. The unlikely hero must learn to channel her newfound powers and fight through the splintering timelines of the multiverse to save her home, her family, and herself.
